State Law reference— Elections, O.C.G.A. tit. 21; challenge of applicant for registration, O.C.G.A. § 21-2-229. Secs. 2-10—2-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - MAYOR AND CITY COUNCIL[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Charter reference— Mayor and city council, §§ 8 et seq., 35, 42.
Sec. 2-41. - Chief executive officer. The mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the city. (Code 1982, § 2-20) Sec. 2-42. - Duties of mayor. It shall be the duty of the mayor to: (1) Preside over the deliberations of the mayor and city council. (2) Have the laws and ordinances of the city put in full force. (3) Supervise all subordinate officers and cause them to perform the duties connected with their respective offices. (4) Adopt such measures as may be deemed proper to ensure the enforcement of this Code and the ordinances of the city. (Code 1982, § 2-21) Charter reference— General duties and powers of mayor, § 14. Sec. 2-43. - Presiding officer. The mayor shall preside at all meetings of the mayor and city council, and in his absence, the mayor pro tem shall preside. If the mayor and mayor pro tem are absent, the city council shall elect a presiding officer or chairperson pro tem who shall preside. (Code 1982, § 2-22) Sec. 2-44. - Mayor pro tem. A mayor pro tem shall be elected by the mayor and city council at its first meeting after the members' election at the time of election of other officers. The mayor pro tem shall serve during the sickness, absence or disability of the mayor and shall be clothed with all rights and privileges of the mayor and perform the mayor's duties. (Code 1982, § 2-23) Charter reference— Selection of mayor pro tem, § 3. Sec. 2-45. - Councilmembers' duties. The duties of the aldermen shall be to: (1) Legislate for the city. (2) Act on such committees and attend to the executive part of the government of the city as the mayor and city council may determine from time to time. (Code 1982, § 2-24) Sec. 2-46. - Compensation. The mayor and councilmembers shall receive salaries as shall be fixed as provided in the Charter of the city. (Code 1982, § 2-25) Charter reference— Compensation of mayor and councilmen, § 13. Sec. 2-47. - Regular meetings. The regular meetings of the mayor and city council shall be held at the council chamber on the third Thursday night in each month. (Code 1982, § 2-26) Sec. 2-48. - Called meetings. Extra meetings of the mayor and city council may be called by the mayor in case of necessity or emergency, in which event, the members of the city council not out of the city shall be notified. Any business may be transacted at a called meeting that may be done at a regular meeting. (Code 1982, § 2-27) Sec. 2-49. - Minutes of meetings. Minutes are to be kept of all the transactions of the mayor and city council, showing, among other things, which members are present, and how each member voted on all motions, where an aye and nay vote is called for. All contracts shall be spread on the minutes. No paid claim shall be placed on the minutes, except when ordered by the mayor and city council, but the city clerk shall keep a record of claims paid in a book kept for such purpose. (Code 1982, § 2-28) Sec. 2-50. - Parliamentary procedure at meetings. The proceedings of the mayor and city council shall be governed by the general rules of parliamentary law and practice for other deliberative bodies, so far as applicable and not inconsistent with the special rules of the mayor and city council, the Charter and the ordinances of the city. (Code 1982, § 2-29) Sec. 2-51. - Duties upon passage of ordinances; publication discretionary. After the passage of an ordinance, the ordinance shall be signed by the mayor and transcribed by the city clerk in the book of ordinances, and shall be published in a newspaper of the city, at the discretion of the mayor. (Code 1982, § 2-30) Sec. 2-52. - Effective date of ordinances. Ordinances which do not provide for their taking effect at a different time shall take effect immediately after their passage, without reference to their publication in a newspaper. (Code 1982, § 2-31) Sec. 2-53. - Appointment of committees. At the first regular meeting following each election, the mayor shall appoint from the city council, by order entered on the minutes, such committees as may be necessary for the proper government of the city. (Code 1982, § 2-32) Sec. 2-54. - Community development committee. The duties of the community development committee shall be to: (1) Perform and coordinate any action or activity required on behalf of the city in the implementation and execution of any federal or state grant. (2) Coordinate such actions and activities with the mayor and city council, the Middle Georgia Regional Development Center and other state or federal agencies. (3) Perform such other duties as may be required. (Code 1982, § 2-33) Secs. 2-55—2-90. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- Cross reference— Any ordinance fixing compensation or other benefits of officers or employees of the city saved from repeal, § 1-7(4); inspectors for buildings and building regulations, § 18-5; emergency management director, § 30-32; chief of the fire department, § 42-32; chief of police, § 54-61 et seq.; enforcing officer for subdivisions, app. A, art. IV, § A; enforcing officer for zoning, app. B, § 101 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-91—2-110. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - CODE OF ETHICS
Sec. 2-111. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: City official means the mayor, all members of the city council and any and all other persons appointed to represent the city on any board or commission unless specifically exempted from this division by the mayor and city council. Complaint means a written statement containing specific allegations of misconduct by a city official; provided, however, such allegations must be filed within six months of the discovery of the alleged misconduct. Interest means any direct pecuniary benefit, which is not a remote interest held by, or accruing to, a city official as a result of a contract or transaction that is, or may be, the subject of an official act or action by, or with, the city. (Amd. of 1-20-2000) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 2-112. - Findings. The city is governed by a representative democracy. Persons who are elected, appointed and hired to serve the public are required to fulfill their public duties in a manner that is fair, faithful and honest in order to preserve the public trust. This requires that the government be conducted in an open manner, when appropriate, so that the public will have access to information about the decisions that are made that affect them. Public trust also requires that acts which are contrary to the public interest be defined and prohibited; ethical behavior be encouraged; and unethical behavior be discouraged in a process that is fundamentally fair. (Ord. of 11-18-1999, intro. ¶) Sec. 2-113. - Purpose; adoption. (a) It is essential to the proper administration and operation of the city that the public servants be, and give the appearance of being, independent and impartial; public office not be used for private gain; and there be public confidence in the integrity of the mayor and city council. In recognition of this purpose, a code of ethics for all city officials is hereby adopted. (b) The purpose of the code of ethics is to: (1) Encourage high ethical standards in official conduct by city officials. (2) Establish guidelines for ethical standards of conduct for all such officials by setting forth the acts or actions that are incompatible with the best interests of the city. (3) Require disclosure by such officials of private financial or other interest in manners affecting such interest. (4) Serve as a basis for disciplining persons who refuse to abide by its terms. (Ord. of 11-18-1999, art. I) Sec. 2-114. - Applicability. The provisions of the code of ethics shall be applicable to the mayor and all members of the city council and any and all other persons appointed to represent the city on any board or commission unless specifically exempted from this division by the mayor and city council. (Ord. of 11-18-1999, art. II) Sec. 2-115. - Standards of conduct. (a) No city official shall: (1) Use such position to secure special privileges or exemptions for such person or others, or secure confidential information for any purpose other than official responsibilities; (2) In any matter before the city council or board or commission in which he has a substantial interest, fail to disclose such interest prior to any discussion or vote; (3) Directly or indirectly receive, or agree to receive, any compensation, gift, reward or gratuity in any matter or proceeding connected with, or related to, the duties of his office, except as may be provided by law; (4) Enter into any contract with the city, except as specifically authorized by state statute. Any city official who has a proprietary interest in an agency doing business with the city shall make that interest known, in writing, to the city council; (5) Use public funds in any manner, except in a manner which is for the general welfare of the people and not for personal economic gain; (6) Grant or make available to any person any consideration, treatment, advantage or favor beyond that which it is the general practice to grant or make available to the public at large; (7) By conduct, give a reasonable basis for the impression that any person can improperly influence him or unduly enjoy his favor in the performance of official acts. (b) This section shall in no way prohibit: (1) A nonpecuniary gift of insignificant value; (2) An award publicly presented in recognition of public service; (3) A commercially reasonable loan or other financial transaction made in the ordinary course of business by an institution or individual authorized by the laws of the state to engage in the making of such loan or financial transaction; (4) Campaign contributions made and reported in accordance with state law. (Ord. of 11-18-1999, art. III) Sec. 2-116. - Board of ethics created; composition. (a) There is hereby created a board of ethics, consisting of five residents of the city to be appointed as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. Each member of the board of ethics shall have been a resident of the city for at least one year immediately preceding the date of taking office and shall remain a resident of the city while serving as a member of the board of ethics. No person shall serve as a member of the board of ethics if the person has, or has had within the preceding one-year period, any interest in any contract, transaction or official action of the city. (b) The mayor and councilmembers shall each designate two qualified citizens to provide a pool of 14 individuals who have consented to serve as members of the board of ethics and who will be available for a period of two years to be called upon to serve if a board of ethics is appointed. (c) The city administrator shall maintain a listing of the 14 qualified citizens. Should it be determined a complaint warrants a hearing before the board of ethics, the mayor and city council, at the first public meeting after such determination, shall draw names randomly from the listing of qualified citizens until the specified five members of the board of ethics have been appointed. Such board of ethics will elect one of its members to serve as chairperson. (d) The members of the board of ethics shall serve without compensation. The mayor and city council shall provide space for the board of ethics. Subject to budgetary procedures and requirements of the city, the city shall provide the board of ethics with such supplies and equipment as may be reasonably necessary for the board of ethics to perform its duties and responsibilities. (Ord. of 11-18-1999, art. IV) Sec. 2-117. - Duties and powers of board of ethics. (a) The constituted board of ethics shall have the following duties and powers: (1) Establish procedures, rules and regulations governing its internal organization and conduct of its affairs; (2) Hold a hearing within 60 days after the receipt of a complaint. Failure to hold a hearing within the specified time shall result in the complaint being deferred to mayor and city council for disposition; (3) Receive and hear complaints of violations of the standards required in this division; (4) Make such investigation and response to a complaint as it deems necessary to determine whether any person has violated any provision of this division; (5) Hold such hearings and make such inquiries as deemed necessary to investigate and rule upon complaints; (6) Report its findings to the mayor and city council within five days of the completion of the hearing for such action as the mayor and city council deem appropriate. (Ord. of 11-18-1999, art. V) Sec. 2-118. - Violations; disciplinary action. Violations of the code of ethics shall subject the offender to disciplinary action by the mayor and city council that may include censure, public or private reprimand and/or request for resignation. (Ord. of 11-18-1999, art. VI) Secs. 2-119—2-140. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - CITY CLERK AND TREASURER[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Editor's note— An ordinance adopted by the mayor and city council of the city on December 17, 1987, amended section 19 of the Charter to provide for a city administrator in lieu of the clerk and treasurer and subsection (e)2 thereof provides that the city administrator shall perform all the duties of the office of clerk and treasurer as provided in the city Charter. Charter reference— City administrator to perform duties of city clerk and treasurer, § 19.
Sec. 2-141. - Appointment. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: City clerk and city treasurer shall refer to the city clerk and treasurer. (b) There shall be an officer known as the city clerk and treasurer, who shall also be the ex officio tax receiver and tax collector, who shall be appointed and hold office as provided in the Charter. (Code 1982, § 2-40) Charter reference— Appointment, duties, §§ 18, 19, 38. Sec. 2-142. - Filling vacancies in office. If any vacancy in the office of the city clerk shall occur, the mayor shall fill the office by appointment until the next regular meeting of the mayor and city council after such vacancy occurs, at which time, the mayor and city council shall elect an officer to fill the unexpired term. (Code 1982, § 2-41) Sec. 2-143. - Oath and bond. The city clerk and treasurer, before entering on the discharge of his official duties, shall take and subscribe to an oath and give bond to faithfully perform the duties as clerk and treasurer, tax collector and tax receiver. The bond shall be in such sum as the mayor and city council may prescribe and shall have good and solvent security to be approved by the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 2-42) Charter reference— Required bond, § 19(f). State Law reference— Indemnification of public officers and employees, O.C.G.A. § 45-9-1 et seq.; personal liability of municipal officers, O.C.G.A. § 36-33-4. Sec. 2-144. - Duties. The duties of the city clerk and treasurer, as such, and as ex officio tax collector and tax receiver, shall be to: (1) Attend every meeting of the mayor and city council and keep a fair record of the proceedings thereof in a book to be provided for such purpose. (2) Issue all summonses, writs, processes and other papers necessary for the enforcement of the laws, ordinances and regulations of the city, or which may be required of such officer. (3) Issue all licenses to persons entitled, upon their compliance with the requirements in relation thereto, and keep a record of the issuance of such licenses in a separate book to be kept for such purpose, in which such officer shall state the name of the person applying for the license, the nature of the license and the amount received. (4) Keep a supply of such other official forms, as may be necessary. (5) Preserve and keep all records and files of the mayor and city council. (6) Transcribe from the minutes in a separate book, known as an ordinance book, all ordinances passed by the mayor and city council from time to time. (7) Publish such notices as are required to be published. (8) Be receiver of tax returns, make up the digest, collect property taxes and do such other things in reference to taxes as may be required by ordinance. (9) Collect all moneys from every other source due the city not otherwise provided for in this section. (10) Keep a written record of all money collected from property tax, fines and forfeitures, sale of city property or other sources. The record shall be kept so as to show each separate item collected under its own proper head and shall be balanced by payments to the general fund. (11) Be the custodian of the funds of the city, deposit all the funds at a solvent bank in the city as designated by the mayor and city council, and receive and pay out all moneys in the manner prescribed by law. (12) Keep a written record of each account paid by the city, item by item, giving the date of payment. (13) Keep his office open during the business hours of each day. (14) Perform such other acts as may be required of such officer in the Charter or by the mayor and city council pertaining to such office. (Code 1982, § 2-43) Charter reference— Duties of clerk and treasurer, §§ 19, 38. Sec. 2-145. - Reports. (a) At the end of each month, the clerk and treasurer shall make a detailed report of transactions for the month, bringing forward the balance and showing the amount on hand at the close of the month. Such reports shall be referred to the finance committee, which shall examine it and report as to its correctness at the next meeting. (b) At the close of each year, the clerk and treasurer shall make a consolidated report of financial transactions during the year and shall submit the report to the mayor and city council for approval. (Code 1982, § 2-44) Sec. 2-146. - Duties upon leaving office. At the expiration of the term of office, the clerk and treasurer shall turn over to his successor the balance of the city's money in such officer's hands for which such officer may be liable, take a receipt for such money, and make a final report to the mayor and city council at its next meeting. (Code 1982, § 2-45) Sec. 2-147. - Paying out money from treasury. The clerk and treasurer shall pay out no money, except as provided in this Code and in the ordinances and Charter of the city. Payments in an unauthorized manner will not be allowed to such officer as credits. (Code 1982, § 2-46) Secs. 2-148—2-170. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - CITY ATTORNEY[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- Cross reference— Authority of city attorney, § 62-9.
Sec. 2-171. - Appointment. There may be appointed a city attorney. If a city attorney is appointed, such attorney shall be appointed by the mayor and city council at the same time the city clerk is appointed, and shall hold office at the pleasure of the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 2-50) Charter reference— Authority to appoint attorneys, § 20. Sec. 2-172. - Duties. The city attorney shall act as legal advisor to the mayor and city council and shall represent the city in all legal matters before any court. At the request of the mayor and city council, the city attorney shall defend all officers or employees of the city in any suit or prosecution for any act in the discharge of their official duties. When required by the mayor and city council, the city attorney shall also act as attorney and counsel for any officer of the city in any prosecution or proceeding which may be instituted by order of the mayor and city council or by such officer in any court other than the municipal court. The city attorney shall do every professional act incidental to such office which may be required of such attorney by the mayor and city council and shall furnish, upon request, any city officer or employee with advice touching the duties of such officer or employee. The city attorney shall prosecute such offenders before the municipal court as may be requested by the mayor and city council. At the end of his term, the city attorney shall make a report to the mayor and city council of the condition and status of all city litigation. The city attorney shall attend the meetings of the mayor and city council, when required. (Code 1982, § 2-51) Sec. 2-173. - Compensation. The city attorney shall receive as a retainer, for advice and other work performed for the city, such compensation as may be determined, each year, by the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 2-52) Secs. 2-174—2-200. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES[6] Footnotes: --- (6) --- Cross reference— Any ordinance establishing a commission, authority or agency not inconsistent with this Code saved from repeal, § 1-7(17); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; bureau of fire prevention, § 42-71; historic preservation commission, § 50-4; board of trustees, § 58-51 et seq.; planning commission, § 74-31 et seq.; utility commission, § 90-41 et seq.; board of zoning appeals, app. B, § 111 et seq.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 2-201. - Code enforcement board. There shall be created for the citizens of the city, a seven-member board to be known as the Fort Valley Code Enforcement Board, having all powers authorized by the state as enumerated in O.C.G.A. § 36-74-1 et seq. (Res. of 9-19-2002) Secs. 2-202—2-220. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - COMMITTEE ON THE HANDICAPPED[7]
Footnotes: --- (7) --- State Law reference— Local fire departments generally, O.C.G.A. § 25-31-1 et seq.; Georgia Firefighter Standards and Training Act, O.C.G.A. § 25-4-1 et seq.
Sec. 2-221. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Appeal means a request to the mayor and city council to reconsider the decision and procedures of the committee on the handicapped. Committee on the handicapped means a committee that consists of five members of the community, selected by the mayor and city council, knowledgeable on the problems of the handicapped, or representing a handicapped group or organization, each member of which will have demonstrated sound judgment and civic pride and will serve a two-year term. Evidentiary hearing means a hearing before the committee on the handicapped where a grievant and management may present testimony and evidence in support of their respective positions. Grievance form means the standard form promulgated by the city for the purpose of reporting and processing grievances. Handicapped coordinator means the management official designated to be responsible for coordination of efforts to comply with the handicapped discrimination regulations. (Code 1982, § 17-50) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 2-222. - Procedure for filing and handling grievances. (a) Within 90 days of the effective date of an alleged discriminatory act or condition, or 90 days from the date that the grievant could reasonably be expected to have knowledge of the existence of the act or condition, the grievant must request and submit a grievance form with the city clerk's office. Complaints arising from actions and conditions which are ongoing or repetitive in nature shall be considered timely. (b) Upon receiving the grievance form, the city clerk shall forward the grievance form to the management official designated as the handicapped coordinator. (c) Within ten business days, the handicapped coordinator shall determine the merit of the complaint, meet and confer with the grieving party and attempt to resolve the complaint. (d) If the problem remains unresolved, the city clerk shall, upon receiving the grievance form from the handicapped coordinator, notify and convene the committee on the handicapped. (e) Within ten business days of such notification, the committee on the handicapped shall conduct an evidentiary hearing on the subject grievance and prepare a written recommendation to resolve the problem. The grievance form and recommendation shall be returned to the city clerk for administrative review by the mayor and city council. (f) The city clerk shall present the recommendation of the committee on the handicapped and the grievance form to the mayor or the chairperson of the committee on the handicapped. Within ten business days, the mayor and city council shall review and approve or modify the recommendation. (g) The city clerk shall notify the grievant regarding the disposition of the grievance. (h) If the grievance remains unresolved by the committee on the handicapped's recommendation, the grievant may, in writing, direct the city clerk to prepare his grievance form for appeal by the mayor and city council at the next regularly scheduled meeting. (i) Upon submission of an appeal, the mayor and city council shall conduct an independent investigation. The mayor and city council may elect to delegate such finding of fact to counsel. A resolution of the problem shall be rendered at the following regularly scheduled meeting. The decision of the mayor and city council shall be final. (Code 1982, § 17-51) Secs. 2-223—2-230. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - CODE ENFORCEMENT BOARD
Sec. 2-231. - Short title; authority. This division shall be known and may be cited as the City of Fort Valley Code Enforcement Board Ordinance. This division is authorized by O.C.G.A. § 36-74-20, et seq. (Ord. No. 03-0918-65, § 1, 9-18-2003) Sec. 2-232. - Intent. It is the intent of this division to promote, protect and improve the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Fort Valley by the creation of an administrative board with authority to impose administrative fines and other noncriminal penalties to provide an equitable, expeditious, effective and inexpensive method of enforcing any codes and ordinances in force in the city where a pending or repeated violation continues to exist. (Ord. No. 03-0918-65, § 2, 9-18-2003) Sec. 2-233. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Code inspector means any authorized agent or employee of the city whose duty it is to ensure code compliance. City means the City of Fort Valley, Georgia. City of Fort Valley codes and ordinances means City of Fort Valley zoning ordinances and resolutions, ordinances and resolutions enacting subdivision regulations, environmental ordinances and resolutions, state minimum standard codes provided for in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25, ordinances and resolutions enacted pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25, other ordinances and resolutions regulating the development of real property, and ordinances and regulations providing for control of litter and debris, control of junked or abandoned vehicles, and control of overgrown vegetation. Notwithstanding the above, the term "City of Fort Valley codes and ordinances" shall not include: (1) Those codes and ordinances requiring a permit, unless the alleged violator has failed to secure all necessary valid permits under said codes and ordinances; or (2) Any local amendments to the state minimum standard codes provided for in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25 that have not been adopted in conformity with the requirements of subsection (c) of O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25. Enforcement board means the City of Fort Valley Code Enforcement Board. Mayor and council means the mayor and council of the City of Fort Valley. Violation involving the health or safety of a third party means a violation that creates a legitimate concern for the health and safety of a third party occupant of a dwelling place or that creates an immediate and substantial danger to the environment. (Ord. No. 03-0918-65, § 3, 9-18-2003) Sec. 2-234. - Organization of the code enforcement board. (a) The enforcement board shall consist of seven members appointed by resolution of the city. In making appointments to the enforcement board, the mayor and council shall make good faith efforts to appoint up to two alternate members for the enforcement board to serve on the board in the absence of board members. (b) Members of the enforcement board shall be residents of the city. In making appointments to the enforcement board, the mayor and council shall make good faith efforts to appoint one or more individuals who have experience or expertise relevant to one or more of the municipal codes that are within the subject matter jurisdiction of the enforcement board, including individuals with property management and litter control experience; provided, however, that the authority and jurisdiction of the enforcement board shall not in any way be limited due to the absence from its membership of one or more individuals with such experience or expertise. (c) Appointment; terms. (1) The initial appointments to the enforcement board shall be as follows: Three members appointed for a term of two years each; and four members appointed for a term of four years each. (2) Upon the expiration of the initial terms specified above, all terms shall be for three years. (3) A member may be reappointed by resolution of the mayor and council. (4) An appointment to fill any vacancy on the enforcement board shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term of office. If any member fails to attend two of three successive meetings without cause and without prior approval of the chairperson, the enforcement board shall declare the member's office vacant, and the mayor and council shall promptly fill such vacancy. (5) The members shall serve in accordance with the policies and procedures of the city and may be suspended and removed for cause. The mayor and council may, with or without cause, refuse to reappoint any member of the enforcement board at the expiration of his term of office. (d) The members of the enforcement board shall elect a chairperson, who shall be a voting member, from among the members of the board. The presence of four or more members shall constitute a quorum of the enforcement board. Members shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for such travel, mileage, and per diem expenses as may be authorized by the mayor and council or as otherwise provided by law. (Ord. No. 03-0918-65, § 4, 9-18-2003) Sec. 2-235. - Enforcement procedures. (a) It shall be the duty of the code inspector to initiate enforcement proceedings pursuant to the various codes; however, no member of the enforcement board shall have the power to initiate such enforcement proceedings. (b) Except as provided in subsections (c) and (d) of this section, if a violation of any code or ordinance is found, the code inspector shall notify the violator and give him a reasonable time to correct the violation. Should the violation continue beyond the time specified for correction, the code inspector shall proceed with enforcement through the enforcement board. If the code inspector proceeds through the enforcement board, the code inspector shall notify the enforcement board and request a hearing. The enforcement board shall schedule a hearing, and written notice of such hearing shall be hand delivered or made as provided in section 2-240 to said violator. At the option of the enforcement board, notice may additionally be served by publication as provided in section 2-240. If the violation is corrected and then recurs or if the violation is not corrected by the time specified for correction by the code inspector, the case may be presented to the enforcement board even if the violation has been corrected prior to the hearing, and the notice shall so state. (c) If a repeat violation is found, the code inspector shall notify the violator but is not required to give the violator a reasonable time to correct the violation. The code inspector, upon notifying the violator of a repeat violation, shall notify the enforcement board and request a hearing. The enforcement board shall schedule a hearing and shall provide written notice pursuant to section 2-240. The case may be presented to the enforcement board even if the repeat violation has been corrected prior to the hearing, and the notice shall so state. (d) If the code inspector has substantial reason to believe a violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety and welfare or if the violation is irreparable or irreversible in nature, the code inspector shall make a reasonable effort to notify the violator and may immediately notify the enforcement board and request a hearing. (Ord. No. 03-0918-65, § 5, 9-18-2003) Sec. 2-236. - Conduct of hearing. (a) Upon request of the code inspector, or at such other times as may be necessary, the chairperson of the enforcement board may call a hearing by the enforcement board. Minutes shall be kept of all hearings by the enforcement board, and all hearings and proceedings shall be open to the public. The mayor and council may provide or assign clerical and administrative personnel to assist the enforcement board in the proper performance of its duties. (b) Each case before the enforcement board shall be presented by the city attorney or by the code inspector or other member of the administrative staff. (c) The enforcement board shall proceed to hear the cases on the agenda for that day. All testimony shall be under oath and shall be recorded. The enforcement board shall take testimony from the code inspector and alleged violator. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply, but fundamental due process shall be observed and shall govern the proceedings. (d) At the conclusion of the hearing, the enforcement board shall issue findings of fact, based on evidence of record and conclusions of law, and shall issue an order affording the proper relief consistent with owners granted in this division. The findings and conclusions shall be motion-approved by a majority of those members present and voting, except that at least four members of the enforcement board must vote in order for the action to be official. The order may include a notice that it must be complied with by a specified date and a fine may be imposed if the order is not complied with by said date. A certified copy of such order may be recorded in the public records of the city and Peach County and shall constitute notice to any subsequent purchasers, successors in interest, or assigns if the violation concerns real property, and the findings therein shall be binding upon the violator and, if the violation concerns real property, subsequent purchasers, successors in interest, or assigns. If an order is recorded in the public records pursuant to this subsection and the order is complied with by the date specified in the order, the enforcement board shall issue an order acknowledging compliance that shall be recorded in the public records. A hearing is not required to issue such an order acknowledging compliance. (Ord. No. 03-0918-65, § 6, 9-18-2003) Sec. 2-237. - Powers. The enforcement board shall have the power to: (1) Adopt rules for the conduct of its hearings, which rules shall, at a minimum, ensure that each side has an equal opportunity to present evidence and argument in support of its case; (2) Subpoena alleged violators and witnesses to its hearings, with the approval of the court with jurisdiction over a criminal violator of the municipal code or ordinance. Subpoenas may be served by an officer of the police department or by any other individual not less than 18 years of age; (3) Subpoena evidence to its hearings in the same way as provided in subsection (2) of this section, with the approval of the court with jurisdiction over a criminal violator of the municipal code or ordinance; (4) Take testimony under oath; and (5) Issue orders having the force of law to command whatever steps are necessary to bring a violation into compliance. (Ord. No. 03-0918-65, § 7, 9-18-2003) Sec. 2-238. - Administrative fines and liens. (a) The enforcement board, upon notification by the code inspector that an order of the enforcement board has not been complied with by the set time, may order the violator to pay an administrative fine in an amount specified in this section. (b) Fines. (1) An administrative fine imposed pursuant to this section for a violation involving the health or safety of a third party shall not exceed $1,000.00 per day. (2) An administrative fine imposed pursuant to this section for a violation that is not a violation involving the health or safety of a third party shall not exceed a total of $1,000.00. (3) In determining the amount of the fine, if any, the enforcement board shall consider the following factors: a. The gravity of the violation; b. Any actions taken by the violator to correct the violation; and c. Any previous violations committed by the violator. (4) The enforcement board may reduce a fine imposed pursuant to this section. (c) A certified copy of an order imposing an administrative fine maybe recorded in the public records of any county and thereafter shall constitute a lien against the property on which the violation exists and upon any real or personal property owned by the violator. Upon petition to the superior court, such order may be enforced in the same manner as a court judgment by the sheriffs of this state, including levy against the personal property, but such order shall not be deemed to be a court judgment except for enforcement purposes. After three months after the filing of any such lien which remains unpaid, the enforcement board may request the city attorney to foreclose on the lien. (Ord. No. 03-0918-65, § 8, 9-18-2003) Sec. 2-239. - Appeals. An aggrieved party, including the city, may appeal a final administrative order of the enforcement board to the superior court. Such an appeal shall be a hearing de novo. An appeal shall be filed within 30 days of the execution of the order to be appealed. (Ord. No. 03-0918-65, § 9, 9-18-2003) Sec. 2-240. - Notices. (a) All notices required by this division shall be provided to the alleged violator by certified mail, return receipt requested; by hand delivery by any law enforcement officer, code inspector, or other person designated by the city; or by leaving the notice at the violator's usual place of residence with any person residing therein who is above 15 years of age and informing such person of the contents of the notice. (b) In addition to providing notice as set forth in subsection (a) of this section, at the option of the enforcement board, notice may also be served by publication, as follows: (1) Notice may be published once during each week for four consecutive weeks (four publications being sufficient) in the newspaper in which the sheriff's advertisements are printed in Peach County. Proof of publication shall be made by affidavit of a duly authorized representative of the newspaper; (2) Notice by publication may run concurrently with, or may follow, attempts to provide notice by hand delivery or by mail as required under subsection (a) of this section. Evidence that an attempt has been made to hand deliver or mail notice as provided in subsection (a) of this section, together (Ord. No. 03-0918-65, § 10, 9-18-2003) Sec. 2-241. - Provisions are supplemental. It is the intent of this division to provide an additional or supplemental means of obtaining compliance with local codes. Nothing contained herein shall prohibit the city, through its code inspector, from enforcing its des by any other lawful means including criminal and civil proceedings; provided, however, that the city shall not pursue a specific instance of an alleged violation of an ordinance against one violator before both the enforcement board and a magistrate, municipal or other court authorized to hear ordinance violations. (Ord. No. 03-0918-65, § 11, 9-18-2003) Secs. 2-242—2-250. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - FINANCE[8]
Footnotes: --- (8) --- Charter reference— Enforcement by execution of the collection of moneys due city, § 31; revenue from operation of utilities, § 33; issuance of fi. fas., § 34; levy of executions, § 37; clerk and treasurer as custodian of funds, § 38. Cross reference— Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city saved from repeal, § 1-7(2); taxation, ch. 82.
Sec. 2-251. - Purchases. All purchases for the city shall be made by and through the office of the city clerk. (Code 1982, § 9-1) Charter reference— City administrator designated purchasing agent, § 19(e)(8). Sec. 2-252. - Requisitions; purchase orders. (a) Before issuing a purchase order for any work to be performed or any supplies for the city, the purchasing agent shall require the official or employee of the city applying for the purchase order to furnish a requisition therefor, showing the supplies or work wanted and the name of the department to which it is chargeable. (b) The city shall not be liable for any purchase made, work done or service rendered for which a purchase order has not first been issued and signed by the purchasing agent. (c) When a purchase requisition is received by the purchasing agent and it is determined that sufficient funds to cover the cost of the purchase do not exist in the identified line item of the budget, no purchase order will be issued. If funds are to be transferred from one line item to another within the department's budget, such information must be reflected on the requisition form and authorized by the signature of the appropriate committee chairperson. (d) If the transfer of funds, as outlined in subsection (c) of this section, cannot be accomplished or the purchase will cause the requesting department to exceed its total appropriated budget, the request will be transferred to the mayor and city council through the finance committee for its approval. (e) Any purchase classified as an emergency purchase must be identified as such on the requisition form and bear the signatures of the appropriate department head and committee chairperson at the time the requisition is submitted for a purchase order. (f) Under no circumstances will the purchasing agent be authorized to issue a city purchase order for a purchase made that predates the purchase requisition form unless authorized by the finance committee. (Code 1982, § 9-2) Sec. 2-253. - Incurring indebtedness without purchase order. No official or employee of the city shall have the authority to incur any indebtedness against the city without first securing a purchase order from the purchasing agent as provided in section 2-252. Any such official or employee found violating this section shall be held strictly accountable for such violation and liable to removal from office within the discretion of the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 9-3) Sec. 2-254. - Approval of bills against city. All bills against the city shall first be approved by the chairperson of the committee under whose jurisdiction they fall and then approved by the chairperson of the finance committee, or in case of such chairperson's absence, by a member of the finance committee, before payment thereof. (Code 1982, § 9-4) Sec. 2-255. - Drawing and signing of vouchers and checks. All vouchers and checks shall be drawn by the clerk and treasurer, and shall be signed by two of the following: (1) The mayor. (2) The city administrator. (3) A councilmember. (Code 1982, § 9-5; Res. of 4-21-1994) Sec. 2-256. - Payment of moneys collected by officers and employees. All moneys collected for or on behalf of the city by any city officer or employee shall be promptly paid over to the finance director. (Code 1982, § 9-6) Sec. 2-257. - Guidelines for travel expenses generally. (a) Requests for requisitions for travel expenses shall be presented to the finance committee for preapproval no later than ten days prior to the scheduled trip. (b) Registration forms and meeting agendas shall be attached to the expense requisition form, along with an explanation of how the trip constitutes or qualifies as official business. (c) When a requisition form is submitted at least ten days prior to the scheduled trip, the finance committee shall notify the requester, in writing, whether the request is approved, and if so, the amount of expenses approved for payment. (d) If the requester disagrees with all or part of a decision from the finance committee, the matter shall be brought before the entire mayor and city council for resolution. (e) Emergency trips can be approved by the city administrator and/or the mayor and two councilmembers. (Res. of 8-17-1995) Sec. 2-258. - Per diem and travel expenses for elected officials. (a) If any city elected official desires to attend an event out of the city, but within the state, which is related to his position and responsibilities with the city, he shall be reimbursed for the expenses of attending the meeting as provided by the mayor and city council. (b) The extent of reimbursement for expenses incurred for travel outside of the state shall be determined preceding the meeting, provided that the need for attendance has been preapproved by the mayor and city council. (Res. of 8-17-1995; Res. of 3-18-1999)

div.head: Chapter 6 - ADVERTISING[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Publishing of advertisements; signs for alcoholic beverages, § 10-8; businesses, ch. 22; parking for washing, greasing, repairing and advertising, § 86-144; signs required for taxicabs, § 94-42. State Law reference— False advertising, O.C.G.A. § 10-1-420 et seq.; misrepresenting ownership in advertising liquidation, auction or going out of business sale prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 10-1-425; unauthorized signs on public roads, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-51; outdoor advertising, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-70 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 6-1—6-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SIGNS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Signs on utility poles, § 90-9; use requirements by districts, app. B, § 71 et seq.
Sec. 6-31. - Generally. (a) Signs may be erected in the city for the purpose of displaying the business name or other advertising of the firm or business on whose premises the sign is located, provided such sign meets the regulations provided for by this article. A sign permit must be obtained from the city building inspector prior to the installation or erection of any permanent sign. A sign permit is also required where permanent signs are painted on the building for the purpose of displaying the firm or business name, or other advertising as provided for by this article. (b) No sign erected for any purpose shall be erected upon, or extended over or onto, any public property (right-of-way), unless it is specifically provided for by this article. A sign, banners, flags, etc., which are customarily used to advertise conventions, festivals, etc., or that may be a part of a civic or community project may be erected on public or private property, provided permission is obtained from the owner of such property. A sign identifying a church shall be allowed in any district where churches are allowed, provided the sign is located on the same property on which the church is located, and the sign and placement thereof shall be approved by the planning commission prior to the erection of the sign. No permit fee shall be charged for church signs. (c) Portable signs shall not be allowed within any district of the city. (d) Flashing signs shall be prohibited in any district of the city. (e) The provisions of this article shall not apply to the following: (1) Traffic and other municipal signs, such as railroad crossing signs, legal notices and such temporary emergency signs as may be authorized by the city administrator. (2) Signs of public utility companies indicating danger, or which serve as an aid to public safety, or which show the location of underground facilities or public telephones. (3) The prohibition of flashing lights shall not include public service information, such as time, date, temperature or similar information. (4) Directional, information or public service signs, including signs pertaining to public utilities, not exceeding four square feet in area, erected for the convenience of the public, such as signs identifying entrances, exits, parking or no parking areas, restrooms, public telephones, walkways and similar facilities. (5) Signs located on the interior, or within an enclosed lobby or court, of any building, or group of buildings, which signs are designed and located to be viewed exclusively by patrons of such uses. (6) No trespassing signs, or other such signs regulating the use of property, such as no hunting, no fishing, etc., of no more than two square feet in area. (7) Residential development identification structures at major entrances designed to identify a residential subdivision or planned unit development and containing no commercial advertisement. Such structures must be approved by the planning commission. (8) Construction signs identifying the architects, engineers, contractors or other individuals or firms involved with the construction of a building or facility, provided the total area of such signs do not exceed 32 square feet. Such signs shall be confined to the site of the construction and shall be removed within three days of project occupancy. (9) Memorial signs or tablets and names of buildings and dates of erection when cut into any masonry surface or inlaid so as to be part of the building or when constructed of any bronze or other noncombustible material. (10) Signs of historical societies containing no advertising and not more than five square feet in area. (11) Marquees of movie theaters which show no obscene or indecent movies. Such marquees may have changeable letters or copy. (12) Public signs, or other signs incidental thereto, for identification, information or directional purposes erected or required by governmental bodies. (Code 1982, § 5-110) Sec. 6-32. - R-1 and R-2 Residential Districts. In R-1 and R-2 Residential Districts, a sign not over two square feet in area may be used to advertise a permitted home occupation, provided the sign is either attached, or immediately adjacent, to the dwelling. Signs in residential areas shall not be illuminated. (Code 1982, § 5-110.1) Sec. 6-33. - NS-1 and NS-2 Neighborhood Shopping Districts. Permanent signs erected, painted or otherwise constructed in NS-1 and NS-2 Neighborhood Shopping Districts shall be limited as follows: (1) The area of the sign shall not exceed ten percent of the area of the front of the building or establishment, measured at the front building line. Stores or establishments having offices above the ground floor shall not include the area of the front of such offices in the area measurement. (2) Only one sign shall be permitted on the front of any store or business establishment. (3) Where a business is located on a corner, an additional sign of equal size will be permitted on the sides of the building. (4) The length of the sign shall not exceed 80 percent of the length of the store's or business establishment's front dimension. (5) The sign shall be parallel to the face or sides of the building and shall not extend over 18 inches from the face or sides of the building. (6) Lighting for signs shall be in white only and shall be designed so as to designate the name of the place of business or products sold by the business, or other advertisement in a twofold manner, so that it shall serve the purpose for both day and nighttime use. (7) Signs may be erected on a pole away from the building, subject to the approval of the building inspector, provided the front of the building is sufficiently set back from the front property line and no part of the sign extends over public property and is not attached to the building. Pole-mounted signs may be erected in addition to the signs allowed to be erected parallel to the face of the building as provided in subsection (5) of this section; however, no more than one pole-mounted sign per lot frontage is permitted. (8) Projecting signs shall be mounted perpendicular to a building front, with a maximum projecting length of five feet, a minimum height of eight feet from ground level, and the maximum total area shall be 20 square feet per parcel. (9) Stock signs are permitted. For the purposes of this subsection, the term "stock signs" means signs which are customarily used by an organization to identify a product or location uniformly throughout the organization's service area. Examples of such signs are: a. Oil company signs which uniformly identify such service stations; b. Signs which identify fast food chain locations; and c. Signs which identify chain or franchised motel or hotel locations. (Code 1982, § 5-110.2; Res. of 9-21-2000) Sec. 6-34. - C-1 Roadside Business Districts. Signs are permitted in the C-1 Roadside Business Districts, provided such signs comply with the regulations outlined in sections 6-31 and 6-33; however, signs in C-1 districts may be illuminated in any desired color. (Code 1982, § 5-110.3) Sec. 6-35. - C-2 and C-3 General and Central Business Districts. Signs are permitted in C-2 and C-3 General and Central Business Districts under the same regulations as provided under section 6-34. In addition, pole-mounted signs are allowed in C-2 and C-3 districts with the following restrictions: (1) On lots of 150 feet or less, one pole-mounted sign may be erected, subject to the applicable provisions of this article, provided that no pole-mounted sign may exceed 32 square feet in area. (2) On lots with 150 feet or more of frontage, pole-mounted signs are allowed under the same provisions as set forth in section 6-34. (Code 1982, § 5-110.4) Sec. 6-36. - I-N and I Institutional and Industrial Districts. Signs are permitted in the I-N and I Institutional and Industrial Districts, provided such signs meet all of the requirements of this section. In addition, off-premises signs may be erected in I-N and I districts, provided that no more than a total of four signs shall be erected on both sides of a street or highway within a space of 600 feet, with not less than 100 feet between such signs. The maximum height of an off-premises sign, not erected on a building, shall be 25 feet above the ground. An off-premises sign erected on a building may be higher than 25 feet above the ground, provided that all portions of such sign are kept within the perimeter of the building, and do not extend more than ten feet above the roofline of the building. The maximum size of any single off-premises sign shall be 400 square feet, inclusive of any border or trim; however, cutouts and extensions may add up to 20 percent of additional sign area. The design and location of all such off-premises advertising signs shall be approved by the planning commission prior to the issuance of a permit from the building inspector for erection of such signs. Any such off-premises advertising sign which has been abandoned for a period of six months, or becomes dilapidated, shall be removed by the owner, upon receipt of a written notice from the building inspector. If the owner of such sign fails to remove the sign within 30 days after receiving written notice, he shall be summoned to the city municipal court for violation of this article. Every off-premises advertising sign shall be set back from the property line or street line the same distance, or a greater distance, than is required in appendix B of this Code for new buildings on the premises. (Code 1982, § 5-110.5) Sec. 6-37. - Misleading, fraudulent, obscene, indecent and unsightly signs. No sign shall be erected or maintained, or be permitted to remain publicly displayed, which is of a misleading, fraudulent, obscene, indecent or unsightly character. (Code 1982, § 5-111.1) Sec. 6-38. - Removal of certain signs. Any sign, painted or otherwise, which no longer advertises a bona fide business conducted, or a product sold, on the premises, or which becomes dilapidated, shall be removed by the owner, agent or person having the beneficial use of the building, pole or other structure upon which the sign may be found. Such removal will be within 30 days after receipt of written notification from the building inspector. Failure to comply with such notice within the time specified shall be sufficient cause for the building inspector to have such sign removed, whereas, any and all expenses of the removal shall be paid by the owner of the building, pole or other structure to which the sign is attached. If the owner should fail to make such payment, such amount shall be assessed against the property the same as unpaid taxes. Such sign shall be considered no longer advertising a bona fide business or product when the business or product has been removed from the premises for a period of 120 days. (Code 1982, § 5-111.2) Sec. 6-39. - Sound- and noise-making devices and instruments. It shall be unlawful to use any radio, phonograph, whistle, bell or other sound- or noise-making or transmitting device or instrument in connection with any sign. (Code 1982, § 5-111.3) Cross reference— Noise, § 38-31 et seq. Sec. 6-40. - Political campaign signs. Political campaign signs announcing the candidates seeking public office, and other data pertinent thereto, shall be allowed any place within the city, as long as such signs are confined to private property, with the permission of the owner of such property, and removed within 14 days after the election or runoff election for which the signs are made. No political campaign signs shall be erected on, or fastened to, any public property. (Code 1982, § 5-111.4) Sec. 6-41. - Real estate signs. A temporary sign advertising the sale, rental or lease of the premises on which the sign is located may be erected without a permit, subject to the following restrictions: (1) Signs in a residential district may not exceed eight square feet in area. (2) Signs in a shopping or business district may not exceed 32 square feet in area. (3) Signs in an institutional or industrial district may not exceed 64 square feet in area. (4) Signs may not be illuminated. (5) Such signs shall be located on the property which is for sale, rent or lease. (Code 1982, § 5-111.5) Sec. 6-42. - Temporary signs advertising special sales. Temporary signs used for advertising special sales in stores or business establishments are permitted, provided that the gross area of all such signs combined, whether painted on windows, cheesecloth, cardboard or any similar material, shall not exceed 30 percent of the total store front area. Such signs shall not extend more than six inches from the face or side of the building. No temporary sign shall be erected or attached to awnings, marquees or other sidewalk sheds or covers. (Code 1982, § 5-111.6)

div.head: Chapter 10 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; consuming or possessing alcoholic beverage in public place, § 62-10. State Law reference— Local licensing of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-40 et seq.; local licensing of malt beverage sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40 et seq.; local licensing of wine sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-40; public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41; furnishing alcoholic beverages to persons under 21 years of age, jurisdiction of municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-10; driving under influence of alcohol, drugs, etc., O.C.G.A. § 40-6-391.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Alcoholic beverage means and includes all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverages, wines or fortified wines. Building code means and includes all building, plumbing and electrical codes and any other similar technical codes of the city. Church means any permanent building and grounds where persons regularly assemble for religious worship and shall not include any church land or property not regularly used as an assembly area for religious worship services. College means only the state, county, city, church or other colleges that teach the subjects commonly taught in the common colleges of the state and shall not include private colleges where only specialized subjects, such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations and other special subjects, are taught. Distance means the measurement in linear feet by the most direct route of travel on the ground and shall be measured in the following manner: (1) From the front door of the structure from which an alcoholic beverage is sold or offered for sale; (2) In a straight line to the nearest public sidewalk, walkway, street, road or highway; (3) Along such public sidewalk, walkway, street, road or highway by the nearest route; (4) To the front door of the building, or to the nearest portion of the grounds, whichever is applicable under the appropriate statute. Distilled spirits means any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation or containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume, including, but not limited to, all fortified wines. Premises means a definite closed or partitioned establishment, whether room, shop or building, wherein alcoholic beverages are sold or consumed. Retail means retail sales packaged to go and not for consumption on the premises. School means only the state, county, city, church or other schools that teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools of the state and shall include the adjacent open land used for school purposes, but shall not include any portion of a private school where only specialized subjects, such as law, stenography, business, music, art, medicine, dentistry, vocational occupations and other special subjects, are taught. (Code 1982, § 3-50) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2. Sec. 10-2. - Scope. The requirements of this chapter shall be in addition to any other requirements for business licenses under this Code. If other provisions of this Code conflict with this chapter, then this chapter shall control. (Code 1982, § 3-51(b)) Sec. 10-3. - Time limits for opening and continuing business. (a) All licensed businesses issued a license under this chapter must open for business within 90 days after the issuance of a city license. Failure to open for business shall constitute a forfeiture and cancellation of the issued licenses and no refund of license fees or business taxes shall be made. Any applicant unable to comply with the time limit of this subsection may make written request to the clerk for an extension of time not to exceed 90 days, and the clerk, at his discretion, may grant or deny the request in accordance with a form approved by the mayor and city council. (b) Any license issued under this chapter shall automatically be null and void where the licensed business has not operated or been open to the public for six consecutive months. (Code 1982, § 3-52) Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22. Sec. 10-4. - Prohibited interests. (a) No person who has any direct financial interest in a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages at wholesale shall hold any other license or any interest in any other license under the terms of this chapter. (b) No person, related within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity under civil law to any wholesale licensee or employee thereof or any person with any interest therein, shall hold any other license or an interest in any other license issued under this chapter. (c) No elected or full-time appointed official of the city or any person, related within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity under civil law to such an official of the city, shall own any interest in any license issued under this chapter unless the interest was obtained prior to election or appointment to office. (d) No applicant under this chapter, nor any member of the immediate family of any applicant under this chapter, shall own, control or have a financial interest in more than two liquor stores, liquor store licenses or liquor businesses within the state and shall not have any interest in any liquor distillery or wholesale liquor distributorship or business any place. (Code 1982, § 3-53) Sec. 10-5. - Applications for new licenses. (a) [Generally.] The provisions of this Code for general business licensing shall apply to applications for new licenses under this chapter, in addition to the following: (1) Fee. All applications for new licenses under this chapter shall be accompanied by a payment, in cash or by certified check, for the first year's license fee in the amount as set by the mayor and city council and business taxes provided for in this Code for the classification into which the applicant falls; (2) Additional information. The city application shall be a photocopy or other copy of all the appropriate state applications and forms, with a city supplemental application form provided by the city, as well as the following: a. A legal description of the property upon which the proposed premises are located, together with a plat of the property by a registered land surveyor; b. A certificate by a registered land surveyor that the proposed premises are not within 300 feet of any church or within 600 feet of any school, schoolground or college campus; c. A current photograph of the applicant; d. Fingerprints of the applicant, to be taken by the police department; e. A certificate from the building inspector as to the zoning classification of the proposed premises. (b) Oath. The application shall also contain a form of oath providing that the information disclosed in the application is true and correct and, providing further, that the applicant will abide by, observe and conduct his business according to the rules and regulations prescribed by the city, the Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code (O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.), as amended, and the rules and regulations of the state department of revenue in respect thereto. The oath shall be taken by the applicant and the agent in charge of the establishment, if different from, or additional to, the applicant, and the oath shall be taken by the true owners. (c) False statement; misrepresentation. Any false statement or material misrepresentation in any application under this section shall be grounds for the revocation of any license granted under this section. (Code 1982, § 3-54) Sec. 10-6. - Agents. Any application by any person for a license under this chapter shall name in the application one or more residents in the county as the agent and representative of the person to receive all communications, notices, services of process or other papers or documents on behalf of the person in connection with any matter arising out of, or connected with, the issuance, holding, suspension, revocation or other action with respect to any city license. The application shall give the mailing address of such persons, and the mailing to any such person at that address of any notice required to be given under this chapter or any other law shall be sufficient notice to the applicant. If any agent shall cease to be a resident of the county, another person shall immediately be appointed in writing in his place, and written notice shall be given to the clerk for stating the name and address of the new agent. (Code 1982, § 3-55) Sec. 10-7. - Tax records inquiries; preliminary approval required; furnishing data; additional requirements; period of processing. (a) The clerk shall cause an inquiry to be made into the city tax records to determine if the applicant or other party with interest in the application has any outstanding taxes or special assessments that are delinquent against his property or any other moneys owing to the city. No license shall be issued or renewed until such debts are paid in full. (b) All applications shall be approved or disapproved by the chief of police as a condition to action thereon and issuance of a license by the clerk. If the chief of police determines that the application is not in order, in view of the requirements of federal or state law, or this Code and any police department investigation, the clerk shall then notify the applicant of the reasons for not issuing the license to the applicant. (c) All applicants shall furnish all reasonable data, information and records requested of them by the clerk or chief of police and failure to furnish such data, information, contracts, documents, financial statements and other records within 30 days of the request shall automatically serve to dismiss the application. (d) The chief of police may require, in addition to the licensee, fingerprinting and a background investigation of any person interested in the application, including any person with a financial interest, such as stockholders, partners or employees, and any spouse, brother, sister, child or parent of any person with a financial interest. Should the applicant fail to produce such persons within 30 days of the request, the application may be denied by the clerk. (e) By filing an application, applicants agree to produce for oral interrogation any person requested by the chief of police and considered as being important in the ascertainment of the facts relative to such license. The failure to produce such person within 30 days after being requested to do so may result in a denial of the application by the clerk. (f) A period of 45 days shall be allowed for processing any application for a license required under this chapter. For investigative purposes, the chief of police may extend the 45-day processing period according to the licensee's compliance, should the chief of police deem it necessary. (Code 1982, § 3-56) Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 82. Sec. 10-8. - Publishing of advertisements; signs. (a) At least once a week for two weeks immediately preceding city council approval of any license application under this chapter, the applicant shall cause advertisements to be placed in the newspaper for sheriff's advertisements in the county. The advertisements shall be in a form prescribed by the clerk and shall include the name and address of the applicant, the type of license applied for, the business location applied for and the time, date and location of the city council meeting on the application. (b) The applicant shall also cause to be placed upon the location of the proposed premises to be licensed, signs of a size, number and form prescribed by the clerk, stating the type of license applied for and the time, date and location of the city council meeting on the application. (Code 1982, § 3-57) Cross reference— Advertising, ch. 6. Sec. 10-9. - Completion of premises proposed to be licensed. Where a building in which any person intends to operate under the provisions of this chapter is, at the time of the application for the license, not in existence or not yet complete, a license may be issued for the location, provided the plans for the proposed building clearly show a compliance with the other provisions of this chapter. No sales shall be allowed in the establishment until it has been completed in accordance with the plans and is in conformity with all of the other provisions of this chapter and this Code. (Code 1982, § 3-58) Sec. 10-10. - Issuance of license to persons with prior convictions. (a) No license under this chapter shall be issued, renewed or transferred to any person where any individual having an interest either as owner, partner or stockholder, directly or indirectly, beneficial or absolute, shall have been convicted of any felony within five years immediately prior to the filing of the application, or convicted of any misdemeanor relating to any alcoholic beverage business or any municipal ordinance violation relating to any alcoholic beverage business within two years immediately prior to the filing of the application. (b) For the purposes of this section, the term "conviction" includes an adjudication of guilt, a plea of guilty or nolo contendere or the forfeiture of a bond, in part or in whole, when charged with a crime, or the suspension or revocation of any alcoholic beverage license owned, in whole or in part, by persons listed in subsection (a) of this section. (Code 1982, § 3-59) Sec. 10-11. - Issuance or denial of license; resubmission of application. (a) The clerk shall deny a city license under this chapter on any of the following grounds: (1) Failure to meet state requirements for a state license; (2) Failure to pay required fees and taxes; (3) Failure to provide valid information, documents, etc., required by this chapter; (4) False information in the application or attached documents; (5) Improper residency of registered agents; (6) Failure to pass review by the chief of police; (7) Failure to post and maintain proper signs and advertisements required in this chapter; (8) Failure to meet distance or location requirements; (9) Prior convictions, as provided in section 10-10; or (10) Failure to meet any other requirements in this chapter for a license of the class applied for. (b) An application which has been denied shall not be resubmitted for a period of 12 months after the denial, unless there is a substantial change therein which would affect the reason for the original denial. (c) The city clerk may otherwise issue any city license provided for in this chapter after approval by the city council. (Code 1982, § 3-60) Sec. 10-12. - State regulations. All licenses issued under this chapter shall be subject to the rules and regulations adopted by the state, as amended, and prescribed by the state department of revenue, and violation of such statutes and regulations shall be violations of this Code. In addition, all businesses, the applicant for the license, the agent in charge of the business and the owners thereof shall observe and obey the regulations provided in this article and any other applicable provisions of this chapter. (Code 1982, § 3-61) Sec. 10-13. - Books and records; open to inspection. All persons holding wholesale or retail alcoholic beverage licenses from the city shall maintain accurate and complete records of all alcoholic beverages sold or delivered within the city and the collection and remittance of all taxes due thereon. Any establishment holding a license issued under this chapter, and the books and records pertaining thereto, shall, at all times during the period allowable by law for operation of the business, be open to inspection and audit by any officer of the police department, any license inspector of the city or any person designated by the chief of police or the city marshal. In addition, if the premises is being used after hours by employees, the owners or their agents, the premises may be inspected at such time by the persons designated in this section. (Code 1982, §§ 3-44, 3-62) Sec. 10-14. - Open containers prohibited; exception. No bottle or other container of alcoholic beverage shall be opened or consumed by any person on the premises, or in any adjacent parking area, upon which the place of business is conducted and licensed under this chapter, whether the bottle or other container so opened or consumed was bought or obtained at that place of business or elsewhere, unless the premises is licensed under this chapter for consumption on the premises. (Code 1982, § 3-63) Sec. 10-15. - Transfer of license. (a) Scope. Licenses under this chapter shall not be transferrable, except as otherwise provided in this section. (b) Death of licensee. In case of the death of any person holding such a license, or any interest therein, the license may be transferred to the administrator, executor or the lawful heirs of the deceased person, in the discretion of the city council. (c) Withdrawal of partner. Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one or more of the partners in a partnership holding a license from withdrawing from the partnership in favor of one or more of the partners who were partners at the time of the issuance of such license. Such a withdrawal shall not, however, serve to bring any new ownership into the partnership. (d) Transfer of location. Should a transfer of a location be approved, there shall be no pro rata return or refund of any license fee, and the new location shall require a new license under this chapter. (e) Addition of partners and stockholders. A licensee may take in partners or additional stockholders where it is determined by the city council that the additional capital furnished is to be used exclusively for additional inventory or expanding the facilities of the business, or for building new facilities and where it appears that neither the licensee himself, nor any partner or stockholder therein, receives, directly or indirectly, any of the additional capital invested. Under this subsection, an additional partner or new principal stockholder must be approved by the city council. (f) Transfer from agent to agent; name change. Where licenses are held by agents, upon the resignation or removal of an agent holding the alcoholic beverage license for a particular location, the partners, owners or stockholders of the business entity shall immediately appoint a new agent to hold the alcoholic beverage license, which agent shall apply to the chief of police of the city for the reissuance of the alcoholic beverage license in his name for the stated location. Upon a completion of the police background check and investigation as required in this article, the chief of police shall make a recommendation to the city council for the approval or disapproval of the transfer of agent. In such a transfer, it will be required that a new investigation fee be paid for the investigation of the new agent, but no new fees for the issuance of the alcoholic beverage license will be collected until the normal expiration date of the existing license. In such instances in which only the name of the establishment holding an alcoholic beverage license is to change, with no change in the ownership or agent holding the license, the partners, owners or stockholders shall notify the chief of police of the change of name, which notation shall be made on the records of the city and forwarded to the license inspector's office for a change on the records of such office. No charge will be made for the name change. (Code 1982, § 3-64) Sec. 10-16. - Furnishing to, purchase of or possession by persons under 21 years of age of alcoholic beverages.
