(a) Except as otherwise authorized by law: (1) No person knowingly, directly or through another person, shall furnish, cause to be furnished or permit any person in such person's employ to furnish any alcoholic beverage to any person under 21 years of age; (2) No person under 21 years of age shall purchase, attempt to purchase or knowingly possess any alcoholic beverage; (3) No person under 21 years of age shall misrepresent such person's age in any manner whatsoever for the purpose of illegally obtaining any alcoholic beverage; (4) No person, knowingly or intentionally, shall act as an agent to purchase or acquire any alcoholic beverage for, or on behalf of, a person under 21 years of age; and (5) No person under 21 years of age shall misrepresent his identity or use any false identification for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining any alcoholic beverage. (b) The provisions contained in O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23(b), (c), (d) and (e) are hereby adopted with like effect as if recited in this subsection, and any future amendment or repeal of such provisions shall amend or repeal the pertinent provisions of this section. (Code 1982, § 3-67) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23. Sec. 10-17. - Duration and renewal of license. Except as otherwise provided, duration and renewal of licenses under this chapter shall be from January 1 through December 31 of each year; and no licensee shall have any vested right to the renewal of any city license. No license under this chapter may be renewed if the license could be denied under this chapter. (Code 1982, § 3-69(a)) Sec. 10-18. - Location of retail businesses. No retail business licensed pursuant to this chapter shall be located within the boundaries of the R-1 Residential, R-2 Residential, I-N Institutional and I Industrial zoning districts. (Code 1982, § 3-70; Res. No. 14-0515-23, 5-15-2014) Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; zoning, app. B. Sec. 10-19. - Collection of taxes from distributors, wholesale dealers and manufacturers. At the time of delivery of any alcoholic beverages as set forth in this chapter, such wholesale dealer, distributor or manufacturer shall collect from the retail dealer the taxes imposed by this chapter, giving a correct and proper receipt therefor, and hold such taxes in trust for the city until the tax is remitted to the city as provided in this chapter. It shall be unlawful for any wholesaler, distributor, manufacturer or person to sell or deliver any alcoholic beverages as set forth in this chapter to any retail dealer in the city, or for any such alcoholic beverages to be transported into the city for resale by any means whatsoever, except to a licensed wholesale distributor, without collecting the taxes thereon, as set forth in this section, at the time of such sale or delivery. (Code 1982, § 3-71(a)) Sec. 10-20. - Duties of retail dealers generally. All retail dealers in any alcoholic beverages as set forth in this chapter, and all persons selling any such alcoholic beverages at retail within the city, shall keep a correct record of all purchases of each of such alcoholic beverages, and shall demand of and require all persons from whom they purchase such alcoholic beverages to furnish and deliver to them with such alcoholic beverages a correct invoice of each purchase. Such invoice shall be kept and preserved by such retailer at his place of business for a period of one year from the date of such purchase, and such invoice shall be open and subject to inspection by any authorized representative of the city, at all reasonable times. Such retailer shall, on or before the close of business on Monday of each week, make a report to the city clerk showing the number of containers of each and all such alcoholic beverages purchased during the previous week, and up to the close of business on Saturday of the week, showing the size and contents of each container, the name and address of all dealers and persons from whom purchases were made, and the dates of delivery of such containers. Such report shall be accompanied by a remittance of all taxes due under this chapter for all purchases made, except purchases on which taxes have been paid to the manufacturers, distributors or wholesalers at the time of delivery as provided in this chapter and, for all such taxes paid to such manufacturers, distributors or wholesalers at the time of delivery as provided in this chapter, such retailers shall furnish the city with the proper original receipts. (Code 1982, § 3-72) Sec. 10-21. - Refusal to make reports or remittances. If any wholesaler or distributor fails or refuses to timely make the reports or remittances as provided in this chapter, the clerk shall notify such party, in writing, by mail or otherwise and, if such reports are not made and the taxes paid within five days from the date of such notice, the clerk shall proceed to assess the amount of taxes due by such wholesaler or distributor from the best information available, plus ten percent thereof as a penalty, and cause an execution for the assessment to be issued at once, and proceed to collect such taxes, penalty and costs as provided by ordinance for the collection of any other delinquent taxes, and in addition thereto, prosecute such wholesaler or distributor in the municipal court for such offense. (Code 1982, § 3-73) Sec. 10-22. - Processing and investigation fee. In addition to the license application requirements of this chapter, a processing and investigation fee in the amount as set by the mayor and city council, in addition to other fees and taxes required in this chapter, shall be deposited with the application to cover the expense of advertising, investigating and processing of the application and the fee shall be nonrefundable. (Code 1982, § 3-74) Sec. 10-23. - Policies for suspension and revocation of licenses generally. The following policies relating to suspension or revocation of all licenses for the sale of alcoholic beverages and naturally fermented wines in the city shall be impartially enforced: (1) Whenever there is clear and convincing evidence, to the satisfaction of the chief of police, of any violation of state law or municipal ordinance by any license holder or employee thereof within the city, at any time after service of warrant, the chief of police shall send written notice of any violation to the license holder and the license committee chairperson, who shall call a meeting of the license committee within ten days from the date of such notification for consideration of any alleged violation. The license holder shall be notified, in writing, of the time and place of such meeting and may appear and be heard. (2) All of the following provisions shall apply to the 12-month period from April 1 until license renewal the following year: a. First violation. For a first violation, there shall be an immediate 15-day suspension of privilege and reinstatement fee thereafter in the amount as set by the mayor and city council. b. Second violation. For a second violation, there shall be a suspension of privilege for a 30-day period and a reinstatement fee thereafter in the amount as set by the mayor and city council. c. Third violation. For a third violation, there shall be a suspension of privilege for a period of 60 days and a reinstatement fee thereafter in the amount as set by the mayor and city council. d. Fourth violation. For a fourth violation, the licensee shall be notified to show cause before the mayor and city council why the license should not be revoked or, in the alternative, why there should not be a suspension of privilege for a 90-day period and a reinstatement fee thereafter in the amount as set by the mayor and city council. (3) All decisions suspending or revoking any license shall be in writing, with the reasons stated for such suspension or revocation, and shall be mailed or delivered to the licensee. (4) Upon timely application within ten days after mailing or delivery of the decision of the license committee, any licensee shall be afforded a hearing before the mayor and city council, with an opportunity to present evidence and cross examine opposing witnesses. (Code 1982, § 3-1) Sec. 10-24. - Copies of state licenses required. (a) All applicants for licenses for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall file with the city clerk a copy of any state license for such sales issued to such applicant within 30 days after issuance thereof by state authorities. (b) All applicants for the renewal of any license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall file with the renewal application a copy of any state license for such sales currently held by the applicant. (Code 1982, § 3-2) Sec. 10-25. - Establishments providing on-premises consumption; underage persons prohibited, exceptions. (a) Any person holding an over-the-counter beer license or wine pouring license who does business in an establishment wherein the consumption of alcoholic beverages is allowed or permitted within such establishment or on any adjoining premises is prohibited, during regular business hours, from admitting to such establishment or to the adjoining premises persons under the minimum legal drinking age as established in O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23. (b) The provisions of this section shall not be construed to prohibit persons under the legal drinking age from entering a restaurant, which is defined as any public place maintained and held out to the public as a place where meals are actually and regularly served, such place being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and seating capacity for at least 50 people, and having sufficient employees to prepare and serve suitable food to its guests. Such restaurant shall serve at least one meal a day for at least six days a week, with the exception of holidays, vacations and periods of redecorating. (c) The purpose of this section is to prohibit the presence of persons under the legal drinking age in establishments which derive a major portion of their revenues from the sale of alcoholic beverages, but this section shall not apply to any employee of the licensee. (Code 1982, § 3-3) Sec. 10-26. - Video recording systems. (a) Any licensee who sells any alcoholic beverage packaged to go is hereby required to install a continuous video recording system, dedicated to each register area, with cameras and lenses of a type, number and location approved by the chief of the police department. Such cameras must be capable of producing a retrievable and identifiable image on film or tape that can be made a permanent record and can be enlarged through projection or other means. (b) The retrievable image from the security camera must be preserved for a period of at least 21 days from the date the image is retrieved and shall be made available for inspection by the police department, upon request. (Amd. of 2-18-1999; Res. No. 17-0721-55, 7-20-2017) Sec. 10-27. - Sunday sales. (a) Establishments holding a license for the sale of malt beverages, wine or distilled spirits are permitted to sell and serve only between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. on Sundays. (b) Any person, wholesaler or retailer who shall violate the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as prescribed by law. (Res. No. 13-1121-60, § 10-80, 11-21-2013) Secs. 10-28—10-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - MALT BEVERAGES
Sec. 10-61. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Container means the can, bottle or barrel in which any malt beverage is placed and shall not be deemed to mean the case or carton in which such cans, bottles or barrels are packed. (Code 1982, § 3-20) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. State Law reference— Definitions, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-1-2, 3-5-1. Sec. 10-62. - License application; fingerprinting of applicant; processing. A printed application, to be supplied by the city clerk, shall be completed and filed by any applicant for a malt beverage license within the city. When completed, the application shall be returned to the city clerk's office at city hall, at which time the applicant shall be fingerprinted by the police department. The applicant's fingerprints shall be submitted to the appropriate law enforcement agencies in accordance with state law. The application will then be processed by the police department, fire department, building inspector and county board of health, and returned to the city clerk, who, in turn, will forward the application to the chairperson of the license committee, who will bring the application before the mayor and city council for approval or disapproval. (Code 1982, § 3-21) State Law reference— Authority to license malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2. Sec. 10-63. - Rules and regulations. All rules and regulations governing and controlling the sale of malt beverages shall be posted, for information and notice to the public, beside the licensee's license. Such rules and regulations shall be published and distributed to the various malt beverage licensees, and a written receipt, signed by the licensee, acknowledging receipt of such rules and regulations shall be obtained from each such licensee. (Code 1982, § 3-22) Sec. 10-64. - Excise tax levied and imposed; reports; payment. (a) Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, there is hereby levied and imposed upon each wholesale dealer selling malt beverages within the city an excise tax in the amount as set by the mayor and city council per 12-ounce container, or fraction thereof, of malt beverages sold by such wholesale dealer within the city. (b) All malt beverages sold in, or from, a barrel or bulk container, and being commonly known as tap or draft beer, shall not be subject to the excise tax provided for in subsection (a) of this section, but, in lieu thereof, there is hereby imposed upon each wholesale dealer selling such malt beverages within the city an excise tax in the amount as set by the mayor and city council for each barrel or bulk container having a capacity of 15½ gallons sold by such wholesale dealer within the city and at a similar rate for fractional parts thereof. (c) Each wholesale dealer who sells malt beverages within the city shall file a report by the tenth day of each month, itemizing for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities of all malt beverages, by size and type of container, for the month sold or disposed of within the city. Each such wholesale dealer shall remit to the city, on the tenth day of the month next succeeding the calendar month in which such sales were made, the amount of excise tax due in accordance with this section. (d) No decal, stamp or other identifying mark shall be required on malt beverages sold within the city. (Code 1982, § 3-23) Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 82. State Law reference— Municipal malt beverage excise tax, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80 et seq. Sec. 10-65. - Excise tax in addition to other taxes. The excise taxes provided for in section 10-64 shall be in addition to any license fee, tax or charge which may be imposed upon the business of selling malt beverages at retail or wholesale within the city. (Code 1982, § 3-24) Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 82. Sec. 10-66. - Records required. (a) Each wholesaler selling, shipping or delivering malt beverages in the city shall keep accurate invoices of all sales of malt beverages and shall make the invoices available for inspection by the city. Such records shall be maintained for a period of at least one year. (b) All retail dealers who sell malt beverages at retail within the city shall maintain a record of their purchases from all wholesalers and from any other person from whom they may purchase malt beverages, showing the quantities purchased and the dates thereof, and shall maintain such records for a period of at least one year. (Code 1982, § 3-25) Sec. 10-67. - Failure to make timely reports and remittances; filing false or fraudulent reports; penalties. The failure to make a timely report and remittance shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to two percent of the total amount due during the first 30-day period following the date such report and remittance were due and a further penalty of two percent of the amount of such remittance for each successive 30-day period, or any portion thereof, during which such report and remittance are not filed. The filing of a false or fraudulent report shall render the wholesale dealer making such report liable for a penalty equal to two percent of the amount of the remittance which would be required under an accurate and truthful report. Such failure to make a timely report or remittance, or the filing of a false or fraudulent report, shall also constitute grounds for the revocation of the business license issued by the city to such wholesale dealer. (Code 1982, § 3-26) Sec. 10-68. - Hours of sales. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, or permit to be sold, any malt beverages, other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m., Monday through Friday, inclusive, and 7:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight on Saturday. (Code 1982, § 3-27) Sec. 10-69. - Reserved. Sec. 10-70. - Holders of over-the-counter beer and wine pouring licenses to observe closing regulations; exception. No establishment wherein the holder of any over-the-counter beer license or wine pouring license conducts business as a licensee shall be or remain open or in operation for any purpose on Sunday, or on any day on which the sale of alcoholic beverages is prohibited by state law or municipal ordinance. (Code 1982, § 3-28.1; Res. No. 08-1120-38, 11-20-2008) Sec. 10-71. - Sale near churches and schools. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell any wine or malt beverage at a place within 300 feet of any church or school within the city. Any person who shall violate this section shall, if licensed, be liable to the suspension or revocation of said license. This section shall not apply not any location for which a license has been issued prior to July 1, 1981, nor to the renewal of such license; nor shall this section apply at any location for which a new license is applied for, if the sale of the wine and beer was lawful at such location at any time during the 12 months immediately preceding such application. For the purposes of this section, the term "school" does not include college or university. (b) Distance shall be measured in linear feet by the most direct route of travel on the ground and shall be measured in the following manner: (1) From the front door of the structure from which malt beverages are sold or offered for sale; (2) In a straight line to the nearest public sidewalk, walkway, street, road or highway; (3) Along such public sidewalk, walkway, street, road or highway by the nearest route; (4) To the front door of the church building, or to the nearest portion of the schoolgrounds, whichever is applicable. (Code 1982, § 3-29; Res. No. 10-0415-19, 4-15-2010; Res. No. 10-0415-20, 4-15-2010) Cross reference— Distance of distilled spirits from churches and schools, § 10-138; zoning, app. B. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21. Secs. 10-72—10-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - WINE
Sec. 10-101. - Applicability of chapter provisions. All restrictions against sales and all requirements for granting of wholesale or retail licenses pertaining to the sale of malt beverages within the city shall be applicable to wine sales and licenses made or granted under this article. (Code 1982, § 3-40) State Law reference— Municipal wine license, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-40. Sec. 10-102. - Tax imposed and levied. There is imposed and levied upon every dealer at retail of naturally fermented wines a tax in the amount as set by the mayor and city council per wine gallon and a pro rata tax upon fractional gallons on all such wines sold or distributed in the city. (Code 1982, § 3-41) Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 82. State Law reference— Municipal excise tax on wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-60. Sec. 10-103. - Payment of tax. The tax levied in section 10-102 shall be paid by retailers to wholesalers at the time of delivery of such wines to the retailer. It shall be the duty of each such retailer to pay, and it shall be the duty of each wholesaler of each case delivered by such wholesaler to such retailer to receive, the proper amount of the tax levied in section 10-102. It shall further be the duty of such wholesaler to furnish the city clerk with duplicate invoices of all sales of wine to local retail dealers with the monthly case tax remittance report and to remit such taxes to the clerk by the tenth day of the succeeding calendar month, less a five percent discount. (Code 1982, § 3-42) Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 82. Sec. 10-104. - Failure to pay or remit taxes. It shall be unlawful for any retailer to possess, display or sell any wine delivered in any case on which such taxes have not been paid, and for any wholesaler to fail to remit to the city clerk all such taxes collected as prescribed by this article. (Code 1982, § 3-43) Cross reference— Taxation, ch. 82. Secs. 10-105—10-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - DISTILLED SPIRITS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Municipal authority to regulate distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. §§ 3-4-51, 3-4-93, 3-4-160.
Sec. 10-131. - License required. (a) No distilled spirits shall be stored, delivered, sold or manufactured in the city, except under a license issued pursuant to this article. (b) Licenses may be issued under this article for the manufacturing, wholesaling and retailing of distilled spirits. (Code 1982, § 3-51(a), (c)) Sec. 10-132. - License fee for liquor dispensed and sold by the drink. (a) The governing authority of the city hereby sets the fee for the privilege to sell distilled spirits at $5,000.00 which shall not be subject to proration. (b) A license holder shall, at all times, maintain a policy of general liability insurance of at least $500,000.00, proof of which must accompany the license application and shall be subject to verification at all times during which the license holder's license is valid. (Res. No. 12-0315-17, 3-15-2012; Res. No. 12-0419-23, 4-19-2012) Sec. 10-133. - Billiard tables, pinball machines, music boxes, etc. No retail licensee for any distilled spirits within the city shall permit or maintain on the premises any billiard tables, pinball machines, music boxes or jukeboxes, or any other video or electronic amusement games of any type. (Code 1982, § 3-68) Sec. 10-134. - Renewal of license. In any given year, applicants for renewal of their licenses under this article for the sale of distilled spirits for the next year shall file their application with the city administrator on or before December 10. Upon payment of such fees and license taxes to the city administrator as are applicable, on or before December 31 and no later than January 1, the city administrator shall issue the new license to the applicant. (Code 1982, § 3-69(b)) Sec. 10-135. - Monthly reports. Each wholesaler or distributor who has sold distilled spirits within the city shall file a report by the tenth day of each month, itemizing, for the preceding calendar month, the exact quantities of all distilled spirits, by size and type of container, for the month, sold within the city. Each such wholesaler or distributor shall remit to the city, on the tenth day of the month next succeeding the calendar month in which such sales were made, the amount of excise taxies due, in accordance with the provisions of section 10-140. (Code 1982, § 3-71(b)) Sec. 10-136. - Limitation on number of licenses within a family or corporation. (a) No application for a license to sell distilled spirits at retail shall be granted where the person applying for the license or members of such person's family or any corporation in which the person owns an interest already holds any interest in two or more licenses to sell distilled spirits by the package at retail within the state. For the purposes of this section, the term "family" means any person related to the applicant within the first degree of consanguinity and affinity under civil law. (b) As used in this section, an interest in a license shall be deemed to exist if the person involved is the outright owner of the license; a co-owner of the license; a partner in a partnership which owns all, or any part, of a license; or a stockholder in any corporation organized for pecuniary gain which owns all, or any part, of a license. Notwithstanding any of the other provisions of this section, no one person shall be deemed to have more than one interest in any one license. (c) All applications for a license under this article, both original and renewal, must be accompanied by a full and complete statement, under oath, of information relative to any and all interest, as defined in subsection (b) of this section, in retail liquor stores. This shall include the names and addresses of all persons interested in the ownership of the business of selling at retail package liquor, together with any interest each person or any member of his family has in any other retail liquor store and any other similar information called for by the chief of police. (Code 1982, § 3-75) Sec. 10-136.1. - Number and location of licensed premises limited. (a) Notwithstanding any other provision herein, the total number of licenses issued for sale of distilled spirits shall not exceed one for every 3,500 residents as determined by the most recent decennial census or such other population number determined and provided by any authorized agency of this state. (b) In order to receive or maintain a license to sell distilled spirits, any such establishment must be located and front on either Highway 49, Highway 96 or Highway 341 (or such other name assigned to said highways as they pass within the city). (Res. No. 05-1020-62, 10-20-2005) Sec. 10-137. - Restrictions on other merchandise. A licensee of a retail establishment under this article shall not operate the business in connection with any other mercantile establishment, provided this shall not prohibit a licensee from operating in the same building complex with other businesses. No retailer under this article shall sell, offer for sale, display or keep any other commodity in stock at his place of business where packaged distilled spirits are offered for sale, except for the following, all of which may be sold by the retailer at his option: (1) Beverages containing no alcohol and commonly used to dilute distilled spirits; (2) Wines and malt beverages, when properly licensed; (3) Glasses, stirring sticks and similar paraphernalia commonly used in the consumption of alcoholic beverages; (4) Tobacco products; and (5) Packaged ice. (Code 1982, § 3-76) Sec. 10-138. - Distance from churches and schools. No person shall be licensed by the city under this article when the proposed place of business is within 300 feet of any church, or within 600 feet of any school building, schoolground or college campus. (Code 1982, § 3-77) Cross reference— Sale of alcoholic beverages near churches and schools, § 10-71. Sec. 10-139. - Wholesale and manufacturing licenses. Wholesale and manufacturing licenses shall be issued only to such applicants who are licensed by the state to distribute distilled spirits. Application for wholesale distribution and manufacturing licenses shall be made as set forth in this chapter, and applicants are subject to such qualifications and restrictions as set forth in this chapter. All applications shall be accompanied by the appropriate license fee and investigation fee as provided by this chapter. (Code 1982, § 3-78) Sec. 10-140. - Schedule of license fees and excise taxes. In addition to any other business license fees that may be applicable under this Code, the annual license fees and excise taxes shall be paid for the type of license being acquired as set by the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 3-79) Secs. 10-141—10-160. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - ON-PREMISES CONSUMPTION OF BEER, WINE AND DISTILLED SPIRITS
Sec. 10-161. - Applicability. All restrictions against sales and all requirements for granting licenses contained in this chapter shall apply for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink for on-premises consumption. (Res. No. 12-0216-06, § 10-140, 2-16-2012) Sec. 10-162. - Locations where allowed; exception. (a) For the purposes of this article, the term "premises" shall mean the enclosed, under roof area of a single building and shall include such outdoor patios and open areas directly adjacent to and contiguous with the licensed structure. (b) The provision of this section shall not apply to special event permit licenses. (Res. No. 12-0216-06, § 10-140, 2-16-2012)

div.head: Chapter 11 - SPECIAL EVENTS
div.p: Sec. 11-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Alcoholic beverages means all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverages, wines or fortified wines. Controlled zone means a geographic area with controlled access, with wristband identification of persons authorized to purchase and hold in possession alcoholic beverages, loudspeaker limits and controls, enhanced security measures, and entertainment controls. Special event means a program of cultural and/or entertainment events open to the general public and taking place either fully or in part on public streets, thoroughfares, parks, squares, public property (with approval of the city, or private property in commercial zoning classifications (with approval of the owner). To be regulated by this article, each such special event must be designated as a special event by the police chief or his designee. Special event area means the area that meets the requirements of a special event and controlled zone. (Res. No. 11-0721-18, att. § (11-1), 7-21-2011) Sec. 11-2. - Temporary permit for special events. Organizers of special events to be conducted within the city must first file an application with the police chief, or the chief's designee, for a permit authorizing the event. If alcoholic beverages are to be served, the application shall so state and shall designate a person or business that holds a valid license issued by the city to sell alcoholic beverages as the event's alcohol vendor. An application fee shall be paid with the application, and a permit fee shall be paid before issuance of the permit. The application fee and permit fee shall be established by written policy of the mayor and council. After investigation by the police chief or his designee, the police chief or his designee may issue a special event permit under the following conditions: (1) The applicant must contract with an individual or entity that holds a current, valid license issued by the state allowing the sale of alcoholic beverages who will then hold the special alcohol permit and be responsible for the sale of alcoholic beverages at the special event. (2) The special event alcohol permit may be issued to the licensee and will allow sale of alcoholic beverages beyond the premises described in the licensee's annual license only in the controlled zone specifically described in the application as approved in the permit, and only during the special event approved. (3) Food must be served within the controlled zone during any period of time that alcoholic beverages are served. (4) The application for such special event and special alcohol permit must have been filed with the police chief or his designee, at least 30 days prior to the date of the special event. (5) All applicants and permit holders must comply with all state statutes governing the sale of alcoholic beverages and all provisions listed in the application approved by the city. (6) To qualify as a special event, the proposed event must be open to the general public, subject to reasonable attendance restrictions. As part of the application process, the applicant must provide a copy of the event's marketing plan including copies of marketing materials. The application shall include an estimate of public attendance for each day of the event. The application shall also include a security plan for the event in a form required by the chief of police. The security plan must provide for contingencies, such as attendance in excess of projected attendance, and unexpected public safety issues during the event. The chief of police may place conditions and requirements upon the event as part of an approved security plan. The chief may restrict the number of event attendees allowed within the controlled zone, and may limit attendance during the special event based upon conditions within the controlled zone and the effectiveness of the security plan. The chief may require that the applicant hire off-duty city police officers to be on-site within the controlled zone during the special event. (7) A special event permit and special alcohol permit may be immediately revoked by the police chief (or his designee) for a violation of state or city laws, inadequate security, or unruly attendees or any event that results in an emergency situation in which continued operation of the premises by the licensee may, in the opinion of the police chief, (or his designee), endanger the health, welfare or safety of the public, the attendees, or city or private property. (Res. No. 11-0721-18, § 1, att. § (11-2), 7-21-2011) Sec. 11-3. - Designation of a community special event. The mayor and council will consider approval of an application upon recommendation of the police chief, or his designee, after the police chief has conducted an examination and investigation of the application. The police chief, or his designee, shall review and approve all fencing, wristband identification procedures, loudspeaker limits, entertainment controls, security measures and any other applicable standards for the special event. (Res. No. 11-0721-18, att. § (11-3), 7-21-2011) Sec. 11-4. - Designation and management of controlled zone. The police chief or his designee may implement regulations and controls which will be specific for each designated controlled zone. Such regulations and controls may include, but are not limited to, the following: (1) Fencing and gating. Fencing designated controlled zones and establishing entrance gates for controlling and limiting access to each controlled zone. (2) Identification, entrance criteria. Permit holders shall provide wristbands or other means of identifying persons who have met entrance criteria. Entrance criteria may include, but are not limited to, prohibiting persons from entering with weapons, alcoholic beverages, pets, skates, bicycles, and other items which may be dangerous, disruptive, or inconvenient in crowded conditions, and prohibiting entry by persons appearing to be intoxicated. (3) Identification, consumption of alcoholic beverages. Permit holders shall require wristbands or other means of identifying persons who have displayed proof of attaining the age of 21 years, and who are authorized to purchase or hold in possession alcoholic beverages within the controlled zone. Displaying such a wristband does not relieve alcoholic beverage vendors of responsibility for determining if a person has attained the age of 21 years before dispensing alcohol to that person. (4) Designation of special event manager within controlled zone. The police chief, or his/her designee, may designate and authorize a nonprofit tax-exempt organization or similar entity to organize and manage special event activities within a controlled zone. Such designation may include authorization to collect and expend funds, in which case subsection (5) of this section will apply. (5) Insurance. Any organization authorized to organize and manage special event activities within a controlled zone shall take out and keep in force for all activities associated with such event a special events liability policy. Such policy shall provide the following: a. Minimum coverage limits: $1,000,000.00 single-limit. b. Named as additional insured: the mayor and council of the city, a Georgia municipal corporation, its elected officials, officers, employees and agent. c. Certificate of insurance: A certificate of insurance shall be issued to the additional insured least five days prior to the beginning of the event. Such certificate shall be on a standard form and will provide for notification of the additional insured within ten days of termination of coverage. (6) Security plan. Security plan as described at section 11-2(6). (Res. No. 11-0721-18, att. § (11-4), 7-21-2011) Sec. 11-5. - Transport of alcoholic beverages. The transport of alcoholic beverages for personal consumption either into or out of any designated controlled zone is prohibited. Only the holder of the special alcohol permit may transport alcoholic beverages in and out of the controlled zone. (Res. No. 11-0721-18, att. § (11-5), 7-21-2011)

div.head: Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Authority of city to regulate animals, § 41. Cross reference— Environment, ch. 38; health and sanitation, ch. 46. State Constitution reference— Animal control by municipalities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III. State Law reference— Livestock running at large or straying, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; permitting dogs in heat to roam or run free, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.; notification of bites by animals, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-4; nuisances in municipalities, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-7.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Owner, when used in reference to an animal, includes any person having such animal in his charge, possession or control, or who allows the animal to be kept on his premises. (Code 1982, § 4-1) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 14-2. - Bird sanctuary. The city, as constituted, together with all property belonging to the city or under its jurisdiction, is hereby established as a bird sanctuary. (Code 1982, § 4-2) Sec. 14-3. - Injuring, molesting or killing birds, wild fowl and squirrels. It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to trap, hunt, kill, shoot or attempt to shoot, wound, injure, abuse or molest any bird, wild fowl or squirrel, or to rob bird nests; provided, however, if squirrels, starlings, English sparrows or any other kinds of birds or wild fowl are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality that they constitute a nuisance or menace to the health or property of the citizens of the city, in the opinion of the public health authorities or city authorities, it shall be so declared by such authorities, and such squirrels or birds may then be destroyed in such numbers and in such manner as is deemed advisable by such authorities. (Code 1982, § 4-3) Sec. 14-4. - Cruelty to animals. It shall be unlawful for any person to overload, cruelly treat, maim, bruise, abuse, mistreat, torture, deprive of necessary sustenance, ill use or otherwise wrongfully deal with any domestic animal or fowl or otherwise treat such domestic creatures in a harsh, inhumane or unreasonable manner. Shelter for horses, cattle or other domestic animals shall be provided to protect such creatures against inclement weather and extreme temperatures. (Code 1982, § 4-4) State Law reference— Cruelty to dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-5; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4. Sec. 14-5. - Poisoning animals. It shall be unlawful for any person to put out, or cause to be put out, any poison within the city for the killing of any dog or other domestic animal. (Code 1982, § 4-5) Sec. 14-6. - Rabies inoculation and tag required. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain, or permit the keeping or maintaining, on such person's premises or elsewhere within the city any dog or cat which has not been inoculated against rabies and tagged with a current inoculation tag. (Code 1982, § 4-6) State Law reference— Authority of city to control rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-3. Sec. 14-7. - Livestock running at large. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any horse, mule, cow, hog, goat, sheep or other animal used or fit for either food or labor to allow such animal to run at large upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys or public grounds within the city. (Code 1982, § 4-7) State Law reference— Livestock running at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; impoundment of livestock, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-4; liability for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-7. Sec. 14-8. - Dogs running at large. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog to allow the dog to run upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys or other public grounds in the city. Any dog off the premises of the owner and not confined in a cage or in a vehicle shall be accompanied by its owner or other person, in which event, such dog must be leashed with a leash of sufficient strength to hold the dog. (Code 1982, § 4-8) State Law reference— Liability for damage done to livestock or poultry by dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-4. Sec. 14-9. - Impounding livestock. Any animal mentioned in section 14-7 found at large within the city shall be taken up and impounded by the city. Each animal so impounded shall be sold by the chief of police at public outcry, after an advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, giving the time and place of such sale. The proceeds of such sale, after paying all costs and expenses thereof, and of taking up and keeping such animal, shall be deposited in the city treasury for 90 days to await the claim of the owner, at the expiration of which time, if there is no claimant thereof, such proceeds shall be used for the general purposes of the city. The owner of such animal may, at any time before the sale, reclaim the animal by paying all costs and expenses of such impounding and keeping. The fees for taking up and impounding and keeping the animal shall be as set by the mayor and city council. State Law reference— Impounding animals, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq. Sec. 14-10. - Impounding dogs. (a) Any dog found running at large shall be taken up and impounded by the city and kept for a period of 72 hours unless claimed by its owner, in which event, such owner shall pay to the city clerk an impounding fee as set by the mayor and city council. Should such dog not be claimed within 72 hours after the publication of a notice, then it may be put to death. Any dog found running at large bearing no current rabies inoculation tag may be immediately destroyed. (b) Any dog found within the city which has not been inoculated and tagged, or the tag of which has been altered, disfigured or rendered illegible, shall, if not destroyed as provided in subsection (a) of this section, be taken up and impounded. If the owner of such dog shall fail, neglect or refuse to claim such dog and have it properly tagged, in case its tag has been lost, altered or disfigured, or inoculated, in case it has not been inoculated in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, and also pay the impounding fee as set forth in this section, the chief of police, or such officer as the chief might designate, shall, on the fourth day after the publication of such notice, either kill the dog or have it inoculated and tagged and sell the dog for a sum sufficient, if possible, to pay the impounding and inoculation fees. The impounding fee shall be as set by the mayor and city council to cover the cost of taking up and impounding the dog, plus the cost of the publication of the notice, together with the sum as set by the mayor and city council for each day the dog is impounded, to cover the cost of feeding the dog. (Code 1982, § 4-10) Sec. 14-11. - Fees additional. In addition to the payment of the fees pursuant to this chapter, the owner of any impounded animal shall be subject to prosecution for a violation of the provisions of this chapter. (Code 1982, § 4-11) Sec. 14-12. - Pens, coops and enclosures within 300 feet of buildings. It shall be unlawful for any person to build or maintain any pen, coop or enclosure for animals or fowl, or to permit any animal or fowl to be kept, maintained or grazed within 300 feet of any building where people reside or work. This section shall not apply to any building on the same premises where such animal or fowl is kept or maintained, nor shall it apply to dogs or cats kept as household pets, but it shall apply to dog kennels where more than one dog is kept. (Code 1982, § 4-12) Sec. 14-13. - Nuisances. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any animal or fowl in the city in such a manner as to create an unsanitary or obnoxious condition, or to become noisy, offensive or a nuisance to the neighbors or citizens of the city, or to disturb the peace of the city. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to allow an animal over which such person has custody or control to remain on such person's premises if the animal shall constitute a nuisance as defined in this section or by the law of the state. For the purposes of this section, it shall constitute a nuisance per se for a dog to bark, or any animal to howl, whine or emit any noises whatsoever so as to disturb any occupant of any adjoining or adjacent property within hearing distance of such property. (c) Should a complaint arise from the causes referred to in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the person involved will be properly notified and given adequate time to either dispose of the animal or fowl, or eliminate the cause of the complaint. (Code 1982, § 4-13) Sec. 14-14. - Swine. No person shall keep any swine within the city. (Code 1982, § 4-15) State Law reference— Hogs running at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq. Sec. 14-15. - Dead animals on public property. The owner of any dead animal upon the public streets and ways shall remove such dead animal so as to prevent the creation of a nuisance. If the owner fails to remove such dead animal, the city shall remove and dispose of such carcass and charge the cost of such removal and disposition to the owner of the carcass, if known. (Code 1982, § 4-16) Cross reference— Solid waste, § 90-261 et seq. State Law reference— Dead Animal Disposal Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-5-1 et seq. Sec. 14-16. - Dead animals on private property. When any dead animal is found on private property, the owner of the dead animal or the owner of the premises upon which such animal is located shall immediately remove the dead animal at such person's own cost. Upon failure to remove the dead animal within a reasonable time, the city shall remove the carcass, and the cost of such removal shall be collected from the offending party. (Code 1982, § 4-17) Cross reference— Solid waste, § 90-261 et seq. Sec. 14-17. - Dog and cat licenses. The mayor and city council shall establish a license fee for spayed or neutered dogs and cats and a license fee for dogs and cats not spayed or neutered. There shall be no charge for Seeing Eye dogs. Each such animal will be licensed according to rabies tag numbers, and rabies tags can be used as license tags. All dogs and cats must have current rabies vaccinations in order to be licensed. (Mo. of 8-19-1993) Secs. 14-18—14-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DANGEROUS DOGS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 38.
Sec. 14-51. - Definitions; exemption. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dangerous dog. (1) The term "dangerous dog" means any dog that, according to the records of an appropriate authority: a. Inflicts a severe injury on a human being, without provocation, on public or private property; or b. Aggressively bites, attacks or endangers the safety of humans, without provocation, after the dog has been classified as a potentially dangerous dog and after the owner has been notified of such classification. (2) The Rottweiler and pit bull breeds of dogs shall be considered dangerous and, as such, covered under this article. The pit bull dog shall include the following: a. Staffordshire Bull Terrier. b. American Staffordshire Terrier. c. American Pit Bull Terrier. d. Dogs which have the physical appearance of being predominantly of the breed of dogs listed in this definition. Dog control officer means an individual selected by the city, pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22(c), to aid in the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article. Owner means any natural person or any legal entity, including, but not limited to, a corporation, partnership, firm or trust owning, possessing, harboring, keeping or having custody or control of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the city. Potentially dangerous dog means any dog that, without provocation, bites a human being upon public or private property. Proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, while on the owner's property, securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, fence or structure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and top, and, if the dog is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height, and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the dog's escape either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the dog. Records of an appropriate authority means records of: (1) Any state, county or municipal law enforcement agency; (2) Any county or municipal animal control agency; (3) The county board of health; (4) A federal, state or local court; or (5) A dog control officer provided for in this article. Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery or that results in death. (b) Exemption. A dog that inflicts an injury upon a person when the dog is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties shall not be a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this article. A dog shall not be a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this article if the injury inflicted by the dog was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort, or was tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog, or had in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused or assaulted the dog, or was committing, or attempting to commit, a crime. (Ord. of 4-15-1999, § 4-14(a), (j)) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-21. Sec. 14-52. - Investigations and inquiries by dog control officers; notice of classification. (a) A dog control officer, upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within his jurisdiction from a law enforcement agency, animal control agency, rabies control officer or county board of health, shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this article. Any local government shall be authorized, but not required, to provide, by ordinance or resolution, for additional duties of a dog control officer in identifying dangerous dogs or potentially dangerous dogs and their owners to carry out the provisions of this article. (b) The dog control officer shall, if possible, interview the owner and require a sworn affidavit from any person desiring to have a dog classified as dangerous. Any animal that is the subject of a dangerous dog investigation, that is not impounded by the dog control officer, shall be confined by the owner in a securely fenced or enclosed area pending the outcome of the investigation and the outcome of any hearings related to the dangerous dog classification. The address of where the animal is, or shall be kept, shall be provided to the dog control officer. No dog that is the subject of a dangerous dog investigation may be relocated or ownership transferred pending the outcome of an investigation and related hearings. If a dog is to be destroyed, the dog shall not be relocated or ownership transferred. (c) When a dog control officer classifies a dog as a dangerous dog or reclassifies a potentially dangerous dog as a dangerous dog, the dog control officer shall notify the dog's owner, in writing, by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery to the owner's last known address of such classification or reclassification. Such notice shall be complete upon its mailing. (Ord. of 4-15-1999, § 4-14(c)) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-23. Sec. 14-53. - Classification procedures; notice; hearing. (a) As applied to the owners of potentially dangerous dogs, the procedures provided for in this section must be carried out as a necessary condition for the enforcement of the provisions of this article against such owners. As applied to the owners of dangerous dogs, the procedures provided for in this section shall not be an essential element of any crime provided for in this article. (b) When a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is classified as such, the dog control officer shall notify the dog's owner of such classification. (c) The notice to the owner shall meet the following requirements: (1) The notice shall be in writing and mailed by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery to the owner's last known address; (2) The notice shall include a summary of the dog control officer's findings that formed the basis for the dog's classification as a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog; (3) The notice shall be dated and shall state that the owner, within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, has a right to request a hearing on the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; (4) The notice shall state that the hearing, if requested, shall be before the mayor and council and shall specify the name of the applicable agency which will conduct the hearing; (5) The notice shall state that if a hearing is not requested, the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog will become effective, for all purposes under this article, on a date specified in the notice, which shall be after the last day on which the owner has a right to request a hearing; and (6) The notice shall include a form to request a hearing before the mayor and council and shall provide specific instructions on mailing or delivering such request to the agency. (d) When the mayor and council receives a request for a hearing as provided in subsection (c) of this section, it shall schedule such hearing within 30 days after receiving the request. The mayor and council shall notify the dog owner, in writing, by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery of the date, time and place of the hearing, and such notice shall be mailed to the dog owner at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be given the opportunity to testify and present evidence and, in addition thereto, the mayor and council shall receive such other evidence and hear such other testimony as the mayor and council may find reasonably necessary to make a determination either to sustain, modify or overrule the dog control officer's classification of the dog. (e) Within ten days after the date of the hearing, the mayor and council shall notify the dog owner, in writing, by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, the notice shall specify the date upon which that determination is effective. (Ord. of 4-15-1999, § 4-14(c)) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-24. Sec. 14-54. - Possession requirements. (a) It is unlawful for an owner to have or possess within the city a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog without a certificate of registration issued in accordance with the provisions of this section. (b) Subject to the additional requirements of subsection (c) of this section for dangerous dogs, the dog control officer, when an owner possesses a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of such dog, if the owner presents to the dog control officer, or the dog control officer otherwise finds, sufficient evidence of: (1) A proper enclosure to confine the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; and (2) The posting of the premises where the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is located with a clearly visible sign warning that there is a dangerous dog on the property. The state department of natural resources shall design a uniform symbol for the purpose of implementing subsection (b)(2) of this section, and shall provide copies of the design to the mayor and city council. The sign required to be posted by subsection (b)(2) of this section shall conform substantially to the design provided by the state department of natural resources pursuant to this subsection. (c) In addition to the requirements of subsection (b) of this section, the owner of a dangerous dog shall present to the dog control officer evidence of: A surety bond in the amount of $15,000.00 or more, issued by a surety company authorized to transact business in the state, payable to any person injured by the dangerous dog. (d) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer within 24 hours if the dog is on the loose, is unconfined, has attacked a human, has died or has been sold or donated. If the dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall also provide the dog control officer with the name, address and telephone number of the new owner of the dog. (e) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer if the owner is moving from the dog control officer's jurisdiction. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who is a new resident of the state shall register the dog as required in this section within 30 days after becoming a resident. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who moves from one jurisdiction to another jurisdiction within the state shall register the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog in the new jurisdiction within ten days after becoming a resident of the new jurisdiction. (f) Issuance of a certificate of registration or the renewal of a certificate of registration by the city does not warrant or guarantee that the requirements specified in subsections (b) and (c) of this section are maintained by the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog on a continuous basis following the date of the issuance of the initial certificate of registration or following the date of any annual renewal of such certificate. (g) The dog control officer is authorized to make whatever inquiry is deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this article. Law enforcement agencies of local governments and the sheriffs of counties shall cooperate with dog control officers in enforcing the provisions of this article. (h) The city shall charge an annual fee as set by the mayor and city council, in addition to regular dog licensing fees, to register dangerous dogs and potentially dangerous dogs as required in this article. Certificates of registration shall be renewed on an annual basis. At the time of the annual renewal of a certificate of registration, the dog control officer shall require evidence from the owner or make such investigation as may be necessary to verify that the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is continuing to be confined in a proper enclosure and that the owner is continuing to comply with other provisions of this article. (Ord. of 4-15-1999, § 4-14(d)—(f); Res. of 1-20-2000) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-25. Sec. 14-55. - Permitting dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs to be outside proper enclosure. (a) It is unlawful for an owner of a dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is muzzled and restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration, but will prevent the dog from biting any person. (b) It is unlawful for the owner of a potentially dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the restraint of a responsible person. (Ord. of 4-15-1999, § 4-14(g)) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-26. Sec. 14-56. - Grounds for confiscation; disposition. (a) A dangerous dog shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer, a law enforcement officer or another person authorized by the dog control officer, if the: (1) Owner of the dog does not secure the liability insurance or bond required by section 14-54(c); (2) Dog is not validly registered as required by section 14-54; (3) Dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure; or (4) Dog is outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 14-55(a). (b) A potentially dangerous dog shall be confiscated in the same manner as a dangerous dog, if the dog is: (1) Not validly registered as required by section 14-54; (2) Not maintained in a proper enclosure; or (3) Outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 14-55. (c) Any dog that has been confiscated under the provisions of subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall be returned to its owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this article and upon the payment of reasonable confiscation costs. If the owner has not complied with the provisions of this article within 20 days of the date the dog was confiscated, such dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-27. Sec. 14-57. - Specific violations; penalties. (a) The owner of a dangerous dog who violates the applicable provisions of section 14-54 or 14-55, or whose dangerous dog is subject to confiscation under section 14-56(a), shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of a high and aggravated nature. In addition to any confinement that might be imposed for a conviction under this subsection, for the second conviction, a fine of not less than $500.00 shall be imposed, and for a third or subsequent conviction, a fine of not less than $750.00 shall be imposed. (b) The owner of a potentially dangerous dog who violates the applicable provisions of section 14-54 or 14-55, or whose potentially dangerous dog is subject to confiscation under section 14-56(a), shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. In addition to any confinement that might be imposed for a conviction under this subsection, for a second conviction, a fine of not less than $150.00 shall be imposed, and for a third or subsequent conviction, a fine of not less than $300.00 shall be imposed. (c) No owner of a dangerous dog shall be held criminally liable under this article for injuries inflicted by such owner's dog to any human being while on the owner's property. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-28. Sec. 14-58. - General violations; penalties. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep or harbor a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, except in conformity with the provisions of this article. (b) Except as otherwise provided in this article, any violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, or imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or both. (Ord. of 4-15-1999, § 4-14(b))

div.head: Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Code enforcement board, § 2-201 et seq.; environment, ch. 38; fire prevention and protection, ch. 42; health and sanitation, ch. 46; historic preservation, ch. 50; planning, ch. 74; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 90; building sewers and connections, § 90-226; subdivisions, app. A; zoning, app. B; application of regulations for buildings, app. B, § 52; one principal building per lot, app. B, § 61; nonconforming uses, app. B, § 64. State Constitution reference— Power of city to provide technical codes, Ga. Const. art. IV, § II, ¶ III. State Law reference— Buildings and housing, O.C.G.A. tit. 8; construction, alteration, etc., of buildings and other structures, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.; state building, plumbing, electrical, etc., codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq.; adoption and administration of codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; fire protection and safety, O.C.G.A. tit. 25; fire safety standards and inspections, O.C.G.A. § 25-2-12; municipal authority to require closing, demolition or repair of structures intended for human habitation that are unfit, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-11; unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7; electrical contractors, plumbers, conditioned air contractors, low-voltage contractors and utility contractors, O.C.G.A. § 43-14-1 et seq.; nonresident contractors, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-30 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Standard fire safety standards, O.C.G.A. § 25-2-12; municipal authority to require closing, demolition, repair of structures intended for human habitation, which are unfit, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-11.
Sec. 18-1. - Violation of adopted codes; penalties. Any owner, builder, contractor or any other person who shall violate, or cause to be violated, any of the provisions of any code adopted in this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and subject to punishment as provided in section 1-12. (Code 1982, § 5-1) Sec. 18-2. - Fire limits established. The fire limits of the city are hereby established as that area of the city within districts C-1, C-2, C-3 and I-N as shown and indicated upon the zoning map of the city. (Code 1982, § 5-2) Charter reference— Authority to establish fire limits, regulate construction therein, § 29. Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 42. State Law reference— Regulation of fire and other hazards, O.C.G.A. § 25-2-1 et seq. Sec. 18-3. - Building code adopted; amendment procedure. (a) There is hereby adopted by the city the Standard Building Code, current edition, with Georgia amendments, as the building code of the city, subject to all amendments adopted by the mayor and city council, and to all conflicting provisions contained in this Code or state law. A certified copy of such code is on file in the office of the city clerk. (b) Revisions of, and amendments to, the Standard Building Code may be accepted for use within the city upon consideration thereof and an order to that effect adopted by the mayor and city council, by simple order entered on the minutes of the city. The action of the city in accepting such revisions or amendments to the Standard Building Code from time to time by order on its minutes shall not preclude adoption of revisions or amendments by ordinance and incorporation in this Code by reference. (Code 1982, § 5-3) State Law reference— State minimum standard building code, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20. Sec. 18-4. - Amendments to building code. The building code is hereby amended as follows: Section 104. Section 104 is hereby amended as follows: 104.6.2 Whenever the building official shall find any building or structure, or portion thereof, to be unsafe, as defined in this section, he shall, in accordance with established procedure for legal notices, give the owner, agent or person in control of such building or structure written notice, stating the defects thereof. This notice shall require the owner, within 90 days from the date of notice, either to complete specified repairs or improvements, or demolish and remove the building or structure, or portion thereof. (Code 1982, § 5-3.1) Sec. 18-5. - Inspectors. Wherever powers and duties are prescribed in this chapter for an electrical inspector, gas inspector, air conditioning, heating or ventilation inspector, or plumbing inspector, such powers and duties shall apply to the director of utilities or his designees, unless specifically otherwise provided in this chapter. (Code 1982, § 5-4) Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-91 et seq. Sec. 18-6. - Permit fees. (a) The building code is hereby amended as to permit fees to provide as determined by the mayor and city council. (b) Upon application prior to the expiration of any building permit previously issued, such permit may be extended for a period not to exceed six months from the date of its original expiration upon the payment of one-half of the permit fees prescribed in subsection (a) of this section. (c) No excavation, ditching or demolition of any lot or structure shall be allowed within the city without a permit issued by the city clerk, upon written application and a payment of a fee set by the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 5-5) Sec. 18-7. - Permit required to move buildings and structures. No person shall utilize the streets and highways within the city for movement or passage of any building or other structure without a written permit authorizing such movement. (Code 1982, § 5-6) Sec. 18-8. - Applications for building moving permits; fees. Any person desiring to move any building or other structure through or over any street or highway within the city shall apply, in writing, to the city clerk for a permit, upon such form as the clerk may prescribe, and shall pay therewith a permit per structure, or in lieu thereof, an annual permit fee, which annual permit shall expire 12 months from the date of issuance of such permit. The amounts of such fees shall be as set by the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 5-7) Sec. 18-9. - Issuance of building moving permits; restrictions and conditions. All building moving permits shall be issued with such restrictions regarding routes and hours of movement as the chief of police may prescribe and upon the express condition that holders of such permits shall agree to indemnify the city and the utilities commission for any actual labor and equipment costs or any damages suffered to streets, utilities or other public property. (Code 1982, § 5-8) Sec. 18-10. - Time limit for submission of building moving permit application; duration; transferability. All applications for building moving permits shall be submitted to the city clerk at least 48 hours prior to the proposed movement and, upon issuance, shall be valid for a period of seven days from the date of issuance, and shall not be transferable. (Code 1982, § 5-9) Sec. 18-11. - Scope of building moving permit. Each building moving permit, other than an annual permit, shall authorize the movement of only one structure. (Code 1982, § 5-10) Secs. 18-12—18-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ELECTRICITY[3] Footnotes: --- (3) --- Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 90.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 18-41. - Code adopted; amendment procedure. (a) There is hereby adopted by the city the National Electrical Code, current edition, with Georgia amendments, as the electrical code of the city, subject to all amendments adopted by the mayor and city council, and to all conflicting provisions contained in this Code or state law. A certified copy of such code is on file in the office of the city clerk. (b) Revisions of and amendments to the National Electrical Code may be accepted for use within the city upon consideration thereof and order to that effect adopted by the mayor and city council, by simple order entered on the minutes of the city. The action of the city in accepting such revisions or amendments to the National Electrical Code from time to time by order on its minutes shall not preclude adoption of revisions or amendments by ordinance and incorporation in this Code by reference. (c) All electrical construction and all material and appliances used in connection with the installation, maintenance and operation of electrical wiring, apparatus or equipment for lights, heat or power inside the city shall conform to such special rules and regulations as may be embodied in this article or other ordinances of the city, and to the rules and regulations as embodied in the National Electrical Code for the installation of wiring and apparatus for electrical purposes as established or amended, and such rules and regulations are hereby adopted and approved as a part of this article and are incorporated by reference as fully as if set out at length in this article. (Code 1982, § 5-20) State Law reference— State electrical code, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20. Sec. 18-42. - Amendments to code. The electrical code adopted in this article is hereby amended and changed in the following respects. (Cited sections of the 1962 or later editions of the National Electrical Code shall be construed to refer to analogous sections of the current or revised editions). (1) Article 110. Article 110 is hereby amended by adding the following sections: No meters shall be installed above the ground floor in any building, except by special permission. All service switches shall be mounted on a substantial wall of boards, not less than five feet from floor. All meters shall be six feet from the dial of the meter from the floor or ground. Concentric cable or entrance cable will be permitted only for service in houses and shall not be used as branch or subfeeder, except for ranges and water heaters. All feeder wires and branch circuits supplying current for elevators shall be computed on the basis of a two percent drop in voltage based on starting current of elevator motors having the same current characteristics which are supplied from one main feeder; such feeders may be computed on a two percent drop in voltage based on 75 percent of the combined starting current of all motors supplied by such feeder drops to be taken at the controller. The minimum size of the conductors to any individual elevator motor circuit shall be based on the starting current of the motor and in accordance with the code rating of the conductor. Open wiring on insulators or racks shall not be permitted in or on buildings, except by special permission. Attic fans and ventilating fans over 16 inches shall be equipped with a safety link or other approved device in the air stream causing the current to be disconnected or to close off the air stream when the temperature rises above 165 degrees Fahrenheit; the location of the control to meet with the approval of the department or agency of the city having jurisdiction. Any electrical wiring in public buildings which shall be installed shall be encased in metal conduits. In all nonpublic one- and two-story wood frame construction outside the fire limits, the use of copper type NM plastic-covered, grounded Romex is permitted. Aluminum service entrance cable may be used as needed for panels in multiple unit apartment structures of wood frame one- or two-story construction, provided such cable has a fuse disconnect at the meter location. It shall be unlawful for any person to bridge a fuse gap in an ungrounded conductor in any manner whereby the conductor protected by such gap is fused above its rated capacity. All residents requiring six-branch circuits with provision for an electric range and dryer or water heater will require a 100-amp main. Only residences which have no provisions for an electric range, dryer or water heater will be accepted for 60-amp and No. 6 wire. No breakers for a range will be installed if, in the opinion of the inspector, a main and range panel can be installed. Each ranch-type house will have to be inspected as to which way to connect service wires to the main. In most cases, conduit will extend through the roof at the nearest point to the utility supply pole. Such conduit will be of from 1½-inch rigid up to four inches, with an approved weather head, and extending from 12 to 30 inches above the roof, with the height depending upon the location and required clearance. All mains must be encased in rigid conduit to the meter for any and all services, and no mains will be smaller than No. 6 wire and the neutral will be so marked by color (white). All nonmetallic sheathed cable shall be of the grounding type. Boxes used at outlets for receptacles and lighting fixtures shall be designed for such purpose and shall be of the grounding type. (2) Article 210. Article 210 is amended as follows: The maximum wattage permitted on No. 12 wire branch circuits shall be 1,500 watts. On branch circuits where the feed is over 100 feet to the first light, it shall be necessary to increase to the next larger size wire. These requirements apply to 110-volt branch circuits. In establishments used as beauty parlors, all branch circuits supplying current for receptacle outlets shall be on a size No. 12 or larger. No receptacle will be allowed on a circuit supplying current for ceiling or bracket outlets. Only two receptacle outlets shall be allowed on one circuit. All receptacles shall be not less than 15-amp capacity and of single gauge type. (3) Article 230. Article 230 is hereby amended by adding the following sections: Service entrance wires in all buildings shall be run in rigid conduits. Service conduits are to be continuous from the point where the utility company's wires attach to building to meter [sic] and shall have not less than three feet of wire left at the outer end of service conduits. All services for ranch type houses, or low roofs where the service wire is less than ten feet, must extend above the roof 12 inches or more, depending upon the type of service wire that is to be used. All service entrance wires shall be brought out at the nearest point of accessibility to the utilities' service drop, except by special permission of the authority enforcing this code. All service entrances shall terminate in approved type fittings and be securely anchored so as to hold the service drop. Not more than two service entrances shall be run from any one service drop, except by permission of authority enforcing this code. Each separately metered installation of more than two branch circuits shall be controlled by an approved type safety switch, with fuses no larger than the capacity of the service wires. Meter service switches which control four or more circuits shall be not less than three-wire, 60-amp capacity. On all buildings or houses that require four or more circuits, the service shall be of three wires of a size not less than No. 6. All service entrances supplying five or more meters shall be provided with a main line breaker or switch. On installations requiring service switches larger than 400-amp capacity, an approved circuit breaker shall be installed. All service wires shall be of a size or capacity, within ten percent, to carry the full load rating of the service switch.
