If the owner of any property shall refuse or fail to comply with the provisions of section 40-11 after ten days' written notice addressed to the owner of such property and delivered to the property by a city official or employee, the city shall remove the offensive matter and/or cut such weeds and undergrowth on the property. Such work shall be done at the expense of the owner of the property. Upon completion of such work, execution shall be issued by the city clerk against the owner and the property for such expense and all costs. The person returning such property for taxation in the city, or the person against whom such property may be assessed if there has been no return of such property by the owner, shall be deemed to be the true owner of such property. Such execution shall issue and be enforced as provided by the Charter or by law. (Code 1982, § 11-13) State Law reference— Abatement authority of municipal court, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5. Sec. 46-14. - Junked and dismantled automobiles and discarded personal property—Maximum storage period. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any furniture, appliance, machinery or equipment, including motor vehicles which are either in a wholly or partially rusted, wrecked, junked, dismantled or inoperative condition to remain on the premises of any dwelling, dwelling unit, place of business or vacant lot for a period in excess of 30 days. (Code 1982, § 11-14) Sec. 46-15. - Junked and dismantled automobiles and discarded personal property—Duty of owners, occupants and inhabitants. It shall be the duty of owners, occupants and inhabitants of any building, dwelling or dwelling unit to keep the exterior of such building, dwelling or dwelling unit, including its premises, yards, lawns, courts and alleys, clean, clear and free of any accumulation or deposit of the items set forth in section 46-14; provided, the owner of a dwelling or building containing two or more dwelling units, tenants or occupants shall be responsible for maintaining the shared or public area of the dwelling or building and premises thereof. The same duty under this section shall rest upon the owner of any vacant lot. (Code 1982, § 11-15) Sec. 46-16. - Junked and dismantled automobiles and discarded personal property—Exemptions. Sections 46-14 and 46-15 shall not apply to any person who holds a valid business license for dealing in the items set forth in section 46-14 in the condition referred to in such section, provided such business is not operated in an unlawful manner. (Code 1982, § 11-16) Sec. 46-17. - Junked and dismantled automobiles and discarded personal property—Abatement. Conditions prohibited by section 46-14 may be abated by the city as provided in section 46-13. (Code 1982, § 11-17) Sec. 46-18. - Toilet facilities and connection to public sewer required. The owner of any house, building or other property used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purpose, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is or may be located a public sanitary or combined sewer of the city, is hereby required, at such person's expense, to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this Code, within 90 days after the date of official notice to do so, provided that such public sewer is within 200 feet of the property line. (Code 1982, § 11-18) Cross reference— Sewers, § 90-221 et seq. Sec. 46-19. - Private sewage disposal systems. (a) Where a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available under the provisions of section 46-18, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this section. (b) Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit issued by the director of utilities and any required county board of health permit. (c) All private sewage disposal systems shall be installed and completed to the satisfaction of the director of utilities. The director of utilities shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the holder of the permit shall notify the director of utilities when the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within 72 hours of the receipt of notice for such inspection by the director of utilities. (d) The type, capacity, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all standards of the state department of human resources. No private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities shall be installed where the area of the lot is less than 15,000 square feet. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet or to the surface. (e) At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, as provided in section 46-18, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this Code, and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. (f) The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city utility commission. (g) No statement contained in this section shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the county board of health. (h) When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to such public sewer within 90 days; and the private sewage disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean bankrun gravel or dirt. (Code 1982, § 11-19)

div.head: Chapter 47 - TREES
div.p: Sec. 47-1. - Tree board establishment. (a) There is hereby created the Fort Valley Tree Board. The board shall consist of five members appointed by majority vote of the mayor and council. (b) The terms of the members of the tree board shall be for five years; however, the initial board members' terms shall be one through five years as determined by lot. Members may be reappointed at the discretion of the mayor and council without unlimited terms. (c) The members shall serve without compensation. (d) At the first meeting of each new calendar year the board shall elect a chairperson who shall be a voting member of the board. (e) A meeting may be called by the chairperson or by three board members. (f) Three board members shall constitute a quorum. (Ord. No. 06-0316-11, § 47-2, 3-16-2006) Sec. 47-2. - Duties and authority of tree board. (a) The tree board is authorized to formulate provisions for a recommended tree ordinance for presentation to the mayor and council for consideration and adoption and, as appropriate, to recommend amendments to the tree ordinance adopted by the mayor and council. (b) The tree board is authorized to develop rules for conduct of the board and shall operate pursuant to such rules as approved by the mayor and council. (c) The tree board shall have such other duties and authority as conferred by the mayor and council. (Ord. No. 06-0316-11, § 47-2(1), 3-16-2006)

div.head: Chapter 50 - HISTORIC PRESERVATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 38; planning, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 90; zoning, app. B. State Law reference— Historic preservation, O.C.G.A. § 44-10-1 et seq.
Sec. 50-1. - Historic preservation guidelines adopted. The Fort Valley Local Historic District Guidelines, which is attached to the resolution from which this section is derived, is adopted as part of this section as if set out at length in this section. (Res. of 9-24-1998; Res. No. 11-1215-37, 12-15-2011; Res. No. 11-1215-38, 12-15-2011) Sec. 50-2. - Purpose and intent. In support and furtherance of its findings and determination that the historic, cultural and aesthetic heritage of the city is a valuable and important asset and that the preservation of such heritage will enhance the promotion of the health, prosperity and general welfare of the people; in order to stimulate revitalization of the business districts and historic neighborhoods and to protect and enhance local historical and aesthetic attractions to tourists and thereby promote and stimulate business; in order to enhance the opportunities for federal or state tax benefits under relevant provisions of federal or state law; and in order to provide for the designation, protection, preservation and rehabilitation of historic properties and historic districts and to participate in federal or state programs therefor; the mayor and city council hereby declare it to be the purpose and intent of this chapter to establish a uniform procedure for use in providing for the protection, enhancement and perpetuation of places, districts, sites, buildings, structures, objects and works of art having a special historical, cultural or aesthetic interest or value in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. of 10-21-1993, § I) Sec. 50-3. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Certificate of appropriateness means a document evidencing approval by the historic preservation commission of an application to make a material change in the appearance of a designated historic property or of a property located within a designated historic district. Exterior architectural feature means the architectural style, general design and general arrangement of the exterior of a building or other structure, including, but not limited to, the kind or texture of the building material and the type and style of all windows, doors, signs and other appurtenant architectural fixtures, features, details or elements relative thereto. The term "exterior architectural feature" does not include pane color. Historic district means a geographically definable area designated by the mayor and city council as an historic district pursuant to the criteria established in section 50-5. Historic property means an individual building, landmark, structure, site, object or work of art, including the adjacent area necessary for the proper appreciation thereof, designated by the mayor and city council as an historic property pursuant to the criteria established in section 50-5. Material change in appearance means a change that will affect only the external architectural features of an historic property or any structure, site or work of art within an historic district, and may include any one or more of the following: (1) A reconstruction or alteration of the size, shape or facade of an historical property, including relocation of any door or window, or removal or alteration of any architectural feature, detail or element. (2) Demolition of an historic property. (3) Commencement of excavation for construction purposes. (4) A change in the location or size of advertising signs on an historic property when such advertising is visible from a public right-of-way. (5) The erection, alteration, restoration or removal of any building or other structure within an historic property or historic district, including walls, fences, steps and pavement, or other appurtenant features, except external paint alterations. (Ord. of 10-21-1993, § II) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 50-4. - Historic preservation commission. (a) Created. There is hereby created a commission whose title shall be "The Fort Valley Historic Preservation Commission," referred to in this chapter as "commission" or "the commission." (b) Position within the city government. The commission shall be part of the planning functions of the city. Staff functions shall be performed by the chief building official. (c) Membership. The commission shall consist of nine members. Members of the commission shall be appointed by majority vote of the mayor and council. All members shall own property in the city and shall have been residents of the city for a minimum of one year at the time of their appointment. At all times one member shall be a resident of a designated historic district. The remaining members shall be individuals who, because of special interest, special training, knowledge or skills in the fields of real estate, law, history or architecture will be able to provide expertise in the operation of the commission. (d) Powers and duties. The commission shall be authorized to: (1) Prepare and maintain an inventory of all property within the city having the potential for designation as historic property; (2) Recommend to the city council specific places, districts, sites, buildings, structures, objects or works of art to be designated by ordinance as historic properties or historic districts; (3) Review applications for certificates of appropriateness, and grant or deny such applications in accordance with the provisions of this chapter; (4) Recommend to the city council that the designation of any place, district, site, building, landmark, structure, object or work of art as an historic property or historic district be revoked or removed; (5) Direct the restoration or preservation of any historic property acquired by the city; (6) Promote the acquisition by the city of facade easements and conservation easements in accordance with the provisions of the Georgia Uniform Conservation Easement Act (O.C.G.A. §§ 44-10-1—44-10-8); (7) Conduct educational programs on historic properties located within the city; (8) Make such investigations and studies of matters relating to historic preservation as the city council or the commission itself may deem necessary or appropriate for the purposes of this chapter; (9) Seek out local, state, federal and private funds for historic preservation, and make recommendations to the city council concerning the most appropriate uses of any funds acquired; (10) Submit to the division of historic preservation of the state department of natural resources a list of historic properties or historic districts designated as such pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 44-10-26; (11) Perform historic preservation activities as the official agency of the city historic preservation program; (12) Receive donations, grants, funds or gifts of historic property and make recommendations to the mayor and city council for disposition of such donations, grants, funds or gifts; (13) Review and make comments to the division of historic preservation of the state department of natural resources concerning the nomination of properties within its jurisdiction to the National Register of Historic Places; and (14) With the consent of the mayor and city council, participate in private, state and federal historic preservation programs. (e) Power to adopt rules and standards. (1) The commission shall adopt rules for the transaction of its business and for consideration of applications for designations and certificates of appropriateness, such as bylaws, removal of membership provisions, and design guidelines and criteria. The commission shall have the flexibility to adopt such rules without amendment to the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. The commission shall provide for the time and place of regular meetings and a method for the calling of special meetings. The commission shall select such officers as it deems appropriate from among its members. A quorum shall consist of five members. (2) Prior to enforcement of any requirements of this chapter, the commission shall develop and publish detailed design guidelines for rehabilitation of historic properties and new construction in historic districts designated by the city council. Such guidelines shall be discussed as a public hearing held by the city council at least 30 days prior to adoption of such guidelines. Once the guidelines are approved by the city council and published, any changes will require approval of the mayor and city council. (f) Conflicts of interest. At any time the commission reviews a project in which a member of the commission has ownership or other vested interest, that member will be forbidden from presenting, voting or discussing the project. (g) Records of meetings. A public record shall be kept of the commission's resolutions, proceedings and actions. All meetings of the commission shall be open to the public. Times and places of such meetings shall be posted on the city hall bulletin board at least one week in advance. (Ord. of 10-21-1993, § III; Mo. of 11-18-1993; Res. No. 03-0821-54, 8-21-2003; Ord. No. 04-0219-12, 3-18-2004; Res. No. 11-1215-39, 12-15-2011) Cross reference— Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-201 et seq. Sec. 50-5. - Recommendations and designations. (a) Preliminary research by commission. (1) Compilation and collection of information and conducting surveys. The commission shall compile and collect information and conduct surveys of historic resources within the city. For economic purposes, this should be done in conjunction with any other interested organization in the county or the city. (2) Power to recommend districts and buildings for designation. The commission shall present recommendations for historic districts and properties to the mayor and city council. (3) Documentation of proposed designation. Prior to the commission's recommendation of an historic district or historic property to the mayor and city council for designation, the commission shall prepare a report consisting of: a. A physical description; b. A statement of historical, cultural, architectural and/or aesthetic significance; c. A map showing district boundaries and classifications (i.e., historic, nonhistoric, intrusive) of individual properties therein, or showing boundaries of individual historic properties; d. A statement justifying district or individual property boundaries; and e. Representative photographs. (b) Designation of an historic district. (1) Criteria for selection. An historic district is a geographically definable area, which contains structures, landmarks, sites, objects and works of art, or a combination thereof, which: a. Has special character or special historical/aesthetic value or interest; b. Represents one or more periods, styles or types of architecture typical of one or more eras in the history of the municipality, county, state, region or nation; and c. Cause such area, by reason of such factors, to constitute a visibly perceptible section of the municipality or county. (2) Boundaries. Boundaries of an historic district shall be included in the separate ordinances designating such districts and shall be shown on the official zoning map of the city. (3) Evaluation of properties. Individual properties within historic districts shall be classified as: a. Historic (contributes to the district and is at least 50 years old); b. Nonhistoric (does not contribute, but does not detract from the district, as provided for in subsection (b)(1) of this section. In time, such property may be reclassified as an historic property); c. Intrusive (detracts from the district as provided for in subsection (b)(1) of this section). (c) Designation of an historic property. (1) Criteria for selection. An historic property is a building, landmark, structure, site or work of art which is deemed worthy of preservation by reason of value to the city, the state or the local region, for one of the following reasons: a. It is an outstanding example of a structure representative of its era and is at least 50 years old; b. It is one of the few remaining examples of past architectural style, either in the city or its respective neighborhood; c. It is a place or structure associated with an event or persons of historic or cultural significance to the city, the state or the region; or d. It is a site of natural or aesthetic interest, that is continuing to contribute to the cultural or historical development and heritage of the city, county, state or region. (2) Boundary description. Boundaries shall be included in the separate ordinances designating such properties and shall be shown on the official zoning map of the city. (d) Requirements for adopting an ordinance for designations of historic districts and historic properties. (1) Applications. Designations of historic districts and historic properties may be proposed by the city, the commission or: a. Historic districts. An historical society, neighborhood association or group of property owners may apply to the commission for designation; b. Historic properties. An historical society neighborhood association or group of property owners may apply to the commission for designation. (2) Required components of a designation ordinance. Any ordinance designating any property or district as historic shall: a. List each property in a proposed historic district or describe the proposed individual historic property; b. Set forth the name of the owner of the designated property; c. Require that a certificate of appropriateness be obtained from the commission prior to any material change to the designated property; and d. Require that the property or district be shown on the official zoning map and kept as a public record to provide notice of such designation. (3) Required public hearings. The commission and the city council shall hold a public hearing on any proposed ordinance for the designation of any historic district or property. Notice of the hearing shall be published in at least three consecutive issues in the principal newspaper of local circulation, and written notice of the hearing shall be mailed by the commission to all owners and occupants of such properties. All such notices shall be published or mailed not less than ten days, nor more than 20 days prior to the date set for the public hearing. A notice sent by the United States mail to the last known owner of the property shown on the city tax roll, and a notice sent by United States mail to the address of the property to the attention of the occupant shall constitute legal notification to the owner and occupant under this subsection. Designation of individual properties will not be made if the owner objects, or designation of historic districts will not be made if a majority of property owners object. (4) Recommendations on proposed designations. A recommendation to affirm, modify or withdraw the proposed ordinance for designation shall be made by the commission within 15 days following the public hearing and shall be in the form of a resolution to the mayor and city council. (5) City council action on commission recommendation. Following the receipt of the commission's recommendation, the city council may adopt the ordinance as proposed, may adopt the ordinance with any amendments it deems necessary, or may reject the ordinance. Adoption of the ordinance shall require a majority vote of the city council. (6) Notification of division of historic preservation. No less than 30 days prior to making a recommendation on any ordinance designating a property or district as historic, the commission must submit the report required in subsection (a)(3) of this section to the division of historic preservation of the state department of natural resources. (7) Notification of adoption of ordinance for designation. Within 30 days following the adoption of the ordinance for designation by the city council, the owners and occupants of each designated historic property, and the owners and occupants of each structure, site or work of art located within a designated historic district shall be given written notification of such designation by the city council, which shall apprise such owners and occupants of the necessity of obtaining a certificate of appropriateness prior to undertaking any material change in the appearance of the designated historic property or within the designated historic district. A notice sent via United States mail to the last known owner of the property shown on the city tax roll and a notice sent via United States mail to the address of the property to the attention of the occupant shall constitute a legal notification to the owner and occupant under this subsection. (8) Notification of other agencies of ordinance for designation. The commission shall notify all necessary agencies within the city of the ordinance for designation, including the person or organization which made application for such designation. (Ord. of 10-21-1993, § IV) Sec. 50-6. - Certificates of appropriateness. (a) When required. (1) Material changes. After designation by ordinance of an historic property or an historic district, no material change to the building, structure, site or work of art in such district shall be made without a certificate of appropriateness. (2) New construction. After designation by ordinance of an historic district, no new construction shall begin without a certificate of appropriateness. (b) Guidelines and criteria used in considering applications. When considering applications for certificates of appropriateness, the commission shall use the guidelines established by section 50-4(e)(2). (c) Filing applications. (1) Submission. Applications for certificates of appropriateness shall be submitted to the commission through the office of the city clerk. (2) Required drawings, specifications, etc. The applicant is not required to submit detailed drawings, plans or specifications with the application; however, the applicant must submit preliminary drawings, sketches and specifications showing proposed exterior alterations, additions or changes. Applications for demolition of existing buildings shall also contain proposed plans for reuse of the land and preliminary drawings, sketches and specifications of any new buildings or structures to be constructed on the land. (d) Commission disposition of applications. (1) Approval. The commission shall approve the application if material changes meet the requirements of the guidelines established in section 50-4(e)(2). (2) Disapproval. The commission shall disapprove the application if material changes do not meet the requirements of the guidelines established in section 50-4(e)(2) and an acceptable compromise cannot be reached with the property owner. a. If the commission rejects an application, the commission shall state its reasons for doing so, and shall transmit a record of such actions and reasons, in writing, to the applicant. The commission may suggest alternative courses of action it thinks proper if it disapproves of the application submitted. The applicant, if he desires, may make modifications to the plans and may resubmit the application at any time after making such modifications, or appeal the ruling to the city council. b. In cases where the application covers a material change in the appearance of a structure which would require the issuance of a building permit, the rejection of the application for a certificate of appropriateness by the commission shall be binding upon the building inspector or other administrative officer charged with issuing building permits and, in such case, no building permit shall be issued. (e) Undue hardships. Where, by reason of unusual circumstances, the strict application of any provision of this chapter would result in difficulty or undue hardship upon any owner of a specific property, the commission, in passing upon applications for certificates of appropriateness, shall have the power to vary or modify strict adherence to such provisions, or to interpret the meaning of such provisions, so as to relieve such difficulty or hardship, provided such variances, modifications or interpretations shall remain in harmony with the general purpose and intent of such provisions, so that the architectural or historical integrity or character of the property shall be conserved and substantial justice done. In granting variances, the commission may impose such reasonable and additional stipulations and conditions as will, in its judgement, best fulfill the purpose of this chapter. (f) Notices; public hearings on applications. At least seven days prior to review of a certificate of appropriateness, the commission shall take such action as may reasonably be required to inform the owners of any property likely to be affected by reason of the application, and shall give the applicant and such owners an opportunity to be heard. In cases where the commission deems it necessary, it may hold a public hearing concerning the application. (g) Consideration of interior arrangements and uses. In its review of applications for certificates of appropriateness, the commission shall not consider interior arrangement or use. (h) Deadline for approval or rejection of application. (1) Notice. The commission shall approve or reject an application for a certificate of appropriateness within 45 days after the filing of such application. Notice of approval or disapproval shall be sent by United States mail to the applicant. (2) Failure to act before deadline. Failure of the commission to act within such 45-day period shall constitute approval, and no other evidence of approval shall be needed. (i) Conformance. All work performed pursuant to a certificate of appropriateness shall conform to the requirements of such certificate. Such conformance is to be determined by the appropriate city official with responsibility for building inspection. (j) Commencement of construction; period of validity; renewal. A certificate of appropriateness shall become void unless construction is commenced within six months of the date of issuance of such certificate of appropriateness. Certificates of appropriateness shall be issued for 18-month periods and are renewable. (k) Records of applications and commission's proceedings. The commission shall keep a public record of all applications for certificates of appropriateness and of all the commission's proceedings in connection with such applications. (l) Appeals. Any person adversely affected by any determination made by the commission relative to the issuance or denial of a certificate of appropriateness may appeal such determination to the city council. Any such appeal must be filed with the city council within 15 days after the issuance of the determination pursuant to subsection (d) of this section or, in the case of failure of the commission to act, within 15 days of expiration of the 45-day period allowed for commission action pursuant to subsection (h)(1) of this section. The city council may approve, modify or reject the determination made by the commission. Appeals from decisions of the city council may be taken to the superior court of the county in the manner provided by law for appeals from convictions for city ordinance violations. (m) Affirmation of existing building and zoning codes. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to exempt property owners from complying with existing city or county building and zoning codes, nor to prevent any property owner from making use of his property not prohibited by other statutes, ordinances or regulations. (Ord. of 10-21-1993, § V) Sec. 50-7. - Demolition or relocation of historic properties. (a) It is the policy of the city to encourage the preservation of historic buildings, structures, sites and areas which constitute a part of the historic fabric of the city or its respective neighborhood. (b) Upon receipt of an application for a certificate of appropriateness to demolish or relocate a building or structure, or any part thereof, the commission shall review the circumstances and the condition of the building or structure, or part thereof, proposed for demolition or relocation and prepare a report of its findings. The report shall include factual data addressing the following criteria: (1) Is the building of such architectural or historical interest that its removal would be detrimental to the public interest? (2) Is the building of such old and unusual or uncommon design, texture and material that it could not be reproduced, or reproduced only with great difficulty? (3) Would retention of the building help preserve and protect an historic place or area of historic interest in the city? (4) Would retention of the building promote the general welfare by maintaining and increasing real estate values; generating business; creating new positions attracting tourists, students, writers, historians, artists and artisans; attracting new residents; encouraging study and interest in American history; or making the city or county a more desirable place in which to live? (c) Based on the report as set forth in subsection (b) of this section, the commission shall: (1) Determine that none of the criteria listed in subsection (b) of this section applies, and issue a certificate of appropriateness for demolition or relocation; (2) Delay issuing the certificate of appropriateness for up to 90 days in order to allow persons or groups interested in historic preservation to work with the owner or applicant in an effort to preserve the structure or locate purchasers who would agree to preserve the building or structure in accordance with the provisions of this chapter; or (3) Issue a certificate of appropriateness, if efforts at preservation prove unavailing. However, no certificate of appropriateness shall be issued for demolishing any structure listed specifically in the National Register of Historical Properties. (Ord. of 10-21-1993, § VI) Cross reference— Repair, closing or demolition of buildings and structures, § 18-291 et seq. Sec. 50-8. - Certain changes and uses not prohibited. (a) Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent the ordinary maintenance or repair of any exterior architectural feature in or on an historic property or property in an historic district when such maintenance or repair does not involve a material change in design, material or outer appearance thereof, nor prevents any owner from making any use of his property not prohibited by other laws, ordinances or regulations. (b) Ordinary maintenance or repair of any exterior architectural feature in or on an historic property to correct deterioration, decay or damage or to sustain existing form, and that does not involve a material change in design, material or outer appearance thereof, does not require a certificate of appropriateness. Change in paint color does not require a certificate of appropriateness; however, property owners are encouraged to seek advice from the commission when changing paint color. Application of all forms of siding (e.g., aluminum, vinyl, asphalt, etc.) does constitute a material change and requires a certificate of appropriateness. (c) Owners of designated historic properties or properties located in designated historic districts shall be required to maintain their property in accordance with existing laws of the city. The city historic preservation commission does not have the power to require special maintenance of historic properties or historic districts; however, the commission may request the appropriate city officials to take action on properties being neglected or not maintained in accordance with existing laws. (Ord. of 10-21-1993, § VII) Sec. 50-9. - Violations of chapter; penalties. Violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished in the same manner as provided in section 1-12 for punishment of violations of other validly enacted ordinances of the city. (Ord. of 10-21-1993, § VIII)

div.head: Chapter 54 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Appointment of marshal, § 18; general duties of marshal, § 36; marshal to levy executions, § 37. Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; civil emergencies, ch. 30; courts, ch. 34; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 62; personnel, ch. 70; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86; duties and authority of police officers, § 86-42; accident report to be given to police, § 86-66. State Constitution reference— Police protection, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(1). State Law reference— Obstructing or hindering law enforcement officers, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-24; arrest of persons, O.C.G.A. § 17-4-1 et seq.; appropriation for training of police officers, O.C.G.A. § 35-4-7; qualifications of peace officer, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-8; special police, O.C.G.A. § 35-9-1 et seq.; compensation of law enforcement officers, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-9; Peace Officers' Annuity and Benefit Fund, O.C.G.A. § 47-17-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 54-1—54-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 54-31. - Personnel matters; responsibility and authority. The chief of police and police committee, acting together, shall have sole responsibility to make recommendations of employment and dismissal of police department personnel and salary schedules to the mayor and city council, which shall, in session, set salaries, make employments and declare dismissals. (Code 1982, § 17-30) Sec. 54-32. - Employment of police authorized. The mayor and city council are hereby authorized to employ a sufficient number of police officers as may be deemed necessary from time to time. (Code 1982, § 17-31) Sec. 54-33. - Knowledge of rules, regulations, laws and ordinances. All police officers shall acquire a full and complete knowledge of the rules and regulations provided for the government of the police department and with the sections of this Code and the laws and ordinances of the city in order that they may enforce such rules, regulations, laws and ordinances. (Code 1982, § 17-32) Sec. 54-34. - Oath; duties. The police officers employed by the city shall take the oath of office prescribed for the chief of police. Such police officers shall perform the same duties as the chief of police and such other duties as may be required by the mayor and city council, but shall remain subordinate to the chief of police. (Code 1982, § 17-33) Sec. 54-35. - Disposition of lost or stolen property. All property coming into the possession of the police, and which is suspected to be lost or stolen, shall be deposited with the chief of police for safekeeping. (Code 1982, § 17-35) Secs. 54-36—54-60. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - CHIEF OF POLICE[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-91 et seq.; pawnbrokers reporting to chief of police, § 22-132.
Sec. 54-61. - Appointment. There shall be appointed annually an officer known as the chief of police, who shall hold office at the pleasure of the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 2-60) Charter reference— Appointment of marshal, § 18. Sec. 54-62. - Oath; bond. (a) Before entering upon the duties of the office, the chief of police shall take the following oath: "I do solemnly swear that I will faithfully perform all the duties imposed on me by the laws and ordinances of the city as chief of police of said city." (b) The chief of police shall give the bond prescribed by the mayor and city council, conditioned on the faithful performance of such duties. (Code 1982, § 2-61) Sec. 54-63. - Duties. The chief of police shall have the responsibility for preserving peace, good order, safety and tranquility in the city; superintend, control and direct the members of the police department; and shall carry out the orders and directions of the mayor, the courts and the police committee about matters in which they severally have jurisdiction under the ordinances of the city. (Code 1982, § 2-62) Charter reference— Duties of marshal, §§ 36, 37; chief of police or designee to act as clerk of court, § 15(d). Sec. 54-64. - Reports; arrests; prosecution of offenders. The chief of police shall report, arrest and prosecute all offenders against the laws and ordinances of the city as shall come to his knowledge, and cause his subordinates to do the same. (Code 1982, § 2-63) Sec. 54-65. - Attendance at meetings of mayor and city council and sessions of municipal court. (a) The chief of police shall attend all meetings of the mayor and city council, when required. (b) The chief of police shall also attend the sessions of the municipal court as clerk of such court, keep a police docket in which shall be entered the names of the parties, the general nature of the offenses, the disposition of the cases and the amounts of the fines, and perform such other duties in connection with the municipal court as may be required of such officer. (Code 1982, § 2-64) Charter reference— Chief of police or designee to act as clerk of court, § 15(d). Cross reference— Municipal court, § 34-31 et seq. Sec. 54-66. - Care of prisoners. The chief of police shall be responsible for the care and well-being of all prisoners confined in the city jail. (Code 1982, § 2-65) Sec. 54-67. - Reports. The chief of police shall make the following reports: (1) The property received from his predecessor, which report shall be made at the first meeting after the chief of police has been installed as such officer. (2) A full report at the close of the year of all property received during the year, and of all property on hand at the close of the year turned over to his successor. (Code 1982, § 2-66) Sec. 54-68. - Record of property. The chief of police shall keep a book in which he shall enter a schedule of all city property turned over to him by his predecessor and all such property as he may receive from other sources. (Code 1982, § 2-67) Sec. 54-69. - Delivery of property to successor. It shall be the duty of the chief of police, at the expiration of his term, to turn over to his successor, by schedule, all writs, executions or unexecuted processes remaining in the chief of police's hands; all books, records and other papers and property belonging to the office or the city under the chief of police's control; and such persons as shall be confined under the chief of police's charge, with the cause of detention for each; and, upon failure to do as required in this section within five days after the expiration of the term of office, the chief of police shall be punished as for a misdemeanor. (Code 1982, § 2-68)

div.head: Chapter 58 - LIBRARY[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78. State Law reference— Libraries, O.C.G.A. § 20-5-1 et seq.; local and regional public libraries, O.C.G.A. § 20-5-20 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 58-1—58-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - THOMAS PUBLIC LIBRARY DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 58-31—58-50. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-201 et seq.
Sec. 58-51. - Name. The name of the governing board of the Thomas Public Library shall be the Thomas Public Library Board of Trustees. (Code 1982, § 12-20) Sec. 58-52. - Composition. The library board of trustees shall consist of six members, four of whom shall be appointed by the mayor and city council and two of whom shall be ex officio members consisting of the mayor and the president of the Thomas Public Library Auxiliary. (Code 1982, § 12-21) Sec. 58-53. - Terms of office of appointive members. The appointive members of the library board of trustees shall serve for four years. The terms of the appointive members shall be staggered, with one term expiring each year. (Code 1982, § 12-22) Sec. 58-54. - Compensation of members. No member of the library board of trustees shall receive any compensation for service on such board. (Code 1982, § 12-23) Sec. 58-55. - Filling membership vacancies. When a vacancy occurs by resignation, death or expiration of a term, the library board of trustees shall make a recommendation to the mayor and city council for the appointment of a new member to such board for the unexpired term or for a four-year term if it is the replacement of a person whose term has expired. (Code 1982, § 12-24) Sec. 58-56. - Officers. At its first meeting in each fiscal year, the library board of trustees shall elect a chairperson, vice- chairperson, secretary and treasurer, all of whom shall serve for one year, with the right to be reelected for additional one-year terms. (Code 1982, § 12-25) Sec. 58-57. - Scope of authority. The library board of trustees shall have complete control and management of the Thomas Public Library and any branches thereof in the county. (Code 1982, § 12-26) Sec. 58-58. - Duties and responsibilities. The library board of trustees shall have general supervision over all public libraries in the city and the county, and all powers and privileges incident thereto, including the following, which in no way limits the general powers of such board: (1) Adopt bylaws under which the library board of trustees shall operate. (2) Prescribe rules and regulations for the control, operation, management and use of the Thomas Public Library and any branches thereof in the county. (3) Establish branches of the public libraries. (4) Establish the compensation and qualifications for employees of the public libraries, including the selection and termination of employees. (5) Enter into contracts for the benefit of the libraries. (6) Expend the appropriated funds in accordance with the budget of the libraries. (7) Accept donations of money, land and other property for the use and benefit of the libraries, and the title to such lands shall be taken in the name of the city or county. (8) Hold property, including land, buildings, books and other equipment, for the use and benefit of the libraries. (9) Operate, control, manage and direct the policies of the public libraries, but shall not become the entity in which legal title to such properties is situated. (10) Do all such acts and things that may be necessary to carry out the purposes for which the library board of trustees was created. (Code 1982, § 12-27) Sec. 58-59. - Receiving funds; Lula Thomas Fund. The library board of trustees shall receive appropriate funds from the county, city, state and United States government and shall be the final authority as to the disbursement of such funds in accordance with the regulations and provisions of law of the several existing governmental bodies. The library board of trustees shall also administer the Lula Thomas Fund in accordance with the directions and provisions of the last will and testament of Lula T. Thomas, and shall make an annual accounting to the mayor and city council, the members of which are the trustees thereof, at the expense of the city. (Code 1982, § 12-28)

div.head: Chapter 62 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Courts, ch. 34; law enforcement, ch. 54; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86. State Constitution reference— Limitations on special legislation, Ga. Const. art. III, § IV, ¶ IV. State Law reference— Crimes and offenses, O.C.G.A. tit. 16; ordinances prohibiting loitering for prostitution, O.C.G.A. § 16-6-24; criminal trespass, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-21; maintaining a disorderly house, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-44; peeping Toms, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-61; abandonment of containers, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-100; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; gambling, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20 et seq.; adoption of municipal ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-3(a).
Sec. 62-1. - Adoption of state misdemeanors. Any act, the commission of which constitutes a misdemeanor under the laws of the state, is prohibited within the city, and if such an act is committed within the city, it is hereby declared to be an offense; provided, however, that the penalty therefor shall not exceed the penalty prescribed in section 1-12 of this Code. (Code 1982, § 15-1) Sec. 62-2. - False reports by city personnel. It shall be unlawful for any officer or employee of the city, whose duty it is to make a report or return, to do so falsely. (Code 1982, § 15-2) Sec. 62-3. - Curfew regulations. (a) During any period of curfew proclaimed by the mayor, it shall be unlawful for any person to be on the streets of the city, either on foot or in any vehicle, during curfew hours, except for the purpose of going to or from work or a valid emergency reason. (b) During any such period of curfew, it shall be unlawful for any business to remain open during curfew hours, except by special written permit from the city administrator in accordance with a form approved by the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 15-3) Sec. 62-4. - Curfew for minors; parental responsibility. (a) It shall be unlawful for any minor, 16 years of age or younger, to loiter, wander, stroll or play upon the public streets, highways, roads, alleys, parks, playgrounds or other public grounds, public places, public buildings, places of amusement, eating places, vacant lots or any place unsupervised by an adult having the lawful authority to be at such places, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. of any day and 6:00 a.m. of the following day; provided, however, that on Fridays and Saturdays the effective hours are between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. of the following day and, provided that the provisions of this subsection shall not apply in the following instances: (1) When a minor is accompanied by his parent, guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of the minor; (2) When the minor is upon an emergency errand directed by his parent, guardian or other adult person having the lawful care and custody of such minor; (3) When the minor is returning directly home from a school activity, entertainment, recreational activity or dance; (4) When the minor is returning directly home from lawful employment that makes it necessary to be in such places during the prescribed period of time; (5) When the minor is attending or traveling directly to or from an activity involving the exercise of free speech, freedom of assembly or free exercise of religion. (b) It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other person having custody or control of any child 16 years of age or younger to permit or, by insufficient control, to allow such child to be in or upon the public streets or any other places listed in subsection (a) of this section within the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m. on any day and 6:00 a.m. the following day, or on Fridays and Saturdays between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. the following day, except in circumstances set out in subsections (a)(1) through (5) of this section. Upon conviction of a violation of this subsection for the first time, a person shall be given a warning citation. Upon further convictions, a person shall be subject to punishment for a violation of this section. (Code 1982, § 15-3.1) Sec. 62-5. - Parades; permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person or group of persons to assemble and put on or participate in any parade or public demonstration in the city without having first applied to and obtained from the city administrator written permission for such parade or public demonstration, at least 48 hours prior thereto, in accordance with a form approved by the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 15-4) State Law reference— Unlawful assembly, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-33; obstructing highways, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-43; control of mass gatherings, O.C.G.A. § 31-27-1 et seq. Sec. 62-6. - Picketing—Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Picketing means the act of standing upon or patrolling any public street, sidewalk, public property or other public place where persons may lawfully assemble, by one or more persons, whether or not carrying signs or placards, whether the picketing is done in an organized or disorganized manner or is authorized or unauthorized by a responsible party, for the purpose of: (1) Persuading other persons to cease patronizing, contracting with or employing any person or business establishment; (2) Persuading other persons to cease certain employment practices; (3) Calling attention, for any reason whatsoever, to any business practice or other practice followed by the business being picketed; (4) Giving publicity to, or communicating information regarding the existence of facts or merits of, a labor dispute or other controversy of any kind, whether or not labor oriented. (Code 1982, § 15-5) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 62-7. - Picketing—Requirements on public property. Any person engaged in picketing on any public right-of-way or other public property within the city shall adhere to the following requirements: (1) Picketing participants must keep moving at all times; (2) Space between individual participants in picketing shall be at least ten feet and such individuals shall remain in single file at all times; (3) If placards or banners are carried, they must be held so as not to endanger any pedestrian or other person and so as not to interfere with the freedom of movement of any person; (4) No placard or banner shall be used or carried in a threatening or menacing manner; (5) Participants in picketing shall not unreasonably interfere with, or obstruct in any way, pedestrian or vehicular traffic; (6) Participants in picketing shall not block, obstruct or unreasonably interfere in any way with ingress to and egress from any building or structure; (7) The number of participants in picketing shall be limited to such numbers as will not unreasonably obstruct or interfere with pedestrian or vehicular traffic; (8) No pedestrian shall be forced to go into any portion of a street in order to avoid coming in physical contact with participants in picketing; (9) Bystanders shall be restricted to two monitors per business establishment picketed. (Code 1982, § 15-6) State Law reference— Unlawful assembly, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-33; obstructing highways, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-43; picketing, O.C.G.A. § 34-6-2 et seq. Sec. 62-8. - Picketing—Permit not required; notice to police department required. No permit from the city is required for picketing on public rights-of-way or property; however, persons desiring to picket are required to notify the police department of: (1) Their intention to picket; (2) The locations of the picketing; (3) The dates and times of the picketing; and (4) The names, addresses and telephone numbers of at least two local residents designated as agents by the organization sponsoring or encouraging such picketing. (Code 1982, § 15-7) Sec. 62-9. - Picketing—Authority of city attorney. The city attorney is authorized, in his discretion, to file civil action for injunction against any individual or organization failing to observe the requirements of this chapter for picketing. (Code 1982, § 15-8) Cross reference— City attorney, § 2-171 et seq. Sec. 62-10. - Consuming or possessing alcoholic beverage in public place. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to drink any alcoholic beverage in any public building within the city. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or have in his possession an open container of any alcoholic beverage while on any public street, sidewalk, park or other public place within the city, or upon or within any motor vehicle while on the streets, sidewalks, parks and public places of the city. (Code 1982, § 15-9) Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 10; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78. State Law reference— Public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. Sec. 62-11. - Disorderly conduct. It shall be unlawful for any person to fight, be guilty of any riotous or disorderly conduct, or disturb the peace and quiet of any person in any other manner within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1982, § 15-10) Sec. 62-12. - Social hosting. (a) Findings and intent. The mayor and city council finds and declares as follows: (1) In 2007, the U.S. Surgeon General issued a report entitled "The Surgeon General's Call to Action to Prevent and Reduce Underage Drinking," which can be found at http:/www.surgeongeneral.gov/topics/underagedrinking/calltoaction.pdf. (Surgeon General's Call to Action.) (2) "Early alcohol consumption by some young people will result in an alcohol use disorder-that is, they will meet diagnostic criteria for either alcohol abuse or dependence." (Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page 4.) (3) "A higher percentage of youth in 8th, 10th and 12th grades used alcohol in the month prior to being surveyed than used tobacco or marijuana, the illicit drug most commonly used by adolescents." (Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page 5.) (4) Various surveys have found that: approximately ten percent of children who are nine to ten years old have started drinking alcoholic beverages; nearly 33 percent of youth start drinking alcoholic beverages before the age of 13; more than ten percent of youth who are 12 to 13 years old and over 33 percent of youth who are 14 to 15 years old reported drinking a whole alcoholic beverage in the year before they were surveyed, and the peak years of alcohol initiation are when youth are in 7th and 8th grades. (Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page 6.) (5) While adolescents typically drink alcohol beverages less often than adults, when they do drink alcohol beverages, adolescents tend to drink more alcoholic beverages at each event than adults. (Surgeon General's Call to Action, at pages 6-7.) (6) Persons who are less than the age of 21 often possess or consume alcoholic beverages at social parties or gatherings held at or on property under control of a person who either has provided the alcoholic beverages or who knows or reasonably should know of such conduct, but fails to take steps to prevent it. (7) "Annually, about 5,000 people under age 21 die from alcohol-related injuries involving underage drinking." (Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page 10.) (8) Underage drinking "plays a significant role in risky sexual behavior, including unwanted, unintended and unprotected sexual activity, and sex with multiple partners. Such behavior increases the risk of unplanned pregnancy and for contracting sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including infection with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS." (Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page 10.) (9) Underage drinking "increases the risk of physical and sexual assault." (Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page 10.) (10) Underage drinking "can cause a range of physical consequences, from hangovers to death from alcohol poisoning." (Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page 11.) (11) Underage drinking "can cause alterations in the structure and function of the developing brain, which continues to mature into the mid to late twenties and may have consequences reaching far beyond adolescence." (Surgeon General's Cal to Action, at page 11.) (12) Underage drinking "causes secondhand effects that can put others at risk. Loud and unruly behavior, property destruction, unintentional injuries, violence, and even death because of underage alcohol use afflict innocent parties. For instance, about 45 percent of people who die in car crashes involving a drinking driver under the age of 21 are people other than the driver." (Surgeon General's Call to Action, at page 11.) (13) There is concern about underage persons obtaining and consuming alcoholic beverages at functions under the control of adults who know or should know of such conduct but fail to stop it. (14) This body finds that adults who knowingly allow underage drinking on property they control should be held responsible and accountable. (15) Too frequently, adults who are aware that underage drinking is illegal allow underage drinking at property they control knowing that they are not breaking the law so long as they don't directly provide the alcohol to minors. This body finds that this is a gap in the current laws that must be eliminated. (16) Law enforcement agency responses to disturbances involving underage consumption of alcoholic beverages at parties or gatherings at or on private residences or other private property frequently require the use of extensive public resources. Further, when law enforcement personnel respond to such disturbances it limits their ability to respond to other service calls in the community, thereby placing the community at increased risk. Law enforcement is not currently reimbursed for their expenses when called to a party or gathering at or on private residence or other private property. (17) The prohibitions found in this section are reasonable and expected to deter the possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages by persons under the age of 21 by holding responsible persons who encourage, are aware of, or should be aware of the illegal conduct, yet fail to take steps to prevent it. In addition, the revenue received, after cost reimbursement to the responding law enforcement agency, will be directed toward law enforcement strategies and prevention programs. (b) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dwelling unit means, without limitations, any of the following: (1) Any single and multifamily residence, including, but not limited to, any apartment, cabin, condominium, duplex, house, or log cabin, and the land on which it is located, whether owned, leased, rented, or occupied for no compensation by the occupants; (2) Any mobile home and the land upon which the mobile home is located, whether or not rent is paid for the mobile home, for the land upon which the mobile home is located, or for both; (3) Any recreational vehicle, whether located on privately-owned or publicly-owned property, and whether or not rent is paid for the recreational vehicle, and the land upon which the recreational vehicle is located. Event means a gathering at which five or more persons assemble or gather for a social occasion or activity. Gathering means an assembled group of people for any occasion or activity. Legal guardian is a person who is lawfully vested with the power and charged with the duty of taking care of an underage person. Other property includes, but is not limited to, the following locations: (1) A hotel or motel room; (2) An assembly hall or meeting room; (3) A common room of a dwelling unit used for a party (e.g., a recreation room of an apartment building or common room of a condominium complex); (4) A site in a campground; (5) A vacant lot; (6) Land or real estate of any type; or (7) Any type of watercraft. Parent means any person who is a natural parent, an adoptive parent, a foster parent, a step-parent, or a person who stands in loco parentis. Party means a gathering or event at which two or more persons assemble or gather for a social occasion or activity. Person has a right of possession if the person is: (1) The owner of the dwelling unit, private resident, or other property; (2) The record owner of the title to the property at the time of the party or gathering regardless of where that person currently resides; (3) A tenant or lessee of the dwelling unit, private residence, or other property; (4) A landlord of another person who has a right of possession in the dwelling unit, private residence, or other property; or (5) The persons who are in charge of the dwelling unit, private residence, or other property. Private residence means the following: (1) A dwelling unit, whether occupied on a temporary basis, whether occupied as a dwelling or for a party or other social function, and whether owned, leased, rented, or used with or without compensation; (2) Any other item on the same land parcel as the dwelling unit, which includes, but is not limited to, any of the following: an animal pen, an animal shed, a barn, a boat dock, a boat house, a cabana, an equipment shed, a free-standing office, a garage, a gazebo, a granary, a hot tub, a hunting cabin, a corn crib, a sauna, a stable, a studio, a swimming pool, a private office, a shed, a silo, a tent, a tool shed, a tree-house, a tractor, or a vehicle of any type or nature; (3) Other items or areas accompanying or on the same land parcel as the dwelling unit, whether improved or unimproved, such as a yard (whether fenced or unfenced), patio, outdoor grilling or eating area, open fields, jetty, pier, dock, or lake shore; (4) Water bodies contiguous to or on the same land parcel as a dwelling unit such as a basin, bayou, brook, creek, dam, lagoon, lake, marsh, pond, river, stream or swamp. Reasonable steps means steps that include, but are not limited to, the following: (1) Controlling access to alcoholic beverages; (2) Controlling the quantity of alcoholic beverages; (3) Ensuring that no one at the party or gathering that is consuming or possessing any alcoholic beverage is underage and verifying the legal minimum drinking age of any person at the party or gathering who appears could be underage by inspecting drivers licenses or other government-issued identification cards. (Res. No. 16-0621-37, 7-21-2016)

div.head: Chapter 66 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; standing in street to hitchhike or solicit, § 86-9. State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq.
Sec. 66-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Peddler includes all peddlers, solicitors, hawkers, canvassers, itinerant merchants and transient vendors of merchandise. (Code 1982, § 14-60) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 66-2. - Registration and card required. It shall be unlawful for any person to go from house to house or from place to place in the city soliciting, selling or taking orders for goods, wares, merchandise or services, including insurance contracts, subscriptions to magazines or newspapers, to expose plates or films to make negatives, to make pictures or photographs for future delivery, or any articles for future delivery unless such peddler shall first have registered with the chief of police and shall have applied for and received from the chief of police a registration card showing such registration. (Code 1982, § 14-61) Sec. 66-3. - Registration card applications; fees; exemptions; fingerprinting. (a) Any person desiring a registration card as required by section 66-2 shall file an application with the chief of police. Such application shall give: (1) The applicant's full name and home address; (2) The name of the last three municipalities in which the applicant worked, if any; (3) The name of the company or individual such applicant represents or works for, if any; (4) The merchandise, services or products to be sold, disposed of, peddled or hawked by the applicant; (5) Two recent photographs of the applicant; and (6) If the applicant represents another individual or company, the applicant must present to the chief of police satisfactory proof of authority to represent such company or individual. (b) The application shall be accompanied by a fee as set by the mayor and city council to help defray the expense of investigation. (c) Persons offering for sale agricultural products, meats, poultry or other articles of food grown or produced by such persons or civic, educational or religious organizations shall not be required to pay the fees required by subsection (b) of this section, but the registration card required hereby shall be issued to such persons by the chief of police upon satisfactory proof that they have produced or grown the products to be peddled or that the purpose for peddling any property is for civic, educational or religious purposes and such card shall so state. (d) At the time of making application for the registration card, the applicant shall submit to, and be fingerprinted by, the chief of police. Such fingerprints shall be kept as a permanent record in the office of the chief of police. (Code 1982, § 14-62) Sec. 66-4. - Registration card issuance, contents, expiration and display. (a) No registration card shall be issued until the applicant shall have complied with all of the provisions and requirements of this chapter. (b) When such registration card is issued, it shall be signed by the city clerk; be dated as of the date of its issuance; and be void after three months from the date of its issuance. Any card not dated and signed as required in this subsection, or which is issued in violation of this section, shall be void. (c) Every peddler shall display such registration card on such his person by means of a cellophane badge at all times while such person is engaged in such business. (Code 1982, § 14-63) Sec. 66-5. - Reregistration after expiration of registration card. (a) After the expiration of a registration card, subsequent registration cards may be obtained by re-registering with the chief of police and applying for such subsequent registration card, and in all other respects complying with the provisions of this chapter. Any peddler may reregister and apply for subsequent registration cards as often as desired. (b) The chief of police shall issue a subsequent registration card to each applicant within 48 hours after such applicant has complied with all requirements for such reregistration as prescribed in this section. Such subsequent card shall be similar to the original card, except the date thereof. (Code 1982, § 14-64) Sec. 66-6. - Compliance with registration provisions prerequisite to engaging in business. All peddlers must comply with the registration provisions of this chapter at least 48 hours prior to going in or upon any private residence within the city for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of magazines, goods, wares, services or merchandise of any kind or character, and/or for the purpose of disposing of and/or peddling and/or hawking such services or merchandise, to expose plates or films to make negatives, and make pictures or photographs for future delivery, unless requested or invited to do so by the owner or occupant thereof. (Code 1982, § 14-65) Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22. Sec. 66-7. - Restriction of sale in public places. (a) It shall be unlawful for any article of any kind or nature whatsoever to be sold or offered for sale from vehicles, conveyances, boxes, stands or other containers while standing or located on the streets, sidewalks or public places of the city, without the express written permission of the mayor and city council. (b) The provisions of this section shall not apply to sales made by any business holding an occupational license on the sidewalk adjacent to its business premises, or to any vendor holding a valid contract with the Georgia Peach Festival, Inc. (Code 1982, § 14-67) Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78. State Law reference— Obstructing highways, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-43. Sec. 66-8. - Sales on private property. Articles may be sold from vehicles, conveyances, boxes or otherwise while located on private premises, but not until and unless the person offering such articles for sale has first secured the written consent of the owner of such premises to sell such articles thereon, and has paid for and secured from the city clerk the regular license to conduct such business within the city, and with the express written permission of the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 14-68) Sec. 66-9. - Time of sales restricted. Under no circumstances shall any person canvass or peddle any article whatsoever within the city prior to 9:00 a.m. and after 9:00 p.m. of any day. (Code 1982, § 14-69)

div.head: Chapter 70 - PERSONNEL[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; law enforcement, ch. 54. State Constitution reference— Retirement or pension systems, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III. State Law reference— Compensation and benefits for municipal employees, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-4; residence of municipal employees, O.C.G.A. § 45-2-5 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 70-1. - Personnel policy and program. The city personnel policy and program, as amended from time to time, is on file in the office of the city clerk. (Code 1982, § 17-1) Secs. 70-2—70-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - RETIREMENT[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— An ordinance adopted on September 20, 1990, § 1, provides as follows: Section 1. An ordinance approved September 26, 1974, as amended, establishing a retirement plan for the employees of the City of Fort Valley, Georgia, and setting forth the joint trust agreement and the contract for the administration of such plan by the city and the Georgia Municipal Employees Benefit System as provided by O.C.G.A. § 47-5-1 et seq., is hereby amended by striking in their entirety articles I—XV of the plan and articles I—XI of the joint trust agreement, and substituting in lieu thereof the following new articles I—XVI of the plan and articles I—XIII of the joint trust agreement. Articles I—XVI of the plan and articles I—XIII of the joint trust agreement referenced above are not set out at length herein, but are on file and available for inspection in the city administrator's office.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 70-31—70-50. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - SOCIAL SECURITY
Sec. 70-51. - Old age and survivors insurance benefits. (a) Policy and purpose. It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend at the earliest date possible, under the agreement entered into by the state and the Federal Social Security Administration, to the employees and officials thereof, and its instrumentalities, not excluded by law or by this section, the benefits of the system of old age and survivors insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act, the state enabling act (O.C.G.A. § 47-18-1 et seq.), and amendments thereto. In pursuance of such policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (b) Authority to execute agreements, etc. The mayor or other chief executive officer of the city is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia for coverage of the employees and officials as provided for in subsection (a) of this section, to include any employees that are in positions covered by a public retirement system, in the manner provided by such law, namely, the joint municipal employees retirement system. (c) Withholdings authorized; disposition. Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided for in subsection (a) of this section are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency. (d) Appropriations from general funds. There shall be appropriated from general funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employer's contributions and administrative expenses, and such funds shall be paid over to the Employees' Retirement System of Georgia in accordance with regulations established by such agency. (e) Records and reports. The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (f) Exclusions. There is hereby excluded from this section any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position or any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. (Code 1982, § 17-26)

div.head: Chapter 74 - PLANNING[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Zoning and planning authority, § 41A. Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; environment, ch. 38; historic preservation, ch. 50; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; utilities, ch. 90; subdivisions, app. A; zoning, app. B. State Constitution reference— Adoption of local plans authorized, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ IV. State Law reference— Redevelopment Law, O.C.G.A. § 8-4-1 et seq.; redevelopment, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-1 et seq.; development authorities, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.; coordinated and comprehensive local planning, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.; development impact fees, O.C.G.A. § 36-71-1 et seq.; regional development centers, O.C.G.A. § 50-8-30 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 74-1—74-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Charter reference— Zoning and planning, § 41A. Cross reference— Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-201 et seq.
Sec. 74-31. - Created and established. The city planning commission is hereby created and established as authorized by the City Charter, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ IV and the General Planning and Zoning Enabling Act of 1957 (1957 Ga. Laws, page 420), as amended. (Code 1982, § 18-1) Editor's note— The statute cited above, though repealed, is referred to in O.C.G.A. § 34-9-4. Sec. 74-32. - Membership; terms; compensation. The planning commission shall consist of six members, who shall be residents of the city, appointed by the mayor and city council. The terms of the members shall be for five years. Any vacancy in membership shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor and city council, which shall also have the authority to remove any member for cause, on written charges, after a public hearing. All members shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in connection with their official duties. (Code 1982, § 18-2) Sec. 74-33. - Officers; rules; meetings; expenditures. (a) The planning commission shall elect its chairperson from among its members. The term of the chairperson shall be one year, with eligibility for reelection. The planning commission shall appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or employee of the municipality. The planning commission shall make its own rules of procedure and determine its meeting time. (b) All meetings of the planning commission at which official action is taken shall be open to the public as provided by law, and all records of the planning commission shall be a public record. (c) The planning commission may appoint such employees and staff as it may deem necessary for its work, and may contract with the state planning agency, city planners and other consultants for such services as it may require. (d) The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for such purpose by the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 18-3) Sec. 74-34. - Powers and duties. The planning commission shall review all proposed zoning decisions, and shall make such recommendations to the mayor and city council regarding any proposed zoning decision as it may deem appropriate. Such recommendations shall have advisory effect only and shall not be binding upon the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 18-4) Sec. 74-35. - Standards for recommendations. The planning commission shall utilize the same standards as those set forth in appendix B, section 126 to this Code in making its recommendations. (Code 1982, § 18-5) Secs. 74-36—74-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - MIDDLE GEORGIA REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT CENTER
Sec. 74-71. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Center means the Middle Georgia Regional Development Center. (Code 1982, § 18-20) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 74-72. - Created and established.
