The mayor and city council, jointly with the governing authorities of other area municipalities and counties, in order to guide the planning for the total development of the city and the middle Georgia area, which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote the public health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, hereby creates and establishes the Middle Georgia Regional Development Center, as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 58-8-30 et seq. The center shall be organized and empowered as provided in this article. (Code 1982, § 18-20) Sec. 74-73. - Membership. The center, by bylaw, shall provide for its membership and for the selection of center representatives by the member governments, subject to the requirements and limitations of this article and applicable state law. Center members shall serve without compensation. (Code 1982, § 18-21) Sec. 74-74. - Organization. The center is hereby authorized to elect its officers and manage its affairs in accordance with its bylaws, subject to the requirements and limitations of this article and applicable state law. (Code 1982, § 18-22) Sec. 74-75. - Powers and duties. The center shall be a public agency as defined, and with all of the powers, duties and obligations set forth in O.C.G.A. § 50-8-30 et seq., and the center shall also have all the powers, duties and obligations of a joint planning commission set forth in any law of general application pertaining to joint planning commissions and regional development centers. (Code 1982, § 18-23) Sec. 74-76. - Advisory body. The center shall act in an advisory capacity, and any plan, or part thereof, or amendment, extension or addition thereto, adopted by the center shall constitute a recommendation. (Code 1982, § 18-24) Sec. 74-77. - Effect on other planning bodies. The passage of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall in no way affect the present or future powers and duties granted to any existing local planning and zoning commission and shall in no way affect the future creation of any local planning and zoning commission and any future amendments related thereto. (Code 1982, § 18-25) Sec. 74-78. - Bylaws. The initial bylaws of the center are attached to an ordinance enacted on February 15, 1973, and the bylaws of the center, as they exist on the effective date of this Code, are hereby approved and consented to. (Code 1982, § 18-26)

div.head: Chapter 78 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Streets, sidewalks, etc., § 25 et seq. Cross reference— Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, closing, paving, widening, vacating, or establishing the grade of any street or public way in the city, or establishing lines for building setback therefrom saved from repeal, § 1-7(7); any ordinance providing for local improvements or assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-7(9); buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; property numbering system, § 18-251 et seq.; cemeteries, ch. 26; environment, ch. 38; library, ch. 58; consuming or possessing alcoholic beverage in public place, § 62-10; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 66; restriction of sale in public places, § 66-7; planning, ch. 74; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86; obstruction of traffic by use of streets, § 86-8; standing in street to hitchhike or solicit, § 86-9; shrubbery and other hazards at street corners; duty of property owner, § 86-10; damaging streets, § 86-105; utilities, ch. 90; vehicles for hire, ch. 94; subdivisions, app. A; design standards for streets in subdivisions, app. A, art. II, § A; street access, app. B, § 62; zoning, app. B; classification of streets, app. B, § 63. State Constitution reference— Street construction and maintenance, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III. State Law reference— Obstruction of streets, sidewalks, etc., O.C.G.A. §§ 16-11-43, 32-6-1, 36-30-10; eminent domain, O.C.G.A. tit. 22; highways, bridges and ferries, O.C.G.A. tit. 32; municipal street systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; subdivisions abutting on state highways, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-150 et seq.; franchises in streets, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-2(7); streets and sidewalks, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; street and sidewalk improvements, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-1 et seq.; grants for public purposes, O.C.G.A. § 36-40-20 et seq.
Sec. 78-1. - Street and sidewalk improvement regulation adopted. There is hereby adopted by the city for the purpose of providing, making, establishing and regulating street and sidewalk improvements, the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-39-1 et seq., being 1927 Ga. Laws, page 321, as amended. The provisions thereof shall be controlling within the city; provided, however, that should the provisions thereof conflict with any provisions of this Code, then the more restrictive provisions shall be deemed controlling. (Code 1982, § 20-1) Charter reference— Street and sidewalk improvements generally, § 25 et seq. Sec. 78-2. - Excavations—Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person, except the city, to make any cut or excavation in any city street or sidewalk, without first obtaining a permit from the superintendent of public works. (Code 1982, § 20-2) Sec. 78-3. - Excavations—Form of application and permit. (a) Any person desiring to cut or make any excavation in any street or paved sidewalk in the city or otherwise affect the right-of-way along any street or sidewalk for the purpose of constructing, installing, operating, maintaining or making connections with any public utility or public utility apparatus, must secure approval from the public works department prior to initiating any such action. (b) Approval for such work may be gained by completion of an application and permit form, which shall be supplied by the public works department, and which shall be approved by the director of public works or his designee. (c) The director of public works is authorized to set standards for any work or act covered by this section. (d) The fee for the application and permit shall be as set by the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 20-3; Ord. of 2-17-2000) Sec. 78-4. - Excavations—Responsibility of excavator. Any person who shall obtain an excavation permit required by section 78-2 shall thereby assume full responsibility for any loss or damage to the city or any person as a result of such excavation or other acts of negligence, and shall indemnify the city against any loss resulting from any damage to either person or the property of any person, and any such permit shall contain such provision. (Code 1982, § 20-4) Sec. 78-5. - Excavations—Refilling and repairing. It shall be unlawful for any person, after having made an excavation in any street, to refill the excavation, except under the immediate supervision and direction of the superintendent of public works. The cost of restoring any such excavated street to its former condition shall be paid by the person making or causing such excavation. (Code 1982, § 20-5) Sec. 78-6. - Excavations—Safety precautions. It shall be the duty of the person making any excavation in any public street or place to maintain a signal at the place of excavation by keeping an amber light burning at the excavation site from sundown to sunrise and a red flag during the day, and to place or construct a railing or barricade next to such excavation. (Code 1982, § 20-6) Sec. 78-7. - Obstruction of streets and sidewalks. It shall be unlawful for any person to place on any street or sidewalk any shavings, refuse, materials or any other obstructions tending to prevent free passage. (Code 1982, § 20-7) Sec. 78-8. - Location of poles and posts. All posts or poles for electric wires, telephone, telegraph or other purposes shall be placed on the edge of sidewalks on the curbing line so as not to damage trees or obstruct passage on the sidewalks or streets, or interfere with working or draining the streets. (Code 1982, § 20-8) Sec. 78-9. - Conveyance of alleyways to adjoining landowners. The conveyance of property occupied by alleyways to adjoining landowners in equal portion is hereby authorized on the following conditions: (1) All adjoining landowners along the full length of the alleyway agree to such conveyance; (2) The adjoining landowners pay all costs and legal fees in connection with such conveyance; (3) The city reserve an easement for utility purposes across the lands. (Code 1982, § 20-9)

div.head: Chapter 82 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Ad valorem taxes generally, § 21; tax assessors, § 24; collection of taxes, fees, etc., by execution, § 31. Cross reference— Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds for the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city saved from repeal, § 1-7(2); any ordinance not inconsistent with this Code levying, imposing or providing for collection of any tax saved from repeal, § 1-7(13); administration, ch. 2; finance, § 2-251 et seq.; tax records inquiries; preliminary approval required; furnishing data; additional requirements; period of processing, 10-7; excise tax levied and imposed; reports; payment, § 10-64; excise tax in addition to other taxes, § 10-65; tax imposed and levied on wine, § 10-102; payment of tax for alcoholic beverages, § 10-103; failure to pay or remit taxes, § 10-104; businesses, ch. 22; business license tax levied, § 22-162. State Constitution reference— Taxation power of municipal governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV. State Law reference— Local taxation of insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1 et seq.; uniform property tax administration and equalization, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-260 et seq.; municipal taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.; uniform valuation for local property taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-352; administration of local taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-380 et seq.; tax for maintaining independent school systems, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-405; franchises, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-420 et seq.; local taxation of rooms, lodgings or accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq.
Sec. 82-1. - Tax rate established annually. In accordance with state law, the mayor and city council shall establish the ad valorem mill rate for the succeeding fiscal year, computed in the manner provided in the Georgia Public Revenue Code (O.C.G.A. tit. 48). (Code 1982, § 19-1) State Law reference— Municipal ad valorem taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq. Sec. 82-2. - When taxes payable; publication of notice. All taxes due the city shall be payable as provided by state law. Ten days before the time of payment of such taxes, the city shall publish once a notice thereof in a newspaper published in the city. (Code 1982, § 19-2) Sec. 82-3. - Issuance of execution on assessments for which taxes have not been paid. In accordance with state law, the city clerk shall issue executions on all assessments upon which taxes have not been paid. (Code 1982, § 19-4) Charter reference— Collection of taxes, fees, etc., by execution, § 31. State Law reference— Garnishment to collect taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-360. Sec. 82-4. - Execution procedure. All executions of the city shall be issued as provided in sections 31 and 37 of the Charter, and shall be made returnable to the second regular meeting of the mayor and city council after the issuance thereof. Whenever any property is levied on under any execution issued by authority of the city, the procedure therefor shall be the same as that followed in sheriff's sales for state and county taxes, except that the officer making the levy may advertise the sale in any newspaper published in the city, and the sale may be conducted by the city marshal before the front door of the city hall and, provided further, where the property levied on is personalty, the sale shall be advertised by posting a notice at the door of the city hall and at two other places in the city ten days before the sale. (Code 1982, § 19-5) Sec. 82-5. - Collection of back taxes. Whenever any property subject to taxation has not been returned for taxation or assessed in any year prior to the then present year and no taxes have been paid thereon for such prior year, the tax assessor shall proceed as provided in O.C.G.A. tit. 48. (Code 1982, § 19-6) Sec. 82-6. - Back taxes where no prior executions have been issued. If tax returns on assessments have been made for any prior years and no taxes have been paid and no executions issued thereon, the city clerk shall give the owner of the property 30 days' notice that execution will be issued, and if the amount of the taxes thereon is not paid in such 30-day period, then execution shall issue and be collected as provided for other taxes. (Code 1982, § 19-7) Sec. 82-7. - City-county local sales and use tax levied. A combination city-county local sales and use tax, at the rate of one percent, is hereby levied by the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 14-11) State Law reference— Joint county and municipal sales and use tax, O.C.G.A. § 48-8-80 et seq. Sec. 82-8. - Procedure for property subject to taxation without prior year assessments. Whenever any property subject to taxation has not been returned for taxation or assessed in any year prior to the then present year and no taxes paid thereon for such prior year, the tax collector shall be authorized to use the judicial in rem tax foreclosure procedure provided for in O.C.G.A. § 48-4-76 et seq. for enforcement of tax liens. (Res. No. 10-1216-65, 12-16-2010)

div.head: Chapter 86 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Any ordinance prescribing traffic regulations of specific locations, prescribing through streets, parking limitations, parking prohibitions, one-way traffic, or limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones, not inconsistent with this Code saved from repeal, § 1-7(14); courts, ch. 34; law enforcement, ch. 54; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; vehicles for hire, ch. 94. State Law reference— Removal of junked motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4; motor vehicles and traffic, O.C.G.A. tit. 40; drivers' licenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-5-1 et seq.; restoration of drivers' licenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-5-80 et seq.; Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; powers of local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370 et seq.; equipment and inspection of motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-1 et seq.; Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act, O.C.G.A. § 40-9-1 et seq.; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq.; authority of municipal courts to try cases involving state traffic laws, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-21.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 86-1. - State laws adopted; application; penalties; amendment or repeal. (a) Adoption. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1 through 40-6-397 of that chapter, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited in this subsection. (b) Application. The provisions of this chapter relating to the operation of vehicles refer to the operation of vehicles upon highways or streets of the city, and as follows: (1) Except where a different place is specifically referred to in a given section. (2) The provisions of this section shall apply to a vehicle operated at shopping centers or parking lots or similar areas which, although privately owned, are customarily used by the public as a through street or connector street. (3) The provisions relating to reckless driving and driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquors or drugs shall apply to vehicles operated upon highways or streets and elsewhere throughout the city. (c) Violations of section; penalties. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. (d) Amendment or repeal. A future amendment or repeal of any provision of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq., Uniform Rules of the Road, shall amend or repeal the pertinent provision of this section. (Code 1982, § 21-1) Sec. 86-2. - Boarding and alighting from vehicles—Generally. Persons entering or leaving a vehicle shall do so on the side nearest the curb. (Code 1982, § 21-2) Sec. 86-3. - Boarding and alighting from vehicles—Vehicles discharging passengers. Any passenger vehicle, consisting of any sort of vehicle conveying passengers for compensation or otherwise, shall, before discharging passengers, drive as near to the right-hand curb of the street as possible to allow passengers to alight from such passenger vehicle at or as near the curb of the street as possible and in such area that it will be impossible for any meeting or following vehicle to pass between such passenger vehicle discharging passengers and the right-hand curb on the street. (Code 1982, § 21-3) Sec. 86-4. - Boarding and alighting from vehicles—Vehicles in motion. No person shall board or alight from any vehicle while such vehicle is in motion, except that railway workers in the course of their employment in switching or otherwise operating or controlling cars on rails may do so. (Code 1982, § 21-4) Sec. 86-5. - Riding on portions of vehicles not intended for passengers. No person shall ride on any portion of any vehicle not designed or intended for the use of passengers. Such prohibition shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to persons riding in truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. (Code 1982, § 21-5) Sec. 86-6. - Improperly loaded vehicles. No driver shall operate upon any street in the city a vehicle which is overloaded, or which is loaded in such a manner that articles or freight on the vehicle is likely to fall therefrom, or which is so loaded that the brakes of such vehicle will not stop the vehicle within the distances specified by law when the brakes are properly applied. (Code 1982, § 21-6) Sec. 86-7. - Passengers on motor scooters and motorbikes. It shall be unlawful for more than one person to ride upon a motor scooter or motorbike. Upon a violation of this section, both the operator and passenger shall be guilty of such violation. (Code 1982, § 21-7) Sec. 86-8. - Obstruction of traffic by use of streets. No person shall occupy or use any street, lane, alley or way so as to interfere with or interrupt the usage thereof by other vehicles. (Code 1982, § 21-8) Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78. State Law reference— Obstruction of highways, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-43. Sec. 86-9. - Standing in street to hitchhike or solicit. (a) No person shall stand in the street for the purpose of soliciting a ride. (b) No person shall stand on a street for the purpose of soliciting employment, business or contributions from the occupant of any vehicle. (Code 1982, § 21-9) Cross reference— Peddlers and soliciting, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78. Sec. 86-10. - Shrubbery and other hazards at street corners; duty of property owner. It shall be the duty of every property owner to keep weeds as well as shrubbery on their respective lots in such a condition as not to create traffic hazards at street corners. Shrubbery, vines, trees or other things which would obstruct the view of a person passing a street corner or street intersection shall be kept in a condition so as not to obstruct the view of motorists using the streets. (Code 1982, § 21-10) Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78. Sec. 86-11. - Truck routes. The driver of a motor truck of a tractor-trailer type or of a weight of 2½ tons or more shall not drive such vehicle on any of the streets in the city other than the streets designated by an official sign indicating and designating such streets as truck routes; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to trucks engaged in delivery of personal property to customers at specific locations within the city. (Code 1982, § 21-10) Sec. 86-12. - Jake brake prohibited. The use of exhaust brakes, exhaust retarders and Jake brake usage is prohibited. It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle equipped with an engine speed governor, also known as a Jake brake, to use or otherwise apply such device within the city. Any violation of this article shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00. (Res. No. 10-0218-12, 2-18-2010) Secs. 86-13—86-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] Footnotes: --- (2) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 86-41. - Responsibility for operation of vehicles. It shall be unlawful for the owner or any other person employing or otherwise directing the driver of any vehicle to require or knowingly permit the operation of such vehicle upon a street or highway in any manner contrary to this chapter. (Code 1982, § 21-20) Sec. 86-42. - Duties and authority of police officers. (a) It shall be the duty of the police officers on traffic duty at intersections or heavily congested traffic zones to direct traffic so as to expedite such traffic and, to this end, it shall be the duty of police officers, where it can be safely done, to direct traffic through intersections controlled by traffic signal lights without regard to the signal light, so that when a red traffic signal light is holding traffic at a street intersection the traffic shall be released and directed to move forward when there is little or no traffic at or approaching such intersection on a green light; and in extremely heavily congested areas such police officer shall have the power and authority to direct traffic without regard to such automatic traffic signal light, even though there is substantial traffic on both or all of such intersecting streets at or near and approaching such intersection. (b) The object and purpose of this section is to eliminate traffic bottlenecks caused by red lights facing heavy traffic while a green light on the intersecting street is of no benefit or of small benefit because of the light traffic on such intersecting street. (Code 1982, § 21-21) Cross reference— Law enforcement, ch. 54. State Law reference— Authority to arrest for traffic violation, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-30. Sec. 86-43. - Temporary regulations. The chief of police may establish temporary traffic regulations which the public must obey after being warned. Verbal warning by an authorized police officer of the city, or by printed signs erected in the area affected, shall constitute sufficient notice to the public of all temporary traffic regulations. (Code 1982, § 21-22) State Law reference— Temporary or experimental regulations authorized, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(19). Secs. 86-44—86-60. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ACCIDENTS
Sec. 86-61. - Death and personal injuries. The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to, or death of, any person shall immediately stop such vehicle at the scene of such accident or as close thereto as possible, in which latter case such driver shall then forthwith return to, and in every event shall remain at, the scene of the accident until such driver has fulfilled the requirements set forth in section 86-63. Every such stop shall be made without obstructing traffic more than is necessary. (Code 1982, § 21-30) Sec. 86-62. - Damage to vehicle. The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting only in damage to a vehicle which is driven or attended by any person shall immediately stop such vehicle at the scene of such accident or as close thereto as possible, in which latter case such driver shall forthwith return to, and in every event shall remain at, the scene of such accident until such driver has fulfilled the requirements of section 86-63. Every such stop shall be made without obstructing traffic more than is necessary. (Code 1982, § 21-31) Sec. 86-63. - Duty to give information and render aid. The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to, or death of, any person or damage to any vehicle which is driven or attended by any person shall give such driver's name and address and the registration number of the vehicle such person is driving and shall, upon request, and if available, exhibit such driver's or operator's license to the person struck or the driver or occupant of, or person attending, any vehicle collided with, and shall render to any person injured in such accident reasonable assistance, including the transporting, or making arrangements for the transporting, of such person to a physician, surgeon or hospital for medical or surgical treatment, if it is apparent that such treatment is necessary or if such transporting is requested by the injured person. (Code 1982, § 21-32) Sec. 86-64. - Striking unattended vehicle; duty of driver. The driver of any vehicle which collides with any vehicle which is unattended shall immediately stop and shall, then and there, either locate and notify the operator or owner of such vehicle of the name and address of the driver and owner of the vehicle striking the unattended vehicle, or shall leave in a conspicuous place on the vehicle struck a written notice giving the name and address of the driver and of the owner of the vehicle striking the unattended vehicle. (Code 1982, § 21-33) Sec. 86-65. - Striking fixtures; duty of driver. The driver of any vehicle involved in an accident resulting only in damage to a fixture legally upon or adjacent to a street or highway shall take reasonable steps to locate and notify the owner or person in charge of such property of such fact and of such driver's name and address and of the registration number of the vehicle such driver is driving, and shall, upon request, and if available, exhibit such driver's or operator's license. (Code 1982, § 21-34) Sec. 86-66. - Accident report to be given to police. The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident occurring within the city resulting in injury to, or death of, any person or property damage to an apparent extent of $500.00 or more shall immediately give notice to the police department of such accident by the quickest means of communication. (Code 1982, § 21-35) Cross reference— Law enforcement, ch. 54. State Law reference— Accident reports, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-273 et seq. Sec. 86-67. - Interfering with property involved in accidents. It shall be unlawful to change, alter, carry away or interfere in any manner with any property or thing involved in any vehicle accident within the city referred to in section 86-66 until a police officer of the city shall have investigated such accident. (Code 1982, § 21-36) Secs. 86-68—86-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES
Sec. 86-101. - Physically unfit persons. No person shall operate any vehicle while such person is physically unfit to operate the vehicle in a reasonably safe manner. (Code 1982, § 21-40) Sec. 86-102. - Speed zones established. The following speed zones are established: _____ (1) Off System.
(2) On System. SR-7 (Martin Luther King JR Drive/U.S. Highway 341).
(3) On System. SR-7 Connector (Oakland Heights).
(4) On System. SR-96 (Orange Street, Vineville Street, Commercial Heights, and East Church Street).
(Code 1982, § 21-41; Res. No. 09-0820-50, att. A, 8-20-2009) State Law reference— Municipal authority to increase or reduce maximum speed limits, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-183, 40-6-371(a)(5), (10), (14). _____ Sec. 86-103. - Towing another vehicle. No vehicle shall pull more than one other vehicle, and the connection between such vehicles shall not exceed 16 feet. (Code 1982, § 21-42) Sec. 86-104. - U-turns. The driver of any vehicle shall not turn such vehicle in order to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street in a business district or any street between intersections. (Code 1982, § 21-43) Sec. 86-105. - Damaging streets. No vehicle shall be operated in such a manner as to damage the streets. (Code 1982, § 21-44) Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78. Sec. 86-106. - Vehicles discharging passengers. When any passenger vehicle is discharging passengers, other vehicles following or meeting such passenger vehicle may pass such vehicle discharging passengers only on the left side of such passenger vehicle discharging passengers, and shall pass the passenger vehicle discharging passengers at such moderate and reasonable speed that the driver of such passenger vehicle may stop the vehicle immediately if any passenger discharged from such passenger vehicle discharging passengers attempts to go around such passenger vehicle to the opposite side of the street by going around the front of such passenger vehicle discharging such person or by going around behind such passenger vehicle in which he has been riding so that no person discharged from any passenger vehicle will be negligently run down, run over or injured by any other vehicle passing, approaching or following the vehicle discharging such passengers. (Code 1982, § 21-45) Sec. 86-107. - Designation of stop intersections. The mayor and city council or the police committee may from time to time designate intersections or other places at which vehicles on a certain street shall be required to stop and yield the right-of-way to other vehicles or pedestrians. Whenever any such intersection is designated as a stop intersection, the chief of police shall cause suitable signs, signals or markings giving notice thereof to be erected and maintained, and it shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with any such sign, signal or marking. (Code 1982, § 21-47) Secs. 86-108—86-140. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Charter reference— Power to provide off-street parking facilities, § 2. Cross reference— Off-street automobile parking and storage, app. B, § 65; off-street loading and unloading space, app. B, § 66. State Law reference— Municipal authority to regulate parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371.
Sec. 86-141. - Illegal parking; enforcement of regulations. (a) Attachment of notice to vehicle. When it is impossible or impracticable to personally serve the owner, operator or person in charge of any illegally parked vehicle within the city with a copy of charges, a notice shall be attached to the vehicle in such a manner as is consistent with the rules and regulations of the state board of public safety. (b) Removal of notice. It shall be unlawful to remove any notice described in subsection (a) of this section attached to any illegally parked vehicle unless and until the offender shall have reported to the police department in accordance with such notice. (c) Removal of vehicle. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any illegally parked vehicle from the place where the vehicle was illegally parked, except to report to the police station in compliance with the notice attached to such vehicle. (d) Impounding authorized. Whenever any vehicle shall be found parked in violation of this chapter or any city ordinance, it is subject to be impounded by the police department. Any vehicle impounded pursuant to this subsection shall remain impounded until all towing costs incurred by the city are paid by the owner or driver of such vehicle. (e) Liability of owner. The owner of a vehicle shall be equally liable with the operator for parking violations. (Code 1982, § 21-50) State Law reference— Removal of illegally stopped vehicles regulated, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-206. Sec. 86-142. - Methods. (a) Except when necessary in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals, the operator of a vehicle shall not stop, stand or park such vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway, headed in the direction of traffic, and with the curbside wheels of the vehicle within six inches of the edge of the roadway, except as follows: (1) Upon the streets which have been marked or signed for angle parking, vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the curb indicated by such marks or signs. (2) In places where, and at hours when, stopping for the loading or unloading of merchandise or materials is permitted, vehicles may back into the curb to take on or discharge loads. (b) Angle parking must conform to, and be within, the division lines. (Code 1982, § 21-51) Sec. 86-143. - Bicycles. It shall be unlawful for any person to park a bicycle upon a street other than upon the roadway against the curb, or upon the sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle, or against a building. (Code 1982, § 21-52) Sec. 86-144. - Parking for washing, greasing, repairing and advertising. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of washing, greasing or repairing the vehicle or for the purpose of displaying advertising. (Code 1982, § 21-53) Cross reference— Advertising, ch. 6. Sec. 86-145. - Parking in excess of 24 hours on public streets. Any vehicle parked on a public street for over 24 hours shall be presumed to be abandoned and may be impounded by the police department. Any vehicle impounded by the police department by reason of a presumption of abandonment on account of parking such vehicle for a period exceeding 24 hours may be redeemed by the owner or his agent by paying towing and storage charges for such vehicle impoundment. (Code 1982, § 21-54) Sec. 86-146. - Parking of trucks. (a) Regulated. No person shall stop, stand or park a truck on a public street, except while actually engaged in the loading or unloading of merchandise. (b) Nighttime in business districts. The parking of trucks having a capacity of more than one-half ton on any street within the business district shall be prohibited for more than one hour between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., unless the truck is in charge of an awake attendant during all hours, and such parked truck shall be properly lighted. (c) Daytime. It shall be unlawful to park trucks in excess of one-half ton for more than one hour from 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. (d) Nighttime in residential areas. It shall be unlawful to park or stand any truck of a weight in excess of 1½-ton capacity or any other freight conveyance of a weight in excess of 1½-ton capacity, except authorized emergency vehicles, on any city street within the residential area of the city between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. for a period of time longer than one-half hour. (Code 1982, § 21-55) Sec. 86-147. - Trucks containing flammable gas or hazardous material. Except for the purpose of legitimate deliveries, all trucks containing flammable gas or any other hazardous material of any form must be parked in private parking lots and not on streets, public property or alleyways within the city. (Code 1982, § 21-56) Cross reference— Environment, ch. 38. Sec. 86-148. - Driver to be present at parked trucks and buses of certain sizes. It shall be unlawful to park a truck or bus with a body of more than eight feet wide or ten feet high on a public street without the driver actually being present. (Code 1982, § 21-57) Sec. 86-149. - Trailers. It shall be unlawful to keep or park any trailer on any public street or other public place, or on any private property within the city, except that one trailer may be parked or stored in a private garage constructed and maintained in accordance with the provisions of the building code of the city in relation to accessory buildings constructed on the rear of residential building lots and also pursuant to building permits granted by the mayor and city council upon application for such permits; provided, however, that the mayor and city council may grant a permit for the parking of a trailer on private property, outside of such a garage, for a period not exceeding 90 days, upon application for such permit, where all residents within an area of 500 feet in all directions from the location of the property of the proposed parking of such trailer shall first consent thereto in writing to the mayor and city council. (Code 1982, § 21-58) Sec. 86-150. - Loading zones. It shall be unlawful for any person to stand or park a vehicle in a passenger or freight loading zone, except while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers or freight. (Code 1982, § 21-59) Sec. 86-151. - Parking in front of city hall. It shall be unlawful for any person to stand or park a vehicle in front of city hall, except while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers or freight. (Ord. of 9-18-1997) Secs. 86-152—86-180. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - RAILROADS
Sec. 86-181. - Compliance required. It shall be unlawful for any conductor having charge of a train, or engineer having charge of a locomotive, to violate any provision of this article. (Code 1982, § 21-70) Sec. 86-182. - Unnecessary whistle blowing. It shall be unlawful for any locomotive engineer or other person to unnecessarily blow the whistle of any railroad locomotive within the city. (Code 1982, § 21-72) Sec. 86-183. - Grade crossings. It shall be unlawful for any railroad company whose road crosses any of the streets in the city to fail, neglect or refuse, upon being notified, to have suitable crossings made and kept in good repair at the different points where such roads cross the streets, alleys, ways and public roads in the city, or for any railroad company to refuse, neglect or fail to put in good traveling order all roads in the city turned or changed for the benefit of such railroad. (Code 1982, § 21-73)

div.head: Chapter 90 - UTILITIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— The city attorney serves as the legal advisor for the utility commission, except where the utility commission employs separate or additional counsel for special assistance upon the recommendation of the city attorney and with the approval of the mayor and city council. Charter reference— Utilities, §§ 28 et seq., 33 et seq. Cross reference— Any ordinance fixing fees or utility rates and charges, not inconsistent with this Code saved from repeal, § 1-7(15); administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; electricity, § 18-41 et seq.; gas, § 18-101 et seq.; environment, ch. 38; health and sanitation, ch. 46; historic preservation, ch. 50; planning, ch. 74; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; standards for telecommunications antennas and towers, app. B, art. XIV. State Constitution reference— Municipal water and sewage services, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 90-1. - Authority to issue bonds. For the purpose of purchasing or constructing any of the utility systems, or making extensions and improvements thereto, the city is authorized to issue bonds under and in accordance with the provisions of the Charter relating to bond issues. (Code 1982, § 13-7) Charter reference— Use of utility revenues, § 33A; authorization of city to provide revenue, § 41. Sec. 90-2. - Acquisition of land for utility systems. The city may acquire, by gift, purchase or the exercise of its right of eminent domain, lands, easements, rights in land and water rights in connection therewith in order to construct, reconstruct, operate, improve, better or extend any utility system both in and out of the city limits. (Code 1982, § 13-8) Charter reference— Authority of city to purchase, etc., property, § 2. Sec. 90-3. - Income from municipal utilities. (a) After payment of necessary operating expenses, the principal and interest on bonds, maintenance and repair costs, and the costs of any extensions and improvements of utility systems, the utility commission is vested with the right and authority to invest any revenues realized from the sale of water, gas and electricity or other utilities in government bonds, bonds of the state, municipal bonds or other bonds which, in the discretion of the utility commission, are safe, or such revenues may be deposited in any bank or other depository which the commission considers safe and sound, pending the use of such funds as set forth in this subsection. (b) The mayor and city council, with the approval of the utility commission, may use, expend or invest revenue derived from the operation of utilities under the utility commission for any cause or purpose in promotion of the common welfare of the city or its citizens and, for such purpose, may use the revenue derived from the operation of such utility systems to supplement the funds available for the county board of education and for such other purpose the mayor and city council and utility commission may determine. (c) Before any funds are used for promoting the common welfare of citizens of the city or to supplement funds available to the county board of education, the mayor and city council, and utility commission, or a majority of each body, shall agree to such use and the amount to be used in each instance. (Code 1982, § 13-9) Charter reference— Use of revenue from operation of utilities, § 33A. Sec. 90-4. - Sale, lease and disposition of utility systems or grant of franchise, privilege and right to sell or distribute electric current restricted. Neither the mayor and city council, the utility commission nor the city itself may sell, lease or otherwise dispose of its waterworks, electric distribution system, gas distribution system or other utility system, or grant any franchise, privilege or right to sell or distribute electric current to any user of such current in quantities of less than 100 horsepower, or grant any franchise to pump, store or distribute water or gas within or without the city unless and until not less than 75 percent of the qualified voters of the city vote in favor of such sale, lease or other disposition of public facilities at an election called for such purpose by the mayor and city council. A notice of such election shall be published in the official county newspaper once a week for four weeks next preceding the election date, stating the time and place of the election and the purpose for which such election is held. (Code 1982, § 13-10) Charter reference— Restriction on sale, lease, disposition of utilities, etc., § 33A(b). Sec. 90-5. - Shutting off service due to nonpayment of rates. When the utility commission, under the rules made by such commission, has shut off service of gas, water, electricity or other utility from any premises where such service is supplied due to the nonpayment of rates charged for such service, the utility commission shall not, by any authority, be compelled to again renew service for such delinquent consumer, at such location or elsewhere, until all past due sums are first paid, including the charges for turning off and turning on such service. (Code 1982, § 13-11) Sec. 90-6. - Authority of mayor and council to regulate utility systems. The mayor and city council is hereby authorized to make all necessary ordinances for the purpose of protecting the city in the ownership and enjoyment of the utility systems, and for the purpose of protecting the city against loss, misuse and waste of any one or all of the municipal utilities, and the mayor and city council may adopt as ordinances all rules and regulations of the utility commission, whenever requested by such commission, in writing. (Code 1982, § 13-13) Sec. 90-7. - Extension of utilities beyond city limits. The utility commission shall have the right and authority to extend the municipal utility systems beyond the limits of the city whenever, in the sound discretion of the utility commission, such extension shall be feasible and in the best interest of all citizens of the city. (Code 1982, § 13-14) Sec. 90-8. - Authority to acquire additional municipal utility systems. The utility commission shall have the right and authority to acquire additional and other municipal utility systems, under the same rules and regulations that govern the utility systems regulated in this chapter. (Code 1982, § 13-15) Sec. 90-9. - Signs on utility poles. It shall be unlawful to tack, staple or otherwise place any sign, bill, poster or advertisement of any nature on any pole or other fixture owned, used or maintained by any public utility. (Code 1982, § 13-16) Cross reference— Signs, § 6-31 et seq. Sec. 90-10. - Theft of or damage to utility assets. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to: (1) Intentionally, and without authority and permission from the owner, injure or destroy any meter, pipe, conduit, wire, pole, lamp, manhole cover, fireplug or any accessories thereto belonging to the city, the utility commission or any other public or private utility (referred to in this section as "owner") engaged in the manufacture, sale or furnishing of electricity, gas, water, telephone, or sanitary sewer services or products, or other public services or products, without the intent to pay the fair cost of repair or replacement thereof; (2) Intentionally, and without authority and permission from the owner, utilize any such service or consume any such product with the intent not to pay the regular charge for such service or product to the owner, and with the intent to deprive the owner thereof; (3) Intentionally, and without authority and permission from the owner, prevent a meter from registering the quantity of such service or product supplied, with the intent to deprive the owner of the regular charge for such service or product; (4) In any way, interfere with the proper action of any such owner, with intent to divert any service or product so as to deprive the owner of the regular charge for such service or product; or (5) Otherwise, intentionally and without authority, use, or cause to be used, without the consent of such owner, any product or service furnished, manufactured, sold or distributed by such owner, with the intent to deprive the owner of the regular charge for such product or service. (b) Proof that a person performed any of the acts set forth in subsection (a) of this section, or proof that a person knowingly received the benefits of such acts, or proof that any of the acts specified in subsection (a) of this section were done on the premises in possession of a person, with that person's knowledge, shall be prima facie evidence that such person is responsible for such prohibited acts. (c) Every person convicted in the municipal court of the city of a violation of any provision of subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-12 of this Code. (Ord. No. 1-2001, 3-15-2001) Secs. 90-11—90-40. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - UTILITY COMMISSION[2]

Sec. 90-41. - Mayor as ex officio member. The mayor shall be an ex officio member of the utility commission, with the rights and powers of other members of the utility commission as now provided by law. (Code 1982, § 13-1) Charter reference— Creation, qualifications, qualifying fee, manner of election, etc., § 28A; utility revenues, §§ 33, 33A. Sec. 90-42. - Filling vacancies. Should a vacancy occur on the utility commission, the remaining members shall immediately notify the mayor and city council. Such vacancy shall be filled by the mayor and city council. The person selected shall serve until the next general election in the city. At such election, the unexpired term shall be filled by the qualified voters of the city. (Code 1982, § 13-2) Charter reference— Filling vacancies, § 28A. Sec. 90-43. - Compensation. The chairperson and other members of the utility commission shall receive an annual salary as provided in the Charter. All salaries shall be paid monthly by checks drawn upon funds deposited to the credit of the payroll account of the utility commission. (Code 1982, § 13-3) Charter reference— For salary, see § 13. Sec. 90-44. - Chairperson; secretary; personnel; vice chairperson. (a) Chairperson. At the next regular meeting of the utility commission following the election for any post thereon, except an election to fill the unexpired term of a member who is not the chairperson, the utility commission shall proceed to elect a chairperson, who shall serve for a period of two years. Such election shall be by secret ballot and determined by a majority vote of the utility commission, provided only a duly elected member of the utility commission may serve as chairperson. (b) Secretary. At the same meeting at which the chairperson is elected, the utility commission shall proceed to elect a secretary, who shall be a resident of the city and whose duty it shall be to attend all meetings of the utility commission, record the minutes thereof, keep a correct set of books showing all purchases of every character pertaining to the management, operation, construction and extension of the utility systems, and make regular itemized monthly reports to the utility commission, showing the receipts and disbursements, together with a statement of money in the bank and where such money is deposited. The books kept shall at all reasonable times be open to the inspection of the mayor and city council and any citizen, under proper regulations provided by the utility commission. Such books shall be audited annually by a competent certified public accountant. (c) Personnel. The utility commission shall have full power and authority to employ such personnel as may be necessary for the operation, management and supervision of the utility systems, which personnel shall be under the direct control and authority of the utility commission. (d) Vice chairperson. At the same meeting at which the chairperson is elected, the utility commission shall proceed to elect a vice chairperson who shall serve for a period of two years. Only a duly elected member of the utility commission may serve as vice chairperson. (Code 1982, § 13-4; Ord. No. 04-0115-03, 1-15-2004) Sec. 90-45. - Meetings; quorum. (a) Meetings. The utility commission shall hold regular meetings at city hall on the second Monday of every month at 7:30 p.m., unless sooner convened by a called or emergency meeting. No called meeting shall be held, except upon the written request of three members of the utility commission and upon 24 hours' notice to all members of the utility commission. All business transacted at a called or emergency meeting shall be confirmed at the next regular meeting of the utility commission and shall be spread upon the minutes thereof. (b) Quorum. A quorum of three members of the utility commission shall be required to transact any business at a regular or called meeting. (Code 1982, § 13-5) Sec. 90-46. - Powers and duties. The operation and management of the utility systems operated by the city shall be under the utility commission. The utility commission shall have full and plenary power to make all rules and regulations for the management and operation of the utility systems, and to: (1) Fix, from time to time, the rates charged for water, gas, electricity and other utilities, with the right to classify such rates; (2) Promulgate and enforce rules and regulations providing for service charges, and the right to classify such charges between resident and nonresident consumers; (3) Require a reasonable deposit in an amount sufficient to cover estimated consumption from the utility systems; (4) Make all necessary extensions and do all necessary work for the maintenance and improvement of the utility systems, and make such extensions and improvements, either by letting contracts to the lowest and best bidder, or by doing such work by its own force, as in the judgment of the utility commission, is deemed best; and (5) Carry on the business of the utility systems. (Code 1982, § 13-6) Charter reference— Powers and duties generally, §§ 28, 28A, 33, 33A. Secs. 90-47—90-80. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICITY

(Amd. of 12-16-1999) Secs. 90-144—90-160. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - WATER RESOURCE PROTECTION
Sec. 90-161. - Intent. The intent of this division is to establish minimum development standards and criteria which will afford reasonable protection of environmentally sensitive natural resources found throughout the city. It has been determined that the wise management of such resources is essential to maintaining the health, safety, general welfare and economic well-being of the public. (Ord. of 12-20-2001, § 1) Sec. 90-162. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Aquifer means any stratum or zone of rock beneath the surface of the earth which is capable of containing or producing water from a well. Drastic means the standardized system for evaluating groundwater pollution potential using the hydrogeological settings described in the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's document EPA-600-87-035. Note: The drastic methodology is the most widely used technique for evaluating pollution susceptibility. Generalized wetlands map means the current U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service National Wetlands Inventory Maps for the city. Jurisdictional wetland means an area that meets the definitional requirements for wetlands, as determined by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. Jurisdictional wetland determination means a delineation of jurisdictional wetland boundaries by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, as required by section 404 of the Clean Water Act, 33 USC 1344, as amended. Pollution susceptibility means the relative vulnerability of an aquifer to being polluted from spills, discharges, leaks, impoundments, applications of chemicals, injections and other human activities in the recharge area. Pollution susceptibility map means the relative vulnerability to pollution prepared by the state department of natural resources using the drastic methodology (Georgia Department of Natural Resources Hydrologic Atlas 20: Groundwater Pollution Susceptibility Map of Georgia). Recharge area means any portion of the earth's surface where water infiltrates into the ground to replenish an aquifer. Regulated activity means any activity which will, or which may reasonably be expected to, result in the discharge of dredged or fill material into the waters of the United States, except the activities exempted in section 404 of the Federal Clean Water Act. Significant recharge area means an area mapped by the state department of natural resources in the Hydrologic Atlas 18, 1989 edition. Water resource district means a map overlay which imposes a set of requirements in addition to the requirements of the underlying zoning district. Wetlands means the areas inundated or saturated by surface water or groundwater at a frequency and duration sufficient to support, and under normal circumstances do support, a prevalence of vegetation typically adapted for life in saturated soil conditions. Wetlands generally include swamps, marshes, bogs and similar areas. The ecological parameters for designating wetlands include hydric soils, hydrological vegetation and hydrological conditions involving a temporary or permanent source of water to cause soil saturation. (Ord. of 12-20-2001, § 3) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 90-163. - Water resource districts established. (a) The city's water resource districts shall include the following: (1) Groundwater Recharge Area District. (2) Wetlands Protection District. (b) The boundaries of the water resource districts are shown on a set of maps designated as the "water resource districts," and are included as part of the city's official zoning map, which is on file in the county zoning administrator's office, located in the county courthouse. (Ord. of 12-20-2001, § 2) Sec. 90-164. - Groundwater recharge area district. (a) Findings of fact. Recharge areas are vulnerable to urban development activities as well as agricultural activities. Pesticides, herbicides sprayed on crops, animal waste and septic tank effluents contribute to a deterioration in the groundwater quality and can threaten the health of residents relying on well water. Development usually means an increase in the amount of land covered with impervious surfaces. Paving land in recharge areas can alter or impair their recharge characteristics, thereby decreasing groundwater supplies. (b) Purpose. The purpose of the groundwater recharge area district is to establish criteria to protect significant groundwater recharge areas from pollution by spills, discharges, leaks, impoundments, applications of chemicals, injections and other development pressures. (c) Delineation. The Groundwater Recharge Area District is delineated in accordance with the state department of natural resources' Most Significant Groundwater Recharge Areas of Georgia Hydrologic Atlas 18, 1989 edition. Each recharge area shall be determined to have a pollution susceptibility of high, medium or low, based on the state Pollution Susceptibility Map Atlas 20, 1992 edition. Such maps are hereby adopted and made a part of this division. (d) Permitted uses. All uses allowed in the underlying zoning districts are permitted in the groundwater recharge area protection district. Additional requirements for specific uses are as follows: (1) New above the ground chemical or petroleum storage tanks, having a minimum volume of 660 gallons, shall have secondary containment for 110 percent of the volume of such tanks or 110 percent of the volume of the largest tank in a cluster of tanks. Such tanks used for agricultural purposes are exempt, provided they comply with all federal requirements. (2) New agricultural waste impoundment sites shall be lined if they are within a: a. High pollution susceptibility area; b. Medium pollution susceptibility area and exceed 15-acre-feet in size; and c. Low pollution susceptibility area and exceed 50 acre-feet in size. As a minimum, the liner shall be constructed of compacted clay, having a thickness of one foot and a vertical hydraulic conductivity of less than 5 by 10 -7 cm/sec (centimeters per second), or other criteria established by the National Resource and Conservation Service. (3) New homes served by septic tank/drainfield systems shall be on lots having the following minimum size limitations as identified on table MT-1 of the department of human resources' (DHR) Manual for On-Site Sewage Management Systems (referred to in this section as "DHR table MT-1"). The minimums set forth in DHR table MT-1 may be increased further, based on consideration of other factors set forth in sections A through F of the DHR manual. a. 150 percent of the subdivision minimum lot size calculated, based on application of DHR table MT-1, if they are within a high pollution susceptibility area; b. 125 percent of the subdivision minimum lot size calculated, based on application of DHR table MT-1, if they are within a medium pollution susceptibility area; c. 110 percent of the subdivision minimum lot size calculated, based on application of DHR table MT-1, if they are within a low pollution susceptibility area. (4) New manufactured home parks served by septic tank/drainfield systems shall have lots or spaces having the following size limitation as identified on table MT-2 of the department of human resources' (DHR) Manual for On-Site Sewage Management Systems (referred to in this section as "DHR table MT-2"). The minimums set forth in DHR table MT-2 may be increased further, based on consideration of other factors set forth in sections A through F of the DHR manual. a. 150 percent of the subdivision minimum lot or space size calculated, based on application of DHR table MT-2, if they are within a high pollution susceptibility area; b. 125 percent of the subdivision minimum lot or space size calculated, based on application of DHR table MT-2, if they are within a medium pollution susceptibility area; and c. 110 percent of the subdivision minimum lot size or space size calculated, based on application of DHR table MT-2, if they are within a low pollution susceptibility area. (5) No construction may proceed on a building or manufactured home to be served by a septic tank unless the county health department first approves the proposed septic tank installation as meeting the requirements of the state department of human resources' Manual for On-Site Sewage Management (referred to in this section as the "DHR manual) and subsections (d)(3) and (d)(4) of this section. (6) New facilities which handle hazardous materials of the types listed in section 312 of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976, excluding underground storage tanks, and in amounts 10,000 pounds or more on any one day, shall perform their operations on impervious surfaces and in conformance with any applicable federal spill prevention requirements and any local fire prevention code requirements. (7) Permanent stormwater infiltration basins shall not be constructed in areas having high pollution susceptibility. (e) Exemptions. Any lot of record approved prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this division is derived is exempt from the minimum lot size requirements contained in subsections (d)(3) and (d)(4) of this section. (Ord. of 12-20-2001, § 4) Sec. 90-165. - Wetlands protection district. (a) Findings of fact. The wetlands within the city are indispensable and fragile natural resources with significant development constraints due to flooding, erosion and soil limitations. In their natural state, wetlands serve man and nature, and provide habitat areas for fish, wildlife and vegetation; water quality maintenance and pollution control; flood control; natural resource education; scientific study; and recreational opportunities. (b) Purpose. The purpose of the wetlands protection district is to promote the wise use of wetlands and protect them from alterations which will significantly affect or reduce the primary functions for water quality, floodplain and erosion control, groundwater recharge, aesthetic natural areas and wildlife habitat areas. (c) Delineation. (1) The wetlands protection district is hereby established, which shall correspond to all lands within the jurisdiction of the city that are mapped as wetland areas by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife National Wetlands Inventory Maps. Such map shall be referred to as the "generalized wetlands map" and is hereby adopted by reference and declared to be part of this division, together with all explanatory matter on, and attached to, such map. (2) The generalized wetlands map does not necessarily represent the boundaries of jurisdictional wetlands within the city and cannot serve as a substitute for a delineation of wetland boundaries by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, as required by section 404 of the Clean Water Act, as amended. Any local government action under this section does not relieve the landowner from federal or state permitting requirements. (d) Wetland development permit requirements. No regulated activity or use, except as identified in subsection (e) of this section, shall be allowed within the wetlands protection district without a development permit from the city. If the area proposed for development is located within 50 feet of a wetlands protection district boundary as determined by the zoning enforcement officer using the generalized wetlands map, a U.S. Army Corps of Engineers' determination shall be required. If the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers determines that wetlands are present on the proposed development site, the development permit will not be granted until a section 404 permit or letter of permission is issued. (e) Permitted uses. The uses set forth in this subsections (e)(1) through (6) of this section are permitted by right within the wetlands protection district to the extent they are not prohibited by any other ordinance or law and, provided they do not require structures, grading, fill, draining or dredging as provided in this section. Such activities are exempt from regulations of section 404 of the Clean Water Act, provided they do not have impacts on a navigable waterway that would necessitate acquisition of an individual section 404 permit; however, under section 10 of the Rivers and Harbors Act, a permit may be required in some circumstances. (1) Forestry practices applied in accordance with best management practices approved by the state forestry commission and as specified in section 404 of the Clean Water Act. (2) Conservation or preservation of soil, water, vegetation, fish or other wildlife, provided it does not affect waters of the state or United States in such a way that would require an individual section 404 permit. (3) Outdoor passive recreational activities, including fishing, bird watching, hiking, boating, horseback riding and canoeing. (4) Cultivation of agricultural crops. Agricultural activities shall be subject to best management practices approved by the state department of agriculture. (5) Pasturing of livestock, provided that riparian wetlands are protected; soil profiles are not disturbed; and approved agricultural best management practices are followed. (6) Education, scientific research and nature trails. (f) Prohibited uses. The following uses are prohibited in the wetlands protection district: (1) Receiving areas for toxic or hazardous wastes or other contaminants. (2) Hazardous or sanitary landfills. (Ord. of 12-20-2001, § 5) Secs. 90-166—90-190. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - BACKFLOW AND CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL
Sec. 90-191. - Purpose. The purpose of this division is to protect the public potable water supply of the city from contamination or pollution by isolating within the customer's internal distribution system or private water system such contaminants or pollutants as would backflow into the public water system and promote the elimination or control of existing cross connections, actual or potential, between the customer's inplant potable water system and nonpotable water systems or plumbing fixtures and the public water system. (Code 1982, § 13-91) Sec. 90-192. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Auxiliary water supply means any water supply on, or available to, the premises, other than the purveyor's approved public water supply, and may include water from another purveyor's public potable water supply or from any natural source, or used water or industrial fluids. Such waters may be contaminated, polluted or objectionable, and may include an unacceptable water source over which the utilities commission does not have sanitary control. Backflow, cross connection and backflow preventer mean the same as defined in the Standard Plumbing Code. Contained cross connection means a connection between a potable water system and a nonpotable water system with an approved backflow preventer at the water service connection to any customer's premises, where it is physically and economically infeasible to find and permanently eliminate or control all actual or potential cross connections within the customer's water system, or where an approved backflow preventer is installed on the service line leading to and supplying a portion of a customer's water system in which there are actual or potential cross connections that cannot be effectively eliminated or controlled at the point of cross connection. Contamination means an impairment of the quality of potable water by sewage, industrial fluids or waste liquids, compounds or other materials, to a degree which creates an actual or potential hazard to the public health through poisoning or the spread of disease. Controlled cross connection means a connection between a potable water system and a nonpotable water system with an approved backflow preventer, properly installed and maintained so that it will continuously afford protection commensurate with the degree of hazard. Director means the director of utilities for the city, who is vested with the authority and responsibility for the implementation of an effective cross connection control and containment program, and for the enforcement of the provisions of this division. Hazard means a potential risk to public health adversely affecting the potable water system. Hazard to the public water system means an actual or potential threat of severe damage to physical property of the public potable water system or the consumer's potable water system, or of pollution or contamination which would have a protracted effect on the quality of potable water in the system. Health hazard means any condition, device or practice in the water supply system or the operation thereof which creates or, in the judgment of the director, may create, a danger to the health and well-being of water consumers. Industrial fluids system means any system containing a fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration constituting a health, system, pollutional or plumbing hazard if introduced into an approved water supply, including, but not limited to, the following: (1) Used waters originating from the public potable water system which may have deteriorated in sanitary quality; chemicals in fluid form; (2) Plating acids and alkalies; (3) Circulating cooling water connected to an open cooling tower and/or cooling towers that are chemically or biologically treated or stabilized with toxic substances; (4) Contaminated natural waters from wells, springs, streams, rivers, bays, harbors, seas, irrigation canals or systems, or other sources; and (5) Oils, gases, glycerines, paraffins, caustic and acid solutions and other liquid and gaseous fluids used for industrial or other purposes, or firefighting purposes. Plumbing hazard means a plumbing type cross connection in a consumer's potable water system which has not been properly protected by an approved airgap or approved backflow preventer. Pollutional hazard means an actual or potential threat to the physical properties of the water system or to the potability of the public's or the consumer's potable water system which constitutes a nuisance, or is aesthetically objectionable, or could cause damage to the system or its appurtenances, but is not dangerous to health. Used water means any water supplied by the utility commission to a consumer's water system, which has passed through the point of delivery and is no longer under the sanitary control of the utility commission. Water service connection means the terminal end of a service connection from the public potable water system, i.e., the point at which the utility commission loses jurisdiction and sanitary control over the water upon delivery to the customer's water system. If a meter is installed at the end of the service connection, then the service connection includes the downstream end of the meter. Water system means the utility system and the customer system. (1) Customer system means the parts of the facilities beyond the termination of the distribution system, which are utilized in conveying utility-delivered domestic water to points of use. (2) Distribution system means the network of conduits used for the delivery of water from the source to the customer system. (3) Source facilities means all components of the facilities utilized in the production, treatment, storage and delivery of water to the distribution system. (4) Utility system means the source facilities and the distribution system, and all facilities of the water system under the complete control of the utility commission up to the point where the customer system begins. (Code 1982, § 13-92) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 90-193. - Requirements. (a) No water service connection to any premises shall be installed or maintained unless the water supply is protected as required by state law and regulations, and this division. Service of water to any premises may be discontinued if any backflow preventer required by this division or state law is not installed, tested and maintained; if any backflow preventer has been removed or bypassed; or if any unprotected cross connection exists on the premises. Service will not be restored until such conditions or defects are corrected. Applicable requirements for backflow prevention will be complied with prior to restoration of service. (b) Any customer system shall be open for inspection at all reasonable times to authorized representatives of the utility commission to determine whether cross connections or other health hazards, plumbing hazards or pollutional hazards exist. (c) An approved backflow preventer shall be installed on each service line to a customer's water system at or near the property line or immediately inside the building being serviced, but, in all cases, before the first branch line leading off the service line, wherever the following conditions exist: (1) In the case of a premises having an auxiliary water supply which is not, or may not be, of a safe bacteriological or chemical quality and which is not acceptable to the director as an additional source, the public water system shall be protected against backflow from the premises by installing an approved backflow preventer in the service line. (2) In the case of a premises on which any industrial fluid or other objectionable substance is handled in such a fashion as to create an actual or potential hazard to the public water system, the public system shall be protected against backflow from such premises by installing an approved backflow preventer in the service line. (3) In the case of a premises having internal cross connections that cannot be permanently controlled, or having intricate plumbing and piping arrangements, or having no entry making all portions of the premises readily accessible for inspection purposes, the public water system shall be protected against backflow from the premises by installing an approved backflow preventer in the service line. (d) There shall be no unprotected takeoffs from the service line ahead of any meter or backflow preventer located at the point of delivery to the customer's water system. (e) The type of protective device required in any case shall depend upon the degree of hazard, which shall be determined as follows: (1) In the case of any premises on which there is an auxiliary water supply, the public water system shall be protected by an approved airgap separation or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. (2) In the case of any premises on which there is water or any substance which would be objectionable, but not hazardous, to health, if introduced into the public water system, the public water system shall be protected by an approved double check valve assembly. (3) In the case of any premises on which there is any material dangerous to health, which is handled in such a fashion as to create an actual or potential hazard to the public water system, the public water system shall be protected by an approved airgap separation or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow preventer. Examples of premises where such conditions exist are sewage treatment plants, sewage pumping stations, chemical manufacturing plants, hospitals, mortuaries and plating plants. (4) In the case of any premises on which there are uncontrolled cross connections, either actual or potential, the public water system shall be protected by an approved airgap separation or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow preventer installed at the service connection. (5) In the case of any premises on which, because of security requirements or other prohibitions or restrictions, it is impossible or impractical to make a complete inplant cross connection survey, the public water system shall be protected against backflow from the premises by either an approved air gap separation or an approved reduced pressure principle backflow preventer installed on each service to the premises. (6) In the case of any premises on which there is no known pollutional or contaminant hazard, the public water system shall be protected by an approved residential dual check valve installed at the service connection. (f) Any backflow preventer required in this section shall be a model and size approved by the director and manufactured in full conformity with the standards established in the latest edition of the Standard Plumbing Code. (g) If, in the judgment of the director, an approved backflow preventer, other than a residential dual check type backflow preventer, should be installed at the customer's water service connection for the safety of the customer's water system, the director shall give notice, in writing, to such customer to install the necessary backflow preventer at a specific location on his premises. The customer shall immediately install such device at his own expense, and failure, refusal or inability on the part of the customer to install, have tested and maintain such device shall constitute a ground for discontinuing water service to the premises until such requirements have been satisfactorily met. Turn-off and turn-on fees must be paid by the customer prior to restoration of service. (h) It shall be the duty of the customer at any premises where backflow preventers, other than the residential dual check valve, are installed, to have certified inspections and operational tests made at least once each year or at more frequent intervals as required by the director. Such inspections and tests shall be made at the expense of the customer, and shall be performed in a timely manner by a certified tester approved by the director. The customer shall be notified by the director in advance when the tests are to be undertaken, and may witness the tests, if so desired. Any device found to be defective shall be repaired, overhauled or replaced at the expense of the customer. Records of such tests, repairs and overhauls shall be kept by the customer and made available to the director. Residential dual check valves installed by the utility commission will be maintained by the utility commission, at its expense. (i) Any backflow preventer installed before the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived which does not meet the requirements of this section, but which was an approved device for the purposes described in this section at the time of installation, and which has been properly maintained, shall, except for the inspection and maintenance requirements under subsection (h) of this section, be excluded from the requirements of this division if the director determines that it will adequately protect the utility system. Whenever such an existing device is moved from its location, or requires more than minimum maintenance, or when the director finds that the maintenance thereof constitutes a health hazard, such device shall be replaced by an approved backflow preventer. (j) Residential dual check type backflow preventers shall be installed at the discretion of the director on new and existing services, and the customers shall pay all applicable fees for such devices. (Code 1982, § 13-93) Secs. 90-194—90-220. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - SEWERS[3]

Sec. 90-221. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l).
